tmpls.name: Card 1

fields: Name 3 major determinants of myocardial oxygen demand.

Heart rate
Myocardial contractility
Myocardial wall tension
During which phase of the cardiac cycle is the majority of blood delivered to the myocardium?
Diastole
Name the 3 vessel types which account for 75% of coronary blood flow resistance.

R1: Large epicardial arteries (trivial in the absence of IHD)
R2: Prearteriolar vessels
R3: Arteriolar and intra-myocardial capillary vessels
Name 4 non-atherosclerotic causes that limit coronary blood flow.

Spasm
Arterial thrombi (e.g. due to procoagulative state)
Coronary emboli
Ostial narrowing due to aortitis
Name the 5 major risk factors for coronary artery disease.

High LDL
Low HDL
Smoking
HTN
Diabetes
Name 4 components of athersclerotic plaque.

Fat
Smooth muscle cells
Fibroblasts
Intracellular matrix
At what degree of stenosis (%) does coronary luminal narrowing begin to limit the ability to increase flow to meet myocardial demand?
Describe 2 processes which result in thrombus formation when an atherosclerotic plaque ruptures.

Platelet activation and aggregation
Activation of the coagulation cascade leading to deposition of fibrin strands
In the event of coronary occlusion, which portion of the myocardium is most affected by ischaemia?
Subendocarium
Describe the mechanism of mitral regurgitation in acute myocardial ischaemia.
Papillary muscle involvement in the setting of large left ventricular infarct
After approximately what period of time does myocardial ischaemic damage become non-reversible?
20 minutes
Name 6 biochemical events which occur in the event of myocardial ischaemia

Fatty acids unable to be oxidised
Metabolism of glucose to lactate, causing pH drop
Reduce myocardial stores of high energy phosphates (ATP)
Potassium leak
Uptake of sodium
Increase in cytosolic calium
ST elevation reflects ischaemia of what part of the myocardium?
Severe transmural ischaemia
Describe Levine's sign.
A clenched fist held over the chest to describe angina.
Describe New York Heart Association class I functional status.
Patient has cardiac disease, but ordinary physical activity does not cause undue fatigue, palpitations, dyspnoea, or angina.
Describe New York Heart Association class II functional status.

Patient has cardiac disease resulting in slight limitation of physical activity. 
Comfortable at rest. 
Ordinary physical activity results in fatigue, palpitations, dyspnoea, or angina.
Describe New York Heart Association class III functional status.

Patient has cardiac disease resulting in marked limiation of physical activity.
Comfortable at rest.
Less than ordinary physical activity causes fatigue, palpitations, dyspnoea, or angina.
Describe New York Heart Association class IV functional status.

Patient has cardiac disease resulting in inability to carry out any physical activity without discomfort.
Symptoms may be present at rest.
Name 4 blood investigations which may be ordered for a patient with suspected new stable ischaemic heart disease.

Lipid profile
HbA1c/fasting glucose
Renal function
Haemoglobin
What ECG findings constitute a positive stress ECG test?

Flat or downsloping ST depression >0.1mV

The following are NOT considered diagnostic:
T wave abnormalities
Conduction abnormalities
Upsloping or junctional ST segment changes
Ventricular arrythmias
Failure to reach 85% predicted heart rate
Name 7 contraindications to exercise stress testing

Rest angina within 48hours of the test
Unstable rhythm
Severe aortic stenosis
Acute myocarditis
Uncontrolled heart failure
Severe pulmonary hypertension
Active infective endocarditis
What is the sensitivity of exercise stress testing?
75% (a negative test does not exclude coronary artery disease).
Histologically, the first phase of atherosclerosis is characterised by the accumulation of what cell type within intima?
Lipid-laden macrophages (foam cells) are the hallmark of early atheroma.
The thickening of the intima by accumulation of lipid-laden macrophages (foam cells) and extracellular matrix represents the first phase of atherosclerosis and is known by what term?
Fatty streaks
In patients with suspected acute coronary syndrome, what is the recommendation regarding use of supplemental oxygen therapy?
Routine use of supplemental oxygen therapy for patient's with oxygen saturation > 93% is not recommended.
Give a definition for unstable angina.
Myocardial ischaemia at rest or with minimal exertion in the absence of myocardial necrosis.
Name 9 cardiac causes of elevated troponin.

Acute coronary syndrome
Myocarditis
Aortic dissection
Takotsubocardiomyopathy
Tachyarrythmias
Heart failure
Coronary artery spasm
Aortic stenosis (structural heart disease)
Cardiac contusion/procedures
Name 4 antianginal medications used in the management of stable angina.

• -blockers
  • Nitrates
  • Calcium channel blockers
  • Ranolazine

The COURAGE trial compared PCI + medical therapy vs. medical therapy alone as an initial management strategy in patients with stable ischaemic heart disease. What was the main conclusion of this trial?

Although the addition of PCI to optimal medical therapy reduced the prevalence of angina, it did not reduce long-term rates of death, nonfatal myocardial infarction, and hospitalization for acute coronary syndromes.
https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/17387127
Name the only antianginal drug class proven to prevent reinfarction and to improve survival in patients who have sustained a myocardial infarction.
-blockers
https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed?term=8371471
Name an appropriate first line investigation for suspected stable ischaemic heart disease.
Cardiac stress testing
Describe the mechanism of action of aspirin.
Irreversible inhibition of cyclooxygenase and thereby inhibiting the formation of eicosanoids (thromboxane A<sub>2</sub>) via the oxygenation of arachidonic acid.
https://jamanetwork.com/journals/jamainternalmedicine/fullarticle/215618
The CURE trial tested the efficacy of prolonged aspirin + clopidogrel compared to aspirin alone in ACS without STEMI. What were the key findings?

• Dual antiplatelet therapy with clopidogrel and aspirin reduced cardiovascular mortality, non-fatal myocardial infarction or stroke
  • Superiority persisted throughout the 12 month study
  • Higher rates of major and minor bleeding, but no increase in life-threatening bleeding or intracranial haemorrhage
https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/11519503
What is the recommended time frame in which a patient presenting with acute chest pain or suspected acute coronary syndrome should undergo an ECG?
10 minutes
National Heart Foundation of Australia & Cardiac Society of Australia and New Zealand: Australian Clinical Guidelines for the Management of Acute Coronary Syndromes 2016
Name 7 contraindications to the use of nitrate therapy.

• Allergy
  • Hypotension (<90)
  • Bradycardia (<50)
  • Tachycardia (>100)
  • Phosphodiesterase inhibitor within the previous 24 hours
  • Hypertrophic cardiomyopathy
  • Severe aortic stenosis
ACC/AHA Guidelines for the Management of Patients With ST-Elevation Myocardial Infarction
Describe the mechanism of action of clopidogrel.
The active metabolite of the thienopyridines (clopidogrel, prasugrel) irreversibly binds to the platelet P2Y<sub>12</sub> receptor and inhibits platelet aggregation for the life of the platelet.
Australian Medicines Handbook
Describe the mechanism of action of ticagrelor.
Ticagrelor, a nuceloside analogue, reversibly inhibits the adenosine diphosphate (ADP) receptor P2Y12. The thienopyridines (clopidogrel, prasugrel) irreversibly inhibit P2Y12.
The PLATO trial compared ticagrelor and clopidogrel in patients with acute coronary syndrome. What were the findings of this study?

• Compared to clopidogrel, ticagrelor significantly reduced the rate of cardiovascular death, myocardial infarction, or stroke
  • Benefit  persisted up to 12 months
  • No increase in overall major bleeding
https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/19717846
Name  indications for coronary angiography in patients with stable ischaemic heart disease (SIHD).

• Angina that significantly interferes with a patient's lifestyle despite maximal tolerable medical therapy
  • Patients with high-risk criteria (survivors of cardiac arrest
Name the preferred first line antianginal for patients with stable ischaemic heart disease (SIHD).
-blocker
Describe the mechanism by which sudden withdrawal of -blocker therapy may precipitate exacerbation of ischaemic symptoms, including myocardial infarction.
Chronic use of -blocker therapy results in upregulation of adrenergic receptor density, and consequent increase in responsiveness to circulating catecholamines.
What is the recommended duration of dual antiplatelet therapy for patients who have undergone stenting for acute coronary syndrome.

12 months
It may be reasonable to continue dual antiplatelet therapy for greater than 12 months in patients who have a low bleeding risk
Approximately what percentage of patients with left main coronary artery disease will also have multivessel coronary artery disease?
In patients with left main coronary disease with associated multivessel disease, what is the preferred revascularisation strategry?

Patients with significant left main coronary artery disease (50%) should undergo revascularisation with either CABG or PCI
CABG is preferred in multivessel disease
In other patients, which is preferable depends on clinician and patient.
What is the preferred revascularisation strategry In patients with coronary artery disease with a  70% stenosis in  3 vessels, without proximal LAD involvement?
CABG
A "small box" on the ECG represents how many millimetres (mm), seconds or milivolts (mV)?

1mm
0.04 seconds
0.1mV
A narrow complex QRS complex on an ECG is defined as what duration of time/number of small boxes?

3 small boxes (small box = 0.04 seconds = 40 milliseconds)
120 milliseconds
The normal cardiac impulse in generated by pacemaker cells in what specialised area of the heart?
Sinoatrial node located at the juntion of the right atrium and superior vena cava.
The p wave on an ECG represents depolarisation of what cardiac structures?
Right and left atrial depolarisation. The right atrium depolarises before the left atrium and represents the first part of the p wave.
First degree heart block is diagnoses by what finding on the ECG?
A PR interval greater than 200 milliseconds (5 "small" ECG squares).
The T wave on an ECG represents repolarisation of what cardiac structures?
Ventricular repoarisation is represented by a T wave (normally) of the same polarity as the QRS complex.
What is the normal range of duration for the PR interval on an ECG?
120 milliseconds - 200 milliseconds (3 - 5 small squares)
Give a definition for heart failure with reduced ejection fraction (HFrEF).

• Symptoms signs of heart failure
  • Left ventircular ejection fracture (LVEF) < 40%
https://academic.oup.com/eurheartj/article/37/27/2129/1748921
Give a definition for heart failure with mildly reduced ejection fracture (HFmrEF).

• Symptoms signs of heart failure
  • LVEF 40 - 49%
  • Elevated levels of natriuretic peptides
  • At least one additonal criterion:
    • Relevant structural heart disease (left ventricular hypertrophy and/or left atrial enlargement)
    • Diastolic dysfunction
https://academic.oup.com/eurheartj/article/37/27/2129/1748921
Give a definition for heart failure with preserved ejection fraction (HFpEF).

• Symptoms signs of heart failure
  • Left ventricular ejection fraction > 50%
  • Elevated levels of natriuretic peptids
  • At least one additional criterion:
    • Relevant structural heart disease (left ventricular hypertrophy and/or left atrial enlargement)
    • Diastolic dysfunction
https://academic.oup.com/eurheartj/article/37/27/2129/1748921
The Killip classification is a system used to stratify risk of death following acute myocardial infarction. What is Killip class I?
Individuals with no clinical signs of heart failure.
Name 4 recreational substances which may cause heart failure.

• Alcohol
  • Cocaine
  • Amphetamine
  • Anabolic steroids
https://academic.oup.com/eurheartj/article/37/27/2129/1748921
Name 4 heavy metals which may cause heart failure.

• Copper
  • Iron
  • Lead
  • Cobalt
Name the recommended technique for measurement of left ventricular ejection fraction using echocardiography.
Modified biplane Simpson's rule
https://academic.oup.com/eurheartj/article/37/27/2129/1748921
Name 8 which should be considered in the initial assessment of a patient with newly diagnosed heart failure.

• FBE
  • UEC
  • LFTs
  • Hba1c/fasting glucose
  • Lipid profile
  • TSH
  • Iron studies
  • Natriuretic peptics
https://academic.oup.com/eurheartj/article/37/27/2129/1748921
Name 2 echocardiographic measurements which are important in determining right ventricular systolic function.

• Tricuspid annular plane systolic excursion
  • Tricuspid lateral annular systolic velocity
https://academic.oup.com/eurheartj/article/37/27/2129/1748921
Name 3 causes of heart failure where genetic testing is recommended.

• Hypertrophic cardiomyopathy (HCM)
  • Idiopathic dilated cardiomyopathy (DCM)
  • Arrhythmogenic right ventricular cardiomyopathy (ARVC)
https://academic.oup.com/eurheartj/article/37/27/2129/1748921

The SPRINT trial compared intensive blood pressure control (target systolic blood pressure < 120 mm Hg) in patients at high risk for cardiovascular disease without stroke or diabetes to standard treatment (target systolic blood pressure 135 - 139 mm Hg). What were the key findings?

In patients at high risk for CVD (without previous stroke or diabetes), intensive BP control (target systolic blood pressure <120mm Hg) improved cardiovascular outcomes and overall survival compared to standard therapy (target SBP 135 - 139mm Hg).
https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/26551272
Describe the mechanism of action of empagliflozin.
Inhibition of sodium-glucose co-transporter 2
Australian Medicines Handbook
Name 4 treatments (or combination of treatments) that may cause harm in patients with symptomatic (NYHA Class II - IV) heart failure with reduced ejection fraction (HFrEF)

• Thiazolidinediones (glitazones)
  • NSAIDs or COX-2 inhibitors
  • Diltiazem or verapamil
  • Adding an ARB to an ACE-I + MRA (risk of hyperkalaemia and renal dysfunction)
https://academic.oup.com/eurheartj/article/37/27/2129/1748921
Describe the universal definition of myocardial infarction.

A combination of criteria is required to meet the diagnosis of acute myocardial infarction:
  • Abnormal cardiac biomarker (value above 99th percentile reference limit)
Plus at least one of the following:
  • Symptoms of ischaemia
  • New significant ST-T wave changes or left bundle branch block
  • Pathological Q waves
  • Imaging evidence of new loss of viable myocardium or regional wall motion abnormality
  • Intracoronary thrombus detected on angiography or autopsy
https://academic.oup.com/eurheartj/article/37/3/267/2466099
Give a definition for type 1 myocardial infarction.
Myocardial necrosis due to disruption of an atherosclerotic plaque, consequent intraluminal thrombus and reduced myocardial blood flow.
https://academic.oup.com/eurheartj/article/37/3/267/2466099
Give a definition for type 2 myocardial infarction.

Myocardial necrosis in which a condition other than coronary plaque disruption results in an imbalance between myocardial oxygen supply and demand. Mechanisms include tachyarrythmias, coronary artery spasm, anaemia, etc.
https://academic.oup.com/eurheartj/article/37/3/267/2466099
Name 8 non-cardiac causes of troponin elevation.

Hypertensive emergency
Critical illness (e.g. shock/sepsis/burns)
Pulmonary embolsim
Pulmonary hypertension
Renal failure
Acute neurological event (stroke/subarachnoid haemorrhage)
Thyroid disease
Infiltrative diseases (amyloidosis, haemchromatosis)
https://academic.oup.com/eurheartj/article/37/3/267/2466099#42049200
Which cardiac biomarker is most useful in the detection of early reinfarction.

CK-MB
Has a more rapid decline after MI, as compared with cardiac troponin.
https://academic.oup.com/eurheartj/article/37/3/267/2466099#42049200
Name the most common cause of left ventricular outflow obstruction.
Aortic stenosis
Name 3 symptoms of aortic stenosis.

Exertional dyspnoea or reduced exercise tolerance
Exertional presyncope or syncope
Exertional angina

Symptoms rarely occur before stenosis is severe.
If these symptoms occur in mild-mod AS, seek other causes.
Name the only 2 effective treatments for severe aortic stenosis.

Surgical aortic valve replacement (SAVR)
Transcatheter aortic valve implantation (TAVI)
Name the 4 main parameters used to identity severe aortic stenosis.

Aortic jet velocity (4.0m/s)
Mean transvalvular pressure gradient (40mmHg)
Valve area <1cm
DVI < 0.25
Describe the valvular anatomy in Stage A aortic stenosis.

Stage A refers to patients who are at risk of developing aortic stenosis.
Bicuspid aortic valve (or other)
Describe the valvular anatomy in Stage B aortic stenosis.

Mild - moderate leaflet calcification with some reduction in systolic motion
OR
Rheumatic valve changes with commisural fusion
Name the 4 key steps in determining whether a patient with aortic stenosis has an indication for valve replacement.

Patient symptoms status
Determine severity of aortic stenosis (echocardiogram)
Assess left ventricular ejection fraction
Determination of whether other cardiac surgery is indicated
Name the 2 factors which lead to exertional dyspnoea in aortic stenosis.

Diastolic dysfunction with an increase in left ventricular filling pressures with exercise
Left ventricle unable to increase cardiac output with exercise
Describe the histological features of achalasia.

Reduced neurons/ganglion cells in the myeteric plexus.
Remaining ganglion cells are surrounded by lymphocytes.
What investigation is required to diagnose achalasia.
Oesophageal manometry.
Using conventional manometry, what findings are suggestive achalasia.

Incomplete relaxation of oesophageal sphincter (LES pressure > 8mmHg above gastric pressure at nadir)
Aperistalsis in the distal oesophagus
Elevated resting lower oesophageal sphincter pressure (hypertensive LES > 45 mmHg)
What is the current theory regarding the aetiology of primary achalasia.

Primary achalasia is idiopathic but is thought to result from inflammation and degeneration of neurons in the oesophageal wall possibly due to an autoimmune disorder.
May be triggered by HSV-1 infection but this is inconclusive.
What is the role of endoscopy in the investigation of suspected achalasia.
Endoscopy should be performed to exclude malignancy at the oesophago-gastric junction.
Name  endoscopic features suggestive of achalasia.

Dilated oesophagus containing residual material
Unusually increased resistance to passage of endoscopy through oesophagogastric junction

Oesophageal mucosa is usually normal in appearance.
Using high-resolution oesophageal manometry, a diagnosis of achalasia is suggested by what finding?

Elevated integrated relaxation pressure (>15mmHg).
Integrated relaxation pressure represents the median of the maximal relaxation pressures in four seconds during the 10-second window of the oesophagogastric junction relaxation that follows a swallow.
What are the findings and diagnosis demonstrated in this barium oesophagram?

Dilated oesophagus
Bird's beak appearance of distal oesophagus
Retained food
Appearance typical of achalasia.
What are the findings and diagnosis?

Simple columnar epithelium extending well above oesophagogastric junction (instead of normal stratified squamous epithelium)
Barret's oesophagus
Name 10 manifestations of IgG4 related disease.

Lymphadenopathy
Type 1 autoimmune pancreatitis
Sclerosing cholangitis
Dacryoadenitis
Sclerosing sialedinitis
Retroperitoneal fibrosis
Aortitis
Thyroiditis (Riedel's thyroiditis)
Lung nodules
Tubulointerstitial nephritis
Describe how a diagnosis of IgG4 related disease is usually made.

Biopsy demonstrating characteristic histopathological findings and immunohistochemical staining.
Supported by elevated serum IgG4 levels (although these are not diagnostic).
Name 5 studies which are part of the postdiagnostic evaluation for IgG4 related disease.

CT chest, abdomen and pelvis
Urinalysis (proteinuria in subclinical tubulointerstitial nephritis)
Serum complement levels (often profoundly low in tubulointerstitial nephritis)
Serum IgE (marker of allergic disease)
FBE (eosinophil count)
Name 4 histological features of IgG4 related disease.

Storiform fibrosis
Dense lymphoplasmacytic infiltration with predominantly IgG4 positive plasma cells
Obliterative phlebitis
Tissue eosinophilia
Name the most common demongraphic affected by IgG4 related disease.

Middle-aged and older men.
The gender discrepancy normalises for disease involving the head and neck.
Why are biopsies of lymph nodes inadequate for diagnosis IgG4 related disease?

Lymph nodes usually do not demonstrate the hallmark histological feature of IgG4 related disease: storiform fibrosis.
Dense infiltration of IgG positive plasma cells is not unique to IgG4 related disease.
Fine-needle aspirates do not provide adequate tissue.
Give a definition for IgG4 related disease

An immune mediated disease comprising a collection of disorders that share pathological, serological and clincial features:
Tumour-like swelling of involved organs
Lymphoplasmacytic infiltrate enriched in IgG4 positive plasma cells
Fibrosis with characteristic storiform pattern
Elevated serum IgG4
What is the most common presentation of autoimmune pancreatitis?
Obstructive jaundice
Give a definition for primary sclerosing cholangitis.
Chronic progressive disorder of unknown aetiology characterised by inflammation, fibrosis and stricturing of medium and large ducts in the intrahepatic and/or extrahepatic biliary trees.
Describe the diagnostic approach for patients with suspected primary sclerosing cholangitis.

IgG4 level (to identify patients with IgG4 related disease)
Antimitochondrial antibodies (to differentiate from primary biliary cirrhosis)
Cholangiography (usually MRCP is first line investigation)
What is the role of liver biopsy in the diagnosis of patients with primary sclerosing cholangitis?

Liver biopsy is seldom diagnostic.
Can be performed in patients with suspected small duct primary sclerosing cholangitis (i.e. patients with normal cholangiography).
Histology is often non-specific and similar to primary biliary cirrhosis.
In a patient with primary sclerosing cholangitis and a gallbladder mass, what is the most appropriate next step?

Cholecystectomy
Gallbladder mass in patients with PSC may represent gallbladder carcinoma.
Patients diagnosed with primary sclerosing cholangitis should be screened for what strongly associated disease?
Ulcerative colitis
Disease progression in arrhythmogenic right ventricular cardiomyopathy may be accelerated by?
Endurance exercise
Arrhythmogenic right ventricular cardiomyopathy is usually caused by mutations in genes which encode what type of proteins?
Desmosomal proteins
Describe the hallmark histological finding in arrhythmogenic right ventricular cardiomyopathy?
Fibrofatty infiltration of the myocardium
Name the most common pattern of inheritance for arrhythmogenic right ventricular cardiomyopathy.
Autosomal dominant
What is the average age of presentation for arrhythmogenic right ventricular cardiomopathy?
30 years
Name the most common cause of sudden cardiac arrest in patients less than 35 years of age.
Hypertrophic obstructive cardiomyopathy (HOCM)
Give a definition for primary sclerosing cholangitis
Chronic progressive disorder of unknown aetiology characterised by inflammation, fibrosis and stricturing of medium and large ducts in the intrahepatic and/or extra hepatic biliary trees
What proportion of primary sclerosing cholangitis patients have concomittant ulcerative colitis?
90% (if routine rectal and sigmoid biopsies taken)
What proportion of ulcerative colitis patients have concomittant primary sclerosing cholangitis?

5%

Only UC patients with abnormal LFTs should undergo evaluation for PSC
First-degree relatives of patients with primary sclerosing cholangitis are at increased risk of which two diseases?

Primary sclerosing cholangitis
Ulcerative colitis
Name 5 symptoms of primary sclerosing cholangitis

Fatigue
Prutitis
Less common: fevers/chills, night sweats, right upper quadrant pain
What proportion of patients diagnosed with primary sclerosing cholangitis are asymptomatic?
Pruritis in primary sclerosing cholangitis is often debilitating. Would you expect an elevated bilirubin in such patients?

No

Pruritis of cholestasis in patients with PSC is often occurs with normal bilirubin.
Name 3 indications for liver transplantation in patients with primary sclerosing cholangitis

MELD score > 15
Recurrent or refractory cholangitis
Intractable pruritis

The usual indications for liver transplantation (e.g. acute liver failure) also apply.
Name 4 clinical signs that may be present at diagnosis in patients with primary sclerosing cholangitis

Jaundice
Hepatomegaly
Splenomegaly
Excoriations

50% of patients will have no findings
Describe the expected LFT abnormalities in patients with primary sclerosing cholangitis

Cholestatic pattern.
Elevated ALP (most patients)
Elevated bilirubin
Hypoalbuminaemia (late stage)

Elevations in ALP and bilirubin fluctuate, possibly indicating transient blockage of stricture bile ducts by sludge or small stones
A patient with primary sclerosing cholangitis has a persistently elevated bilirubin on serial LFTs. This is indicative of what disease stage?
Advanced disease
Name 3 autoantibodies that may be positive in patients with primary sclerosing cholangitis

ANA (75%)
Anti smooth muscle (75%)
P-ANCA against nuclear envelope protein (80%)
Which immunoglobulin may be elevated in patients with primary sclerosing cholangitis?
Name 3 diagnostic investigations that may be useful in patients with suspected primary sclerosing cholangitis

MRCP (best)
ERCP (if MRI contraindicated)
Percutaneous transhepatic cholangiography (PTC)
Why would an antimitochondrial antibody (AMA) test be ordered for a patient with suspected primary sclerosing cholangitis?
To exclude a differential diagnosis of primary biliary cholangitis
Describe the features of primary sclerosing cholangitis seen on cholangiography
Multifocal stricturing and dilation of intrahepatic and/or extrahepatic bile ducts
Name 7 pathology investigations that may be ordered in a patient with suspected primary sclerosing cholangitis

LFTs
ANA
P-ANCA
IgM level
Anti-smooth muscle antibodies
IgG4 level (screen for IgG4 associated disease)
Anti-mitochondrial antibodies (exclude prmary biliary cholangitis)
What is the difference between classic and small duct primary sclerosing cholangitis?

Classic: findings present on cholangiography
Small duct: normal cholangiography, diagnosis made on liver biopsy
Describe the pattern of bile duct involvement in classic primary biliary cirrhosis

Majority intrahepatic and extrahepatic ducts (87%)
May involve gallbladder and cystic duct

Intrahepatic alone (11%) and extrahepatic alone (2%) rare
Is liver biopsy recommended for patients with suspected primary sclerosing cholangitis?

No.

Liver biopsy is rarely diagnostic of PSC
Histology demonstrates fibrous obliteration of small bile ducts with concentric replacement by connective tissue in an "onion skin" pattern.
Seen in less than 25% of liver biopsies.

Biopsy is indicated if small duct PSC is suspected
Of classic and small duct primary sclerosing cholangitis, which has the better prognosis?

Small duct PSC has a far better prognosis
It may progress to classic PSC
What is the median survival from diagnosis with primary sclerosing cholangitis?
10 - 12 years
Is ultrasound a useful investigation for patients with suspected primary sclerosing cholangitis?

No

May reveal abnormal bile ducts, but the examination may be normal.
Findings include bile duct wall thickening, enlargement, cholelithiasis, cholecystitis.
What is poststreptococcal glomerulonephritis caused by?
A specific nephritogenic strain of group A beta-haemolytic streptococcus
What is the most comon cause of nephritic syndrome in children globally?
Poststreptococcal glomerulonephritis
Describe the pathogenesis of poststreptococcal glomerulonephritis (3)

- Patient nephritogenic strains of group A beta-haemolytic streptococcus (GAS)
- Forms immune complexes (antigen antibody complexes)
- Deposition of complexes as subepithelial humps within the glomeruli, complement activation
Influx of inflammatory cells into the glomerulus --> proliferative GN
Describe the the expected light microscopy findings in poststreptococcal glomerulonephritis (5)

Diffuse proliferative glomerulonephritis
Prominent endocapillary proliferation
Numerous neutrophils
Trichrome stain: small subepithelial hump-shaped deposits
Crescents uncommon, confer poor prognosis

Severity correlates with clinical findings

(A) Light microscopy showing a proliferative (exudative) glomerulonephritis. Note numerous neutrophils within glomerular capillaries (Periodic acid Schiff, 40x).
(B) Immunofluorescence microscopy showing bright granular capillary wall staining for C3 (40x).
(C) Immunofluorescence microscopy showing bright granular capillary wall staining for IgG (40x).
(D) Electron microscopy showing a subepithelial electron dense deposit (subepithelial hump, 79900x).
What disease is shown below? Describe the findings shown, and the expected findings in this disease.

Poststreptococcal glomerulonephritis light microscopy.

Findings shown: marked cellular proliferation and neutrophillic infiltration within the glomerular tuft. Few open capillary lumens.
Expected findings: Diffuse proliferative GN (as described above) with prominent endocapillary proliferation and numerous neutrophils.
Severity correlates with clinical findings.

Below is a normal glomerulus for comparison.
Describe what is shown below.
Renal biopsy immunofluorescence microscopy showing bright granular capillary wall staining for C3 in a patient with poststreptococcal glomerulonephritis.
Describe what is shown below.
Renal biopsy immunofluorescene microscopy showing bright granular capillary wall staining for IgG in a patient with poststreptococcal glomerulonephritis.
What is shown below?

Electron microscopy showing a subepithelial electron dense deposit (subepithelial 'hump') in a patient with poststreptococcal glomerulonephritis.
Hump contains immune complexes, IgG, C3
Describe what you would expect to find on immunofluorescence microscopy in a patient with poststreptococcal glomerulonephritis

IgG and C3 in diffuse granular pattern within the mesangium and glomarular capillary walls
Granular pattern is called 'starry sky' pattern
May also see IgN, IgA, fibrin


(A) Light microscopy showing a proliferative (exudative) glomerulonephritis. Note numerous neutrophils within glomerular capillaries (Periodic acid Schiff, 40x).
(B) Immunofluorescence microscopy showing bright granular capillary wall staining for C3 (40x).
(C) Immunofluorescence microscopy showing bright granular capillary wall staining for IgG (40x).
(D) Electron microscopy showing a subepithelial electron dense deposit (subepithelial hump, 79900x).
Describe what you would expect to see on electron microscopy in a patient with poststreptococcal glomerulonepritis

Dome shaped subepithelial electron-dense deposits called humps
These are deposits of immune complexes, IgG, and C3
Describe the clinical manifestations of poststreptococcal glomerulonephritis

Asymptomatic with microscopic haematuria (most patients)
Acute nephritic syndrome 
- Hypertension, haematuria, red cell casts, pyuria, mild-mod proteinuria
Oedema
Elevated creatinine
Antecedent history of group A streptococcal skin (3 - 6 weeks ago) or throat infection (1 - 3 weeks ago)
Name the 5 components of acute nephritic syndrome
Hypertension, haematuria, red cell casts, pyuria, mild-mod proteinuria
Describe what may be seen on urinalysis in a patient with poststreptococcal glomerulonephritis

Haematuria - dysmorphic red cells
+/- red cell casts, 
Variable proteinuria (may be nephrotic range in 5% of patients)
White cells
Name 5 investigations which may be ordered for a patient with suspected poststreptococcal glomerulonephritis

UEC - elevated creatinine
Urinalysis - haematuria, red cell casts, proteinuria, white cells
C3 - low
Blood cultures
Streptozyme test (contains 5 streptococcal antibodies)

Renal biopsy seldom required.
When might a renal biopsy be required for a patient with suspected poststreptococcal glomerulonephritis? (6)

Significant renal imapirment progressing towards dialysis, to confirm diagnosis 
- patients with >30% crescents on biopsy are often treated with immunosuppression via pulsed methylpred
Disease course deviates from expected
Presents late without clear history of group A strep infection
Persistently low C3 beyond 6 weeks (suggestive of membranous GN)
Recurrent episodes of haematuria (suggetive of IgA)
Persistent or progressive increase increase in serum creatinine (uncharacteristic of post-strep GN)
Describe the management of poststreptococcal glomerulonephritis

Management is supportive care.
- Manage complications of fluid overload such as hypertension or pulmonary oedema, via sodium restriction and loop diuretics
- Dialysis rarely required
- Antibiotics not required as postinfective
Give a definition for membranous glomerulonephritis
Glomerular basement membrane thickening with little or no cellular proliferation or infiltration on light microscopy
Name the two most common causes for nephrotic syndrome in adults

Membranous glomerulonephritis (20 - 30% cases caucasians)
Focal segmental glomerulonephritis
Describe the association between malignancy and membranous glomerulonephritis

Associated with malignancy in 25 - 30% of cases
Most commonly solid organ tumours
Malignancy is usually diagnosed before the membranous GN
A diagnosis of MN should not prompt an extensive search for occult malignancy in the absence of a suggestive clinical finding. Age appropriate screening should be implemented.
What age is the peak incidence of membranous glomerulonephritis?
What is the male:female ratio for membranous glomerulonephritis?
Male to female 2:1
Describe the characteristic findings on light microscopy in membranous glomerulonephritis.

Thickening of the glomerular basement membrane throughout all glomeruli
Absence of significant hypercellularity


Normal:
Describe the findings seen on immunofluoresence in patients with membranous glomerulonephritis
Diffuse granular pattern of IgG and C3 along the GBM/along the capillary walls (same thing)
Describe the electron microscopy findings seen in membranous glomerulonephritis (3)

Subepithelial electron dense deposits on the outer aspect of the GBM 
Effacement of foot processes of the overlying podocyte,
Expansion of the GBM by deposition of new extracellular matrix between the immune deposits
Describe the pathogenesis of membranous glomerulonephritis
Glomerular basement membrane expansion occurs due to immune deposits (IgG, C3) within the glomerular basement membrane, causing diffuse thickening
Membranous glomerulonephritis is said to have a 'spike' appearance on silver stain. Why is this so?

Basement membrane takes up the silver stain; immune deposits do not.
In membranous GN, the thickened basement membrane is interdispersed with immune deposits which do not stain.
This makes it look like the basement membrane has projections or 'spikes' on the stain.
Label this glomerulus.
What is the diagnosis? Name two characteristic findings seen here.

Membranous glomerulonephritis
-Capillary loops are thickened and prominent
-Cellularity is not increased
What is the diagnosis? Describe the findings below.

Electron microscopy of membranous glomerulonephritis.
Electron dense deposits (D) seen in the subepithelial space across the GBM and under the epithelial cells (Ep). There is new basement membrane growing between the deposits, which will give a spike appearance on silver stain.

(Top left box - urinary space. Bottom right box - capillary lumen)
Membranous glomerulonephritis may be broadly catagorised into two categories. What are they?

Idiopathic (75%)
Secondary
Describe the significance of phospholipase A2 receptor (PLA2R) antibodies in idiopathic membranous glomerulonephritis

Thought to be a possible cause of idiopathic MN
PLA2R is a transmembrane receptor expressed in glomerular podocytes
Anti-PLA2R identified in 70% of patients with idiopathic MN and 0% controls in one study
May also be useful for monitoring clinical status; higher titres correlate with poorer outcome
Name 8 causes of secondary membranous glomerulonephritis

SLE
Drugs
Infections
Malignancy
IgG4 related disease
Haematopoietic cell transplant and graft-vs-host disease
Post renal transplantation (recurrent or de novo)
Sarcoidosis (rare)
Name 4 infections associated with membranous glomerulonephritis

Hepatitis B - may have low complement
Hepatitis C (chronic) (uncommon)
Syphilis
HIV
Name 5 drugs that may cause membranous nephropathy

NSAIDs
Penicillamine
Gold salts
Bucillamine
Anti-TNF
Describe the significance of thrombospondin type-1 domain-containing 7A (THSD7A) in membranous glomerulonephritis

A transmembrane receptor expressed on glomerular podocytes
Antibodies expressed in 10% of idiopathic MN patients who are also negative for PLA2R
May be more prevalent in Japanese, less in North American and European populations
Describe the type of liver metastases that may be amenable to resection

Colorectal or GI neuroendocrine origin
Can be resected completely, leaving adequate liver
Extrahepatic disease not an absolute contraindication, so long as complete resection (margin negative) is possible
What percentage of metastatic colorectal cancer patients with liver metastases are amenable to resection?
Describe the management of unresectable liver metastases in colorectal cancer

Consider neoadjuvant chemo to attempt to downstage to resectable, or
Radiofrequency ablation
What kind of colorectal liver metastases are most appropriate for radiofrequency ablation?

Unresectable
<3 lesions
<3cm size
Not near major vascular structures
Name the 2 most common histological types of prostate cancer

Adenocarcinoma (95%)
Small cell (neuroendocrine)
Describe the mechanism of androgen production and regulation in men

GnRH released from hypothalamus
Stimulates release of LH and FSH from anterior pituitary
LH stimulates androgens production by testes (Leydig cells) (90 - 95%) and the adrenals (5%)
Testosterone has negative feedback effect on anterior pituitary and hypothalamus
Where is PSA produced?

Prostate cells
Not produced anywhere else
Name 3 causes of an elevated PSA

Prostate cancer
BPH
Prostatitis
Is PSA specific for prostate cancer?

No.
Specific for prostate but not for prostate cancer, can be elevated due to benign prostate pathology.
What is PSA density?

Ratio of prostate size to PSA (usually via CT or MRI; DRE inaccurate)
High density is bad
What is fractionated PSA?

Percentage of PSA present as conjugated or free
High free PSA (>30%) is favourable, low (<10%) associated with cancer
Describe the utility of DRE in diagnosing prostate cancer.

Detects cancer in posterior and lateral glans aspects
Does not detect tumours in other parts of the prostate (25 - 35%)
Cannot detect small (T1) tumours
A digital rectal examination is performed in a patient with a normal PSA. Findings are considered suspicious for prostate cancer. Is a biopsy indicated?

Yes.
Biopsy indicated for concerning findings on DRE, regardless of PSA or other risk factors
A patient with an abnormal digital rectal examination and normal PSA has a transrectal ultrasound performed. The ultrasound is reported as normal. Is biopsy indicated?

Yes.
Biopsy indicated for concerning findings on DRE, regardless of PSA or other risk factors
Biopsy cannot be avoided by obtaining a normal transrectal ultrasound in patients with abnormal DRE (possibility of false negatives)
Is transrectal ultrasound recommended as part of the diagnostic workup for prostate cancer?

No.
Possibility of false negatives.
Useful during biopsies to target lesions for biopsy
Describe Gleason grade.

Based on the architectural features of prostate cancer cells
Correlates well with clinical behaviour
Grade 1 - 5 from most to least differentiated
Describe composite Gleason score.

Derived from adding together the two most prominent Gleason grades
E.g. A biopsy is predominantly grade 3 with secondary grade 4 disease; the composite score is "3+4" or 7.
Describe Gleason grade group

Updated way of stratifying composite Gleason scores into risk groups.
Correlates well with prognosis

Grade group 1: composite Gleason score <6
Grade group 2: score 3+4 = 7
Grade group 3: score 4+3 = 7
Grade group 4: score 8 
Grade group 5: score 9 - 10
Name 3 histopathological factors that correlate with poor prognosis in prostate cancer

Higher Gleason grade, composite Gleason score, and grade group
Perineural invasion
Higher percentage of positive biopsies
Name 3 factors used to determine clinical stage of prostate cancer

TNM stage
Grade group
Preoperative PSA
Describe pathological T staging of prostate cancer

T2 - organ confined
T3 - extraprostatic extension
T4 - tumour is fixed or invdes adjacent structures other than semial vesicles
What percentage of prostate cancer patients are upgraded to a higher stage following radical prostatectomy?
Describe clinical T staging of prostate cancer

T1 - clinically inapparent tumour that is not palpable
T2 - Tumour palpable, confined within prostate
T3 - extraprostatic tumour that is not fixed or does not invade surrounding structures
T4 - tumour is fixed or invades surrounding structures other than seminal vesicles
Describe clinical N staging of prostate cancer

Nx - not assessed
N0 - no positive regional nodes
N1 - metastases in regional node(s)
Describe clinical M staging of prostate cancer

M0 - no distant mets
M1 - distant metastasis
   M1a - nonregional lymph nodes
   M1b - bone(s)
   M1c - other sites with or without bone disease
Describe the criteria for NCCN very low risk prostate cancer

Detected by elevated PSA
No abnormalities on DRE
Histologic grade group 1 (Gleason score <6)
PSA <10
<3 biopsy cores positive, less than 50% involvement per core
PSA density less than 0.15ng/mL
Describe the management of NCCN very low risk prostate cancer

Life expectancy < 20 years: Active surveillance
Life expectancy > 20 years: Active surveilance OR radiation therapy (external beam or brachytherapy) OR radical prostatectomy
Describe the criteria for NCCN low risk prostate cancer

Normal DRE or disease limited to one lobe only (T0 - T2a)
Histologic grade group 1 (Gleason score <6)
PSA <10
Describe the management for NCCN low risk prostate cancer

Active surveillance, or
Radiation therapy (external beam or brachytherapy), or
Radical prostatectomy (lymph node dissection optional)

Very little data on which of the above is preferable; one large randomised trial (ProtecT) showed no significant difference in 10 year survival between the three
Describe the criteria for NCCN intermediate risk prostate cancer.

At least one of the following:

T2b (involving more than one half of one lobe) or T2c (bilateral disease)
Gleason score 7
PSA 10 - 20
Describe the management for NCCN intermediate risk prostate cancer.

Active surveillance (if life expectancy <10 years), or
External beam RT +/- ADT (4 - 6 months), or
Radical prostatectomy with pelvic lymph node dissection
Describe the criteria for high risk prostate cancer

T3a, or
Gleason score 8 - 10, or
PSA >20
Describe the management for high risk prostate cancer

RT (external beam or brachytherapy) + ADT, or
RT (external beam) + docetaxel, or
Radical prostatectomy with extended pelvic lymph node dissection
Describe the NCCN criteria for very high risk prostate cancer

T3b or T4 with seminal vesicle involvement, tumor fixation, or invasion of adjacent organs, or
Primary Gleason grade 5, or
Gleason grade group 4 or 5 (score 8 - 10)
Describe the management of NCCN very high risk prostate cancer

RT (external beam) +/- brachytherapy + long term ADT, or
RT (external beam) + docetaxel, or
Radical prostatectomy with extended pelvic node dissection
Describe the management of prostate cancer with nodal metastasis

RT (external beam) + ADT, or
ADT alone

Nodal mets denote stage IV disease.
Describe NCCN recommendations for ongoing monitoring post definitive therapy for early prostate cancer

PSA every 6 - 12 months for 5 years, then every year
DRE every year (may be omitted if PSA undetectable)
Describe the management of failure of PSA to fall to undetectable levels post definitive therapy

Check PSA doubling time
Imaging to seek distant metastases
- If present, ADT + RT (external beam) to metastases if weight bearing/symptomatic
- if not present, ADT +/- RT

In both cases, can observe instead and institute treatment when symptoms develop of PSA changes to suggest symptoms are imminent
Describe the mechanism of action of goserelin

Used for prostate cancer
Gonadotropin-releasing hormone agonist (also leuprolide, buserelin)
Bind to GnRH receptor on pituitary gonadotropin-releasing cells, causing release of FSH and LH, and increased testosterone from Leydig cells
After 1 week GnRH receptors are downregulated on GnRH-producing cells, causing fall in LH and FSH. Fall in LH leads to fall in testosterone
Castrate levels achieved after 3 - 4 weeks (<1.7nmol/L)
Describe the 'flare phenomenon' seen with GnRH agonist ADT

GnRH agonists initially cause rise in LH (and FSH), and hence testosterone
Downregulation of GnRH receptors occurs 1 week later, causing fall in LH and hence testosterone
In meantime increased testosterone can cause transient worsening of disease
How can the 'flare phenomenon' seen with GnRH agonist ADT be prevented?

Antiandrogens commenced 1 week prior (if high risk) or concurrently
- flutamide, bicalutamide, nilutamide
In which patients in GnRH agonist ADT alone contraindicated?

Patients in whom transient worsening of prostate cancer could have dire consequences:
Impending cord compression
Severe urinary tract obstruction
Painful bony metastases

Can be given with antiandrogens (e.g. flutamide, bicalutamide, nilutamide) to mitigate risk.
Describe the mechanism of action of Degarelix

GnRH antagonist used for prostate cancer (ADT)
Avoids flare phenomenon seen in GnRH agonists
Suppresses testosterone faster (within 3 days vs 3 - 4 weeks)
Name 8 side effects of ADT

Sexual dysfunction
Loss of bone mineral density (increased bone turnover)
Hot flashes
Gynaecomastia
Fatigue
Increased cardiovascular disease and diabetes
Decreased muscle with increased fat
Anaemia
Describe the mechism of action of antiandrogens

Bind to androgen receptors and competitively inhibit their binding to testosterone
No role in treatment of prostate cancer except to prevent flare phenomenon with GnRH agonist ADT
Describe the management of castrate sensitive metastatic prostate cancer

ADT alone, or
ADT + abiraterone, or
ADT + docetaxel

Significant survival benefit with addition of abiraterone or docetaxel to ADT in high risk/high volume disease
May also be used in low risk/low volume disease (grade 2B)
Describe the mechanism of action of abiraterone

Used for treatment of metastatic prostate cancer
Inhibits products of the CYP17 gene, resulting in block of synthesis of androgens in the tumour, testes, and adrenal glands
Risk of adrenal insufficiency, hence given with prednisolone
Contraindicated in severe hepatic dysfunction
Name 5 side effects of abiraterone

Hypertriglyceridaemia (most common)
Hypokalaemia
hypertension
oedema
hepatotoxicity
How is a diagnosis of castrate resistance determined in patients with previously castrate-sensitive prostate cancer?
Evidence of disease progression on ADT
Describe the management of castrate-resistant prostate cancer

Continue ADT, then add one of the following:
Abiraterone + predisolone
Enzalutamide
Taxane chemotherapy (docetaxel)

Less common: immunotherapy (Sipuleucel-T), radium-223

All confer a survival benefit.
Describe the mechanism of action of enzalutamide

Used in metastatic castrate-resistant prostate cancer
Blocks binding of androgens to androgen receptors, inhibits nuclear translocation of the androgen receptor, inhbits association of the androgen receptor with nuclear DNA
Once a patient with castrate resistant prostate cancer has progressed on either abiraterone or enzalutamide, is there evidence for switching to the other agent?

No.
Should choose another modality, e.g. taxane chemotherapy
Name 2 oral medications used in metastatic castrate-resistant prostate cancer thatn interfere with androgenic stimulation

Abiraterone
Enzalutamide
What is the most important prognostic factor in metastatic castrate-resistant prostate cancer?

Site of metastatic involvement
- Lymph node only is best (31.6 months)
- Bone (21 months)
- Lung (19 months)
- Liver (13 months)
A patient is commenced on ADT for castrate-sensitive metastatic prostate cancer. What primary prevention is needed to maintain bone health?

Calcium 1000 - 1200mg/day (food or supplements)
Vitamin D supplement
Lifestyle modification
Baseline + periodic DEXA

No role for bisphosphonates in castrate-sensitive disease.
A patient is on ADT for castrate-resistant prostate cancer with bony metastases. Is therapy required to prevent fractures? What would be used?

Bisphosphonates or denosumab indicated in CRPC with bony mets for fracture prevention
- Not indicated in castrate-sensitive disease

Should also have usual recommendations for patients on ADT:
calcium 1000 - 1200mg/day (food or supplements) + vitamin D supplements + lifestyle modificiations + baseline & periodic DEXA
A patient with metastatic prostate cancer is found to have a falling PSA in the setting of worsening clinical and radiological disease. What might explain this, and how should it be managed?

Transformation to small cell carcinoma
Biopsy, and if confirmed cease ADT and treat with platinum-based chemotherapy
Describe the management of pain due to bony metastases in prostate cancer

Radiotherapy
Analgesia
What type of bony metastases are seen in prostate cancer?

Osteoblastic
Axial skeleton

Note can also have other leson types but less common
Describe the management of localised small cell prostate cancer

Treat as per high or very high risk prostate cancer guidelines, regardless of actual grade:

RT (external beam or brachytherapy) + ADT, or
RT (external beam) + docetaxel, or
Radical prostatectomy with extended pelvic lymph node dissection
Describe the presentation of small cell prostate cancer

High grade disease but low PSA, often <2.5 
60% metastatic at presentation
Paraneoplastic syndromes (cushing's syndrome, peripheral neuropathy, membranous nephropathy, hypercalcaemia)
Poor prognosis, 1 year survival 48%, 5 year survival 14%
What is single strongest factor for poor survival in breast cancer?

Lymph node involvement
In node-negative patients: tumour size
What are the primary prevention guidelines for colorectal cancer?

2 yearly FOBT from age 50 - 74
Lifestyle advice for everyone
Chemoprophylaxis with low dose aspirin should be considered in patients 50 - 70 of average risk
What is the mechanism of action of bevacizumab?

Class: antiangiogenic
Mechanism: Vascular endothelial growth factor (VEGF) ligand inhibitor
What is the mechanism of action of sunitinib, pazopanib, sorafenib?

Tyrosine kinase inhibitors, antiangiogensis agents
Inhibit  VEGF receptor tyrosine kinases 1-3 (sorafebin only types 2-3), hence blocking VEGF signalling
Name 6 adverse effect of antiangiogenesis agents

Hypertension (most common)
Proteinuria/nephrotic syndrome
Aterial and venous thrombosis
Bleeding
Heart failure
LV dysfunction/Myocardial ischaemia

Antiangiogenesis agents block vascular endothelial growht factor signalling
What percentage of colorectal cancers are metastatic at presentation?
What percentage of colorectal cancers are identfied due to suspicious symptoms (as opposed to screening)?
Name 8 primary tumour-related symptoms that may be present in patients with colorectal cancer

Change in bowel habit (74%) (more common with left than right sided CRC)
Rectal bleeding + change in bowel habit (51%)
Rectal mass (24.5%)
Abdominal mass (12.5%)
Iron deficiency anaemia (9.6 - 23%) (Right sided CRCs more likely to cause iron deficiency anaemia from unrecognized blood loss)
Abdominal pain alone (3.8%)
Bowel obstruction
Peritonitis/perforation
Which site of colorectal cancer is associated with the highest mean daily blood loss?
Right sided colorectal cancer - fourfold higher mean daily blood loss (approx 9ml/day) than other colonic sites
Name the 6 most common sites of metastases from colorectal cancer

Regional lymph nodes
Liver (1st site of haematogenous spread - as venous drainage of intestinal tract is via portal system 
Lungs (2nd haematogenous site)
Peritoneum
Bone
Brain
Name 7 clinical features that may be seen in patients with metastatic colorectal cancer

RUQ pain
Abdominal distension
Early satiety
Supraclavicular lymphadenopathy
Periumbilical nodules
Malignant fistula
Strep gallolyticus (formerly bovis) or clostridium septicum sepsis

Symptomatic at diagnosis confers worse prognosis
What is the best diagnostic test for suspected colorectal cancer?

Colonoscopy
Can localise, biopsy, detect synchronous cancers, remove polyps
What is the miss rate for colorectal cancer in asymptomatic patients?
Describe the appearance of colorectal cancer on colonoscopy

Vast majority of CRCs protrude into the bowel lumen
May be exophytic or polypoid
May involve the whole circumference of the bowel wall (correlates with apple core on imaging).
Small number of lesions are flat or depressed
What is the role of CEA in screening, diagnosis, and management of colorectal cancer?

No role in screening or diagnosis
Role in monitoring disease:
- Check pre-op level, if ongoing elevation postop this implies residual disease
- Rising CEA after resection implies recurrence and imaging should be obtained
Role in prognosis: preop CEA > 5 confers poorer prognosis (independent of TNM stage)
Name 2 tumour markers that may be helpful in monitoring patients with colorectal cancer

CEA
CA19-9
Describe the T staging (of TNM) used for colorectal cancers.

Tis: carcinoma in situ
T1: tumour invades submucosa
T2: invades muscularis propria
T3: invades through muscularis propria into pericolorectal tissues
T4: invades through the visceral peritoneum, or invades or adheres to adjacent organs or structures
Describe the N staging (of TNM) used for colorectal cancers.

N1: 1 -3 regional lymph nodes
N2: four or more regional nodes
Describe the M staging (of TNM) for colorectal cancer

M0: no mets
M1: mets to one or more distant sites or organs, or peritoneal mets
- M1a: one site or organ without peritoneal mets
- M1b: two or more sites without peritoneal mets
- M1c: peritoneal mets alone or with other sites
Describe the difference between clinical and pathologic staging of colorectal cancer

Radiographic, endoscopic (including biopsy), and intraoperative findings are used to assign the clinical stage (TNM)
Histological examination is used to assign pathologic stage (pT, pN, pM)
Describe the effect of neoadjuvant treatment on colorectal cancer TNM staging
May significantly alter (improve) stage
What are mismatch repair genes, and what is their significance in colorectal cancer?

MMR genes code for proteins that correct DNA mismatches generated during DNA replication
Defects in MMR therefore increase spontaneous mutation rate, resulting in a high number of DNA replication errors - accumulation of abnormalities in short sequences of neucleotide bases that are repeated dozens to hundreds of times ('microsatellites'). 
Accumulation of these changes is called microsatellite instability (MSI). 

MMR-deficient results in MSI-high
MMR-proficient results in MSI-low

Mutations in one of several DNA MMR genes  resulting in failure to produce MMR proteins
Name 4 MMR genes

MLH1
MSH2
MSH6
PMS2
In which patient populations might MMR proteins be absent?

Found in Lynch syndrome and 15 - 20% of sporadic colorectal cancers
- Lynch syndrome have germline mutations
- Sporadic CRCs have epigenetic genes (methylation) that silence gene expression
Which confers the better prognosis, MSI-high or MSI-low colorectal cancer?

MSI-high

MMR deficient (MSI-H, or microsatellite unstable) tumours have longer survival than MMR proficient tumours that are MSI-low (MSI-L, showing microsat instability in <30-40% of loci) or MSI stable, both in Lynch and sporadic CRC
- We don't know why
- This is despite these tumours often being poorly differentiated
Describe the significance of KRAS mutation in colorectal cancer

Activating mutation of the RAS-RAF-ERK pathway
40% of CRC
Good concordance of primary and mets (but not lymph node mets)
Poor prognostic marker
KRAS is downstream of EGFR, so KRAS mutant CRC is unresponsive to anti-EGFR therapy
Describe the significance of NRAS mutation in colorectal cancer

Poor prognosis
Downstream of EGFR, so unresponsive to anti-EGFR therapy
Describe the significance of BRAF mutation in colorectal cancer

Activating mutation, most occur in codon 600 (V600E)
10% sporadic CRC
Associated with smoking
Strong negative prognostic marker regardless of TNM in MSI stable patients (less so in MSI unstable patients)
Unlikely to respond to anti-EGFR therapy unless together with a BRAF inhibit
Describe the significance of EGFR in colorecal cancer

Epidermal growth factor receptor
Inhibition prevents cell growth
Can be targeted with anti-EGFR agents - cetuximab, panitumumab
Which patient population, of those with metastatic colorectal cancer, are candidates for anti-EGFR therapy (cetuximab)?

Patients without mutant RAS (KRAS, NRAS)

BRAF mutation also makes response unlikely
Describe the chemotherapy management of metastatic colorectal cancer

FOLFOX (oxaliplatin + leucovorin + fluorouracil), or 
XELOX (oxaliplatin + capecitabine), or 
FOLFIRI (irinotecan + leucovorin + fluorouracil)

Plus (add to any of the above):
- Bevacizumab (if KRAS/BRAF mutant, OR right sided)
- Cetuximab (if KRAS/BRAF wild type AND left sided)
Define seizure
Sudden change in behaviour caused by electrical hypersynchonisation of neural networks in the cerebral cortex
Define acute symptomatic seizure
Seizure occurring at the time of a systemic insult, e.g. Traumatic brain injury, stroke, SDH, CNS infection, severe metabolic derangement
Define unprovoked seizure

Seizure due to unknown aetiology OR 
pre-existing brain lesion OR 
progressive nervous system disorder 

(i.e. not an acute symptomatic seizure)
Give a definition for epilepsy, including diagnostic criteria (3)

Epilepsy is a disease of the brain defined by:
At least two unprovoked seizures more than 24hrs apart, OR
One unprovoked seizure with estimated recurrence similar to that following two unprovoked seizures (around >60%), OR
Diagnosis of an epilepsy syndrome
International league against epilepsy
Give a definition for resolved epilepsy

Patient with age-dependent epilepsy who is older than age which syndrome is active, OR
Seizure free for >10 years, and off medication >5 years
International league against epilepsy
Name the 3 broad seizure types

Focal seizures with retained awareness
Focal seizures with impaired awareness
Generalised seizures
Give a definition for focal seizure with retained awareness

Seizure occuring in one part of the brain (i.e. focal) with retained awareness
May have motor or nonmotor onset
May progress to bilateral (focalto bilateral tonic-clonic)
What kind of seizure is an 'aura'?
Focal seizure with retained awareness
A focal seizure with retained awareness where the patient sees flashing lights indicates seizure activity in which part of the brain?
occipital cortex

A focal seizure with retained awareness where the patient has sudden fear or anxiety, epigastric 'rising', gustatory or olfactor hallucinations, and deja-vu indicates seizure activity in which part of the brain?
Temporal lobe
What symptoms might you expect in a patient with focal seizure with retained awareness arising from the temporal lobe?

sudden fear or anxiety
epigastric 'rising'
gustatory or olfactor hallucinations
deja-vu
Describe the presentation of temporal lobe epilepsy

Begins with aura (focal seizure with retained awarenss) with sudden fear or anxiety, epigastric 'rising', gustatory or olfactor hallucinations, and deja-vu
Seizure progresses to focal seizure with impaired awareness and automatisms
What is the commonest focal epilepsy syndrome in adults?
Temporal lobe epilepsy
Describe the EEG and MRI findings in temporal lobe epilepsy

May be normal
MRI: mesian temporal sclerosis or hippocampal sclerosis
EEG: epileptiform activity in temporal lobe
What is the antiepleptic of choice in temporal lobe epilepsy?
Carbamazepine
A focal seizure with retained awareness where the patient has hemiclonic activity in the contralateral face, arm, or leg indicates seizure activity in which part of the brain?

Primary motor cortex (frontal lobe) 
Seizures may be quite focal (isolated to one limb or face) or may spread (or march) to adjacent areas (Jacksonian seizure)
Name 7 antibiotics that cover pseudomonas

Pip/taz
Meropenen
Ceftazidime
Cefepime
Gentamicin
Amikacin

Only oral option: ciprofloxacin
Name 4 features that suggest primary (as opposed to secondary) membranous nephropathy

Exclusively subepithelial and intramembranous electron-dense deposits
Positive for IgG and C3 on immunofluoresence, nothing else
IgG deposits are predominantly IgG4 
Presence of antigen phospholipase A2 receptor (PLA2R) or thrombospondin type-` domain-containing 7A (THSD7A) within immune deposits
Name 1 feature that may be seen in membranous glomerulonephritis that strongly suggests SLE as a cause
Tubuloreticular structures in the glomerular endothelial cells
Name 2 features of membranous glomerulonephritis that suggests secondary MN

Mesangial and/or subendothelial deposits (suggests a circulating immune complex)
Presence of IgA, IgM, C1q, and IgG other than IgG4
Describe the clinical presentation of membranous glomerunonephritis (3)

Nephrotic syndrome (80%) 
Asymptomatic proteinuria (20%)
Normotensive (70%)
Describe the typical onset of membranous glomeruloneprhtis (i.e. days, weeks, or months)
Usually subacute/slow onst due to slow buildup of deposits in subepithelium (FSGS and minimal change are more rapid); proteinuria may be present for months prior to diagnosis
Define nephrotic syndrome
Proteinuria, hypoalbuminaemia, oedema, hyperlipidaemia (some people also include hypertension)
Describe the expected urinalysis results in a patient with membranous glomerulonephritis (3)

Nephrotic range proteinuria
Microscopic haematuria (50%)
Glucose
Describe the expected urine microscopy results in a patient with membranous glomerulonephritis (3)

Oval fat bodies
Lipid droplets
Fatty casts
Describe the expected pathology results in a patient with membranous glomerulonephritis

Hypoalbuminaemia
Hyperlipidaemia
Normal eGFR (70%)
Name 6 investigations that may be ordered in a patient with membranous glomerulonephritis, (excluding investigations seeking primary or secondary cause)

UEC
LFT
FBE
Urinalysis and sediment
24hr urine collection for protein quantification (or spot protein:creatinine ratio)
C3/C4
Name 9 investigations that may be ordered in a patient with membranous glomerulonephritis, seeking a primary or secondary cause

Anti-PLA2R ELISA assay
ANA, and if positive dsDNA, anti-Sm, anti-Ro/SSA, anti-La-SSB
RF and anti-CCP
Hepatitis B and C serology
HIV testing
IgG4
SPEP and serum free light chains
CXR (for cancer and sarcoid)
Consider PSA, FOBT, mammography, other cancer screening as age-appropriate
When might a renal biopsy be avoided in patients with suspected membranous glomerulonephritis?

Anti-PLA2R positive patients AND normal kindey function AND no evidence of secondary cause

If do not fulfil all three, kidney biopsy is indicated.

A renal biopsy is performed in a patient with suspected membranous glomerunonephritis. Light microscopy and immunofluorescence are consistent with MN.
Describe subsequent antibody/antigen testing to establish primary vs secondary MN

Stain for PLA2R antigen
If positive - diagnosis of PLA2R associated MN established
If negative - stain for IgG subclasses

If IgG4 dominant - stain for THSD7A antibody/antigen
If positive - THSD7A-associated MN established
If negative - non-PLA2R, non THSD7A MN established

If IgG1, IgG2, or IgG3 dominant - secondary MN
In which patients with membranous glomerunonephritis is aggressive cancer screening indicated?

THSD7A-associated MN
Secondary MN
A patient with suspected membranous glomerulonephritis is PLA2R negative. Renal biopsy is contraindicated. What would you do?

Repeat anti-PLA2R assay in 3-4 months
If still negative, biopsy if possible

light microscopy
immunofluorescence
electron microscopy
+/- PLA2R antigen

The vast majority of myasthenia gravis patients have autoantibodies against what?
Acetylcholine receptor (80 - 90%)

Name 2 antibodies which may be positive in myasthenia gravis

What percentage of myasthenia gravis patients will have no detectable autoantibodies?
6-12% of patients are seronegative (no antibodies)
What is the ice pack test, and how does it work?

Bedside test for myasthenia gravis
Ice pack is applied to the upper eyelid for 5 minutes, then ptosis is reassessed
Positive if ptosis improves by >2mm or more
Positive in 80% of MG
Improvement is due to cold decreasing breakdown of acetylcholine by ancetylcholinesterase at the neuromuscular junction
Describe the clinical presentations of myasthenia gravis

Cardinal feature: fluctuating skeletal muscle weakness with true muscle fatigue

Two varients:
Ocular: weakness limited to eyelids and extraocular muscles
Generalised: may affect ocular muscles, but also inovles combination of bulbar, limb, and respiratory muscles
Describe the clinical features of ocular myasthenia gravis (2)

Ptosis
Diplopia
What proportion of patients with ocular myasthenia gravis at presentation will remain purely ocular?
Name 2 bulbar manifestations of myasthenia gravis

Muscle of jaw closure weakness (fatigueable chewing)
Oropharyngeal muscle weakness (dysarthria, dysphagia)

Symptoms worsen with prolonged use
What proportion of patients with myasthenia gravis present with proximal muscle weakness alone?
What will occur when a patient with myasthenia gravis diplopia closes one eye?
Diplopia will disappear
Name sites of extraocular involvement in myasthenia gravis

Bulbar muscles (chewing fatigue, dysarthria, dysphagia)
Facial muscles (expressionless)
Neck and limb muscles (neck flexor and extensor weakness causing dropped head syndrome, proximal muscle weakness, can have distal muscle weakness)
Respiratory muscles (can have respiratory failure)
Describe the natural history/disease course of myasthenia gravis

Symptoms may be transient with hours, days, or weeks free of symptoms
New symptoms often develop weeks to months later
Maximal disease after 3 years in 77%
What is the major limitation of the ice pack test

Test for myasthenia gravis
Does not work in patients with extraocular muscle weakness
What is the edrophonium test, and how does it work?

Test for myasthenia gravis
Edrophonium is an acetylcholinesterase inhibitor, rapid onset and short duration
Prolongs presence of acetylcholine in NMJ and thus results in immediate symptom improvement
Used in patients with obvious ptosis or ophthalmoparesis in whom an improvement can be easily observed
What is the sensitivity of the edrophonium test for myasthenia gravis?
In which patients is the endrophonium test relatively contraindicated?

Cardiac disease/arrythmia - symptomatic bradycardia may occur
Bronchial asthma - bronchospasm may occur
Is the edrophonium test specific for myasthenia gravis?

No

May be positive in motor neuron disease, brainstem tumours, compressive cranial neuropathies
Name two bedside tests that may be performed in a patient with suspected myasthenia gravis

Ice pack test
Edrophonium test
What proportion of patients with thymoma and myasthenia gravis would you expect to have Acetylcholine receptor positive disease?
What proportion of patients with generalised myasthenia gravis would you expect to have MuSK positive disease?

38 - 50%
MuSK rare in patients with purely ocular disease
What is the predominant cell type involved in Stephen-Johnson syndrome?
T cells
Name 5 tests or interventions that may be performed in a patient with suspected food allergy

Skin testing for food-specific IgE (sensitive, not specific) - good first test
IgE immunoassay for food-specific IgE in serum
- good for peanut, wheat
Diagnostic elimination diet
Food diary
Supervised food challenge (gold standard)
What is the mean time to cardiac arrest in iatrogenic (drug-induced) anaphylaxis?
5 minutes
What is the mean time to cardiac arrest in insect sting anaphylaxis?
15 minutes
What is the mean time to cardiac arrest in food induced anaphylaxis?
30 minutes
In patients with anaphylaxis, is there a different degree of response to adrenaline in early vs late phase?

Anaphylaxis is most responsive to treatment in early phase, prior to development of shock
Delay is associated with increased mortality
How does adrenaline work when used as treatment for anaphylaxis?

Decreases mediator release from mast cells
Prevents or reverses obstruction to airflow in upper and lower respiratory tracts
Prevents or reverses cardiovascular collapse
Describe the supportive care management of anaphylaxis (6)

Manage the airway - intubate immediately if marked stridor or respiratory arrest
Stop the offending drug/cause
Call for help
Position supine with legs elevated (unless prominent airway swelling, in which case sit upright. Pregnant patients should like on left side)
2 large bore IVCs if normotensive, 125ml/hr NaCl to TKVO
Continuous monitoring
What is the treatment of choice for anaphylaxis?
Adrenaline, all patients, all severities
Describe the dose and route of administration of adrenaline in patients with anaphylaxis without shock/hypotension

Adrenaline 0.5mg IM outer thigh
Subsequent dose in 5 - 15min if required (can give sooner if necessary)
Describe the dose and route of administration of adrenaline in anaphylatic patients who do not respond to IM adrenaline or have shock/hypotension not responding IM adrenaline and fluid resus

IV adrenaline by slow continuous infusion (not intermittent bolus can cause extreme hypertension, ventricular arrythmias)
Use 0.1mcg/kg/min, increase every 2-3min by 0.05microg until BP and perfusion improve. Rare to need more than 1microg/kg/min but no known max dose.
Describe the IV fluid you would give a hypotensive anaphylaxis patient

At least 2L normal saline stat
If still hypotensive give ongoing fluids - may need up to 7L
Which anaphylaxis patients should receive supplemental O2?
Hypoxic patients
What is the significance of a history of beta blocker therapy in anaphylaxis patients? How is this managed?

Beta-blockers can cause treatment-resistance to adrenaline. 
Glucagon should be given if no response to adrenaline because it has inotropic and chronotropic effects that are not mediated through beta receptors.
Glucagon 1-5mg IV slow bolus over 5min. Can then give infusion of 5-15microg/min titrated to effect (not weight)
Beware glucagon-induced vomiting (airway)
Name 2 things you may use to treat hypoxia in the setting of anaphylaxis (other than adrenaline)

Supplemental O2
Bronchodilators
What is the characteristic defect in common variable immunodeficiency (CVID)?
Impaired B cell differentiation with defective production of immunoglobulin, despite presence of B cells
Name the 3 diagnostic criteria for common variable immunodeficiency

Markedly reduced serum concentrations of IgG, plus low IgA and/or IgM
Poor or absent response to immunisation
Absence of any other defined immunodeficiency state
What is the most common severe antibody deficiency?
Common variable immunodeficiency
At what age are most diagnoses of common variable immunodeficiency made?
Describe the pathogenesis of common variable immunodeficiency (4)

Arises from a number of gene defects, may be recessive or autosomal dominant with variable penetrance
Normal overall B cell numbers in 90% of cases
Low percentage of isotype-switched memory B cells (and also plasma cells) capable of producing antigen-specific IgG and IgM which are critical for recall (secondary) antibody responses
T cell abnormalities including low CD4/CD8 cell ratio in some patients
Name 9 clinical manifestations of common variable immunodeficiency syndrome

Infections
Chronic pulmonary disease
Gastrontestinal
Autoimmune
Granulomatous infiltration
Allergic disease
Lymphadenopathy/splenomegaly
Liver disease
Malignancy (typically Non Hodgkins lymphoma)
Describe the shunt below and calculate the Qp:Qs ratio

VSD 
Normal saturations in SVC, IVC, RA, then step up >7% in saturations in the RV indicates oxygenated blood flowing from left ventricle to right ventricle
Qp: Qs = (Aorta - MV) / (PV - PA)
= 97 - 64 / 97 - 88 = 33 / 9 = around 4:1

Symptoms, OR
LV enlargement, OR

Pulmonary hypertension with net L -> R shunt
Endocarditis
AR
RV outflow tract obstruction

Ostium secundum (75%)

Haemodynamically significant shunt
- Symptoms, OR
- RV enlargement, OR
- Qp:Qs > 1.5

Platypnea/orthodeoxia syndrome

Arrhythmia

Pulmonary hypertension
Tricuspid regurgitation
Paradoxical embolism
Describe the formula use to detect and evaluate shunts on cardiac catheterisation

Pulmonary circulation (Qp) and systemic circulation (Qs) should be equal in absence of a shunt
Qp and Qs are calculated using oxygen saturations of aorta, mixed venous, pulmonary vein and pulmonary artey. This gives Qp:Qs ratio, which in normal hearts should be 1:1

Qp:Qs = (Aorta - MV)/ (PV - PA)

Greater than 7% 'step up' in oxygen saturations is abnormal

Example:
Mixed venous 65%
RA 80%
PA 80%
Pulmonary vein 95%
Aorta 95%

There is a 15% step up from mixed venous to RA, indicating an atrial level shunt
Qp:Qs = 95 - 65 / 95 - 80 = 30 / 15 = 2:1
What is the formula for calculating Qp:Qs?
Qp:Qs = (Aorta - MV)/ (PV - PA)
Where would you expect to see a 'step up' in oxygen saturations in an ASD?
Step up in the right atrium (i.e. RA O2 is at least 7% higher than mixed venous O2)
Where would you expect to see a 'step up' in oxygen saturations in a patient with VSD?

Step up in RV 
- RV O2 saturations at least 7% higher than in the RA, indicating a ventricular-level shunt
Where would you expect to see a 'step up' in oxygen saturations in a patient with a PDA?

Step up in pulmonary artery
- O2 sats in the pulmonary artery at least 7% higher than the RV, due to extra oxygenated blood entering from the aorta)
How much higher does the O2 saturation have to be to constitute a 'step up' in patients being evaulated for a cardiac shunt?

A patient undergoes cardiac catheterisation for suspected shunt. These are their oxygen saturations:
Mixed venous 65%
RA 80%
RV 80%
PA 80%
Aorta 95%
Pulmonary vein 95%

Describe where the shunt is and calculate the Qp:Qs ratio

Step up of 15% from MV to RA indicates flow of oxygenated blood from left to right at the atrial level - an ASD
Qp:Qs = (Aorta - MV)/ (PV - PA)
95 - 65 / 95 - 80 = 30 / 15 = 2:1 shunt
Name 2 methods used to close a VSD

Patent ductus arteriosus - consistent saturations in mixed venous, RA, RV, then 15% step up in pulmonary artery (oxygenated blood flowing from aorta into pulmonary artery)

98 - 75 / 99 - 90 = 23 / 9 = around 3:1

Right to left shunt at atrial level - ASD with Eisenmenger syndrome)
Qp:Qs = aorta - MV / PV - PA
89 - 75 / 99 - 75 = 14 / 24 = approx 1:2
What is the formula used to calculate pulmonary vascular resistance

(Pulmonary artery pressure - left atrial pressure) / pulmonary blood flow
Pulmonary blood flow equals cardiac output unless there is a shunt or other abnormality

A 35 year old with dilated cardiomyopathy is assessed for candidacy for heart transplant. He undergoes a right heart catheter. 
Pulmonary artery pressure 70/30 (mean 45)
mean pulmonary capillary wedge pressure 30
cardiac output 5.0L/min

Calculate the pulmonary vascular resistance and explain why this is important.

PVR = (Pulmonary artery pressure - left atrial pressure) / pulmonary blood flow
Pulmonary blood flow = cardiac output unless there is a shunt or some other abnormality
PVR = (45 - 30)/5 = 3
(PVR normal range 1 - 3)

Pulmonary vascular resistance is used to differentiate between pulmonary hypertension due to left heart disease (normal PVR) vs other causes (elevated PVR)
Would you expect normal or elevated pulmonary vascular resistance in a patient with class 2 pulmonary hypertension?

Normal
Class 2 is PTH due to left heart disease; normal PVR differentiates this class from all others.
Describe the pathophysiology of Eisenmenger syndrome (6)

Left to right shunt (usually large and longstanding)
Increased pulmonary blood flow with shear stress and circumferential stretch
Endothelial dysfunction and vascular remodelling - smooth muscle cell proliferation, increase in extracellular matrix, intravascular thrombosis
Increased pulmonary vascular resistance
Reversal of shunt when pulmonary pressures equal/exceed systemic pressures
Cyanosis
Name 6 complications of Eisenmenger syndrome

Erythrocytosis +/- hyperviscosity syndrome
Bleeding (abnormal haemostasis)
Gallstones, gout
Stroke, cerebral abscess (paradoxical emboli)
Heart failure (late)
Sudden cardiac death
Describe the indication for intervention in patients with aortic coarctation

Infant, children, and adult patients with coarctation with peak to peak (or maximum instantaneous) gradient 20 mmHg 
or 
a gradient <20 mmHg with anatomic imaging evidence of significant coarctation and collateral flow.

The peak to peak gradient is a measurement derived from catheterization data in which the peak pressure beyond the coarctation is subtracted from the peak pressure proximal to the coarctation.

Failure of right atrial pressure to drop with inspiration, as observed by a failure of the JVP to fall in inspiration, or a rise of JVP in inspiration
