When should LA and LV pressure be equal?

During diastole, when the mitral valve is open
If not equal, implies an obstruction between them such as mitral stenosis
What pressure across the mitral valve and what valve area would indicate severe mitral stenosis?

Gradient > 10mmHg
Valve area < 1cm2
What difference in pressure would you expect between the pulmonary wedge pressure and the left ventricular end diastolic pressure?

They should be the same
PCWP should equal left atrial pressure
Left atrial diastolic pressure should equal left ventricular end diastolic pressure, as the mitral valve is open.

If not equal, implies obstruction between LA and  LV (e.g. mitral stenosis) or abnormal pulmonary vasculature interfering with using wedge pressure to accurately estmate LA pressure (e.g. pulmonary vein stenosis)
What difference would you expect in left ventricular systolic pressure and aortic systolic pressure?

They should be the same

If not, implies left ventricular outflow tract obstruction - e.g. aortic stenosis, HOCM
What is the difference between constrictive pericarditis and restrictive cardiomyopathy? Why is differentiating between the two important?

Constrictive pericarditis is a disease of the pericardium (e.g. TB pericarditis, connective tissue disease)
Restrictive pericarditis is disease of the myocardium (e.g. idiopathic, post RT, infiltrative)

Both present similarly, but important to differentiate due to different management
What two 'critical' features of constrictive pericarditis are responsible for the physical examination, haemodynamic, and imaging findings?

Greatly enhanced ventricular interaction/interdependance
Dissociation of intracardiac and intrathoracic pressures
What is ventricular interdependance?
The haemodynamics of the left and right ventricles are directly influenced by each other to a much greater degree than normal. A major feature of constrictive pericarditis.
Describe the pathophysiology of ventricular interdependence seen in constrictive pericarditis

In constrictive pericarditis the upper limit of cardiac volume is constrained by the inelastic pericardium. 
The thickened, rigid pericardium prevents the normal inspiratory decrease in intrathoracic pressure from being transmitted to the heart chambers. It also does not expand to accommodate increased venous return in inspiration.
Pulmonary venous pressure declines in inspiration but LV pressure does not, leading to reduced LV volume (lower transpulmonary gradient)
RV volume expands by shifting the interventricular septum, instead of by stretching the pericardium - on catheter seen as a decrease in LV pressure with a rise in RV pressure (remember RV pressure was supposed to fall with inspiration)
What is systolic area index, and how is it important?

SAI = ratio of RV pressure to LV pressure in inspiration versus expiration
i.e. a marker of ventricular interdependance
>1.1 is the most sensitive, specific, and best PPV and NPV for constrictive pericarditis
This trace shows LV pressure (yellow) and RV pressure (orange) in inspiration and expiration. What is the above phenomenon called, and what disease does it indicate?

Fall in LV pressure due to a rise in RV pressure with inspiration (remember RV pressure should fall with inspiration due to fall in intrathoracic pressure which brings increased venous return)
This is interventricular dependance seen in constrictive pericarditis
Due to 'fixed shell'-like pericardium, the increased venous return causes a rise in RV pressure. As the pericardium cannot stretch to accommodate the extra blood, it must expand by shifting the interventricular septum towards the LV, and LV pressure falls.
What sign will be significantly absent in restrictive cardiomyopathy, when LV and RV pressures are measured?
There will NOT be evidence of ventricular interdependance (seen in constritive pericarditis)
What is e' (e prime)?

Mitral annular early diastolic velocity
Measurement of LV myocardial relaxation 
Early in diastole blood is sucked into the ventricle by the active process of myocardial relaxation (as opposed to being pushed in by LA contraction)
What does E represent in echocardiography?
LV passive filling
What is E/e' used for, what what is the normal range?

Ratio between early mitral inflow velocity and mitral annular early diastolic velocity
Used to estmate LV filling pressure
Useful in HFpEF as a marker of diastolic dysfunction
E/e' <10 is normal

Group 2 PH due to left heart disease
Group 3 PH due to chronic lung disease and/or hypoxemia
Group 4 PH due to chronic thromboembolic pulmonary hypertension
Group 5 PH due to unclear multifactorial mechanisms

Group 1 is idopathic, hertiable, and diseases that localise to the small pulmonary arterioles.

Idiopathic
Heritable
Drugs/toxins
Connective tissue disease
HIV
Portal hypertension

Schistosomiasis
Name 5 connective tissue diseases associated with group 1 pulmonary hypertension

What is cor pulmonale?

A complication of group 3 pulmonary hypertension
Refers to PH group 3-induced altered structure (e.g. hypertrophy or dilation) or function of the right ventricle
Name 4 conditions which may result in group 3 pulmonary hypertension

Group 3 is PH due to chronic lung disease or hypoxaemia

COPD

Chronic kidney disease
What is the definition of pulmonary hypertension?
Mean pulmonary artery pressure > 25mmHg
What echo findings would one expect in pulmonary hypertension (5)?

RV enlargement

How can pulmonary artery wedge pressure be used to differentiate between group 2 and group 1/3/4/5 pulmonary hypertension?

Group 2 is PH due to left heart disease

Describe the management pulmonary hypertension

Diuretics if fluid retention
Exercise training
Oxygen if group 3 and resting or excercise hypoxia

Advanged therapy in selected patients (see other card)
Which patients with pulmonary hypertension are candidates for 'advanced therapy' (pulmonary vasodilators)?

NYHA class II - IV despite treatment of underlying cause and:
- group 1, or
- on case by case basis for group 3, 4, or 5
- NOT used in most patients in group 2
Pulmonary arterial hypertension refers to which group of patients with pulmonary hypertension?
Group 1
What is 'advanced therapy' in pulmonary hypertension?
Therapy directed at the pulmonary hypertension itself, rather than the underlying cause
What test should be performed in patients with group 1 pulmonary hypertension to assist with selecting an appropriate 'advanced therapy' agent?

If a patient with group 1 pulmonary hypertension has a positive vasoreactivity test, what advanced therapy agent should be used?

How might one distinguish between hypertrophic cardiomyopathy and Fabry's disease?

Fabry disease is a potential cause of unexplained LVH or hypertrophic cardiomyopathy
What is the formula for calculating the Duke treadmill score?
Exercise time (minutes based on the Bruce protocol) - (5 x maximum ST segment deviation in mm) - (4 x exercise angina [0 = none, 1 = nonlimiting, and 2 = exercise limiting])
What scores constitute low, moderate, and high risk Duke scores?

Low risk score +5

High risk score -11
Which noninvasive investigation modality has the highest sensitivity for detecting flow-limiting stenosis in ischaemic heart disease?

CTCA

clinical assessment indicates non-anginal chest pain but ECG shows ST segment changes or Q waves
In patients whom stable angina cannot be excluded by clinical assessment alone, what diagnostic testing should be used if there is a history of confirmed CAD?
Non-invasive functional imaging (usualy stress echo or nuclear stress test)

A patient with a left bundle branch block requires stress testing for evaluation of chest pain. Should they have an exercise stress test (echo or nuc med), or a pharmacologic stress test (echo or nuc med), and why?

Need to use pharmacologic stress

This applies to both nuclear medicine and echocardiography

Nocturnal confusion

Subcortical vascular dementia arises due to what disease process?

Can MRI distinguish between post-stroke patients with and without vascular dementia?
No
What findings might one expect to see on MRI brain of a patient with vascular dementia?

cortical and subcortical infarctions
subcortical ischemic changes
leukoaraiosis (white matter lesions near the lateral ventricles)
Can leukoaraiosis on MRI brain be seen in healthy controls?
Yes, however is more common and more severe in patients with stroke
What did the Framingham study findings show with regards to leukoaraiosis and stroke risk?
Presence of severe leukoaraiosis at baseline doubles risk of future stroke
What are the benefits of neuropsychological testing in patients with vascular dementia?

Provide baseline for monitoring
Quantify degree of impairment
Detect pattern of impairment consistent with vascular dementia
What findings would you expect on neuropsychological testing in a patient with vascular dementia, compared with a patient with Alzheimer's?
Similar to Alzheimer's, but with much less memory impairment and much more impaired executive function
What are the DSM-5 criteria for Alzheimer's dementia?

Evidence of significant cognitive decline from a previous level of performance in one or more cognitive domains
Cognitive deficits interfere with ADLs
Not due to delirium
Not better explained by another mental health disorder
Insidious onset and gradual progression in at least two cognitive domains
And either:
- a causitive genetic mutation, or
- all three of: 
---decline in memory and learning plus one other cognitive domain, 
---AND steadly progressive gradual decline in function without extended plateaus, 
---AND no evidence of mixed aetiology
What were the findings of the PRAMI trial with regards to stenting only culprit lesions vs complete revascularisation (stenting all significant lesions) in STEMI patients?

PRAMI looked at stenting only 'culprit lesions' on PCI vs stenting all anatomically significant disease in STEMI patients
Stenting all anatomically significant lesions was superior with lower mortality, cardiac mortality, refractory angina
What were the findings of the CvLPRIT trial, with regards to stenting only the culprit lesions vs full revascularisation in STEMI patients?

Treating all anatomically significant lesions on PCI during index admission for STEMI patients was superior to stenting the culprit lesion alone + medical therapy
Stenting all lesions did not have to occur during index procedure so long as it was in the same admission
What is the proposed mechanism of benefit to stenting non-culprit lesions (as well as the culprit lesion) in STEMI patients during the index admission?

Complete revascularisation has significant mortality benefit
Thought to be due to
- reduced ischaemic burden
- stabilises multiple 'vulnerable' plaques that are at risk of rupture in this patient population with generalised inflammaiton and endothelial dysfunction
What are the benefits of complete revascularisation (stenting culprit and non-culprit lesions) during index admission for STEMI patients?
Reduced cardiac death, refractory angina, nonfatal MI
Which approach, radial or femoral, has a lower risk of major adverse cardiac event and all-cause mortality?

No statistically significant difference for stable angina or NSTEMI
Radial is superior in STEMI
Which approach, radial or femoral, has a lower risk of major bleeding and major vascular complications?

Radial approach

This is thought to contribute to the lower mortality in STEMI patients with radial approach (as these patients require aggresive anticoagulation)
Name 4 benefits to a radial approach for PCI

Less bleeding/major vascular complications
Lower mortality in STEMI patients
Earlier ambulation
Patient comfort
What is one drawback of using a radial access approach for PCI in STEMI?
You are 'using up' a potential graft if the patient requires CAGS down the track
What were the findings of the ORBITA trial for optimal medical therapy vs optimal medical therapy + PCI for stable angina?

Optimal medical therapy vs same + PCI for stable angina. 200 patients.
Included sham procedure and blinded follow up

PCI reduced ischaemic burden on stress echo
No statistically significant difference in other outcomes (exercise time, angina)

Summary: no symptom benefit to PCI in stable angina in this trial
What FFR result indicates functionally significant stenosis on PCI?

> 0.8 no functionally significant stenosis (no ischaemia on functional testing)
< 0.8 functionally significant stenosis

If FFR < 0.8, revascularisation is recommended.
What is FFR (Frational Flow Reserve)?

FFR is a single highly reliable and reproducible invasive method to assess the ischemia producing potential of a lesion with accuracy of more than 90% (88% sensitivity, 100% specificity, 100% positive predictive value, 88% negative predictive value)
How is FFR measured?

A pressure wire is passed beyond a coronary artery lesion 
Ratio between coronary pressure distal to the stenosis and aortic pressure under conditions of maximum myocardial hyperemia is calculated

1.0 is normal
> 0.80 is not functionally significant
< 0.80 is functionally significant

12 months

SYNTAX and SYNTAX II trials
Looked at multivessel PCI vs CABG in patients with functionally significant triple vessel disease

If syntax score <23 (not anatomically complex): either procedure
If syntax score >23 (anatomically complex): CABG

Syntax score analyses anatomy of the coronary artery lesion(s) with points awarded based on location, tortuosity, calcification, thrombus, etc .

I looked at it.
What steps may be taken to mitigate bleeding risk in patients on DAPT (5)?

Access site selection
Modulation of modifiable risk factors for bleeding
Low dose aspirin

Routine use of PPI.

Clopidogrel
Regarding dual antiplatelet therapy, which P2Y12 inhibitor should be used in ACS patients?
Ticagrelor or prasugrel is recommended in ACS patients unless drug-specific contraindications exist
What duration of DAPT is recommended in stable CAD patients treated with PCI?

6 months if low bleeding risk
1 - 2 months if high bleeding risk

No
How long should DAPT be continued in ACS patients managed medically?

Irrespective of the final revascularization strategy (e.g. medical therapy, PCI, or CABG), the default DAPT duration in these patients is 12months.

Irrespective of the final revascularization strategy (e.g. medical therapy, PCI, or CABG), the default DAPT duration in these patients is 12months.

Irrespective of the final revascularization strategy (e.g. medical therapy, PCI, or CABG), the default DAPT duration in these patients is 12months.

How much is bleeding risk increased by giving oral anticoagulation + DAPT vs oral anticoagulation alone?
2 - 3 fold risk of bleeding
What is the maximum acceptable duration of triple therapy
6 months
Are bioresorbable stents superior to drug eluting and bare metal stents?

No
Worse outcomes
Increased stent thrombosis and recurrent MI
Not used in Australia
In patients with left main disease, should  PCI or CABG be used?

CABG if high syntax score >32 (highly complex anatomy/high risk lesion(s)
Either may be used in low and intermediate syntax scores

EXCEL trial - 3000 patients with syntax score <32: no difference in outcomes at 3 years
Increased risk of repeat procedures with PCI group
Lower 30 day complication rate with PCI

1 month, if aspirin can be continued

If both aspirin and P2Y12 need to be stopped, or if prior to 1 month, consider bridging with cangrelor, tirofiban, or eptifibatide

History of stent thrombosis
Lower extremities artery disease
Complex PCI
What is the mean age of diagnosis of breast cancer?
What are the mortality and incidence of breast cancer doing?

Increasing incidence
Decreasing mortality
Describe the breast cancer screening mammogram program

Women aged 50 - 74 are invited for 2 yearly mammograms
Women aged >40 can access screening mammogram
What is the mortality relative risk with screening mammograms vs no screening?
RR 0.80 breast cancer specific mortality
What is the most common mutation associated with breast cancer?
BRCA
What is the mechanism behind BRCA mutations increase breast cancer risk?

BRCA1 and 2 code for proteins responsible for repair of double strand DNA breaks via homologous recombination
Defect in one copy is sufficient to cause disease state (autosomal dominant inheritance)
Why do PARP inhibitors work well in BRCA mutant cancers?

PARP1 is most abundant member of the PARP family
When inhibited, double-strand DNA breaks accumulate and under normal conditions are repaired via the BRCA pathway-dependent homologous recombination mechanism
In BRCA mutant cancers, damage cannot be repaired
Describe the difference between the 'genetic era' and the mutations it allowed us to identify, vs the genomic era.

Genetic era found single mutations  via classic linkage analysis that were high penetrance and high risk (monogenetic syndromes) e.g. BRCA raising breast and ovarian cancer risk
Genomic era now focuses on whole genome sequencing to find multiple low risk alleles (polygenetic inheritance) that cumulatively result in high risk of disease
The 'genetic era' identified what types of mutations? (3)

Pathogeneic variant in one gene, resulting in high predisposition for disease
Often protein-truncating varients (frameshifts common)
Genetic tests for these have well-established clinical utility
The 'genomic era' has led to identification of what types of mutations?

Multiple common gene varients (multiple alleles) that together contribute to risk of disease
Genetic variation modified by environment
Still not well-established in clinical practice
What are tumour suppressor genes?

Monitor and prevent DNA replication of damaged genome:
- Act as cell cycle checkpoints
- Recognise DNA damage and promote repair
- Cause apoptosis if cannot be accurately repaired
Is a loss or gain of function required for mutation in tumour suppressor genes to cause cancer?
Loss of function
How do mutations in tumour suppressor genes lead to malignancy?

Loss of function mutations lead to inability to recognise or repair damaged DNA, or cause apoptosis in cells with damaged DNA
This leads to accumulation of further mutation
Describe the 'two hit hypothesis'

Both tumour suppresor gene alleles within a single cell must be crippled for total loss of function
- Either both germline (autosomal recessive inheritance), or
- One germline and one somatic (autosomal dominant inheritance)
e.g. BRCA, APC, MMR, p53
BRCA, APC, MMR, and p53 are all examples of what kind of gene?
Tumour suppressor gene
Name 4 tumour suppressor genes implicated in familial cancer syndromes

BRCA
APC
MMR
TP53
Mutations in what types of gene are responsible for the majority of inherited cancer syndromes?
Tumour suppressor genes
Mutation in what gene results in retinoblastoma?
RB1
What kind of gene is RB1?
Tumour suppressor gene (mutation results in retinoblastoma)
RB1 mutation is associated with retinoblastoma. What type of inheritance pattern does it follow?
Autosomal dominant
RB1 mutation is seen in what proportion of familial or bilateral retinoblastoma?
RB1 mutation is seen in what proportion of unilateral or nonfamilial retinoblastoma?
Name the 3 most common cancers, other than retinoblastoma, seen in patients with familial retinoblastoma

Osteosarcoma (RR 314)
Soft tissue sarcoma (RR 243)
Melanoma (RR 50)
Are patients with nonfamilial retinoblastoma at risk of other malignancies?

Yes, not not nearly as much as familial retinoblastoma
Risk of soft tissue sarcoma (RR 21) and melanoma (RR 1.97)
What is the mean age at diagnosis of familial or bilateral retinoblastoma?
12 months
What is the mean age at diagnosis of unilateral retinoblastoma?
2 years
Describe how inheritance of one non functioning allele of a tumour suppressor gene leads to increased cancer risk, using the two hit hypothesis

Inactivation of both alleles within the same cell is required to cause disease
Usually this takes a very long time (cancers diagnosed in old age)
If one allele is inactivated from birth (germline mutation), only one further mutation is required to cause disease. This leads to cancer developing and younger age, and multiple primaries
What are proto-oncogenes?

Normal genes that regulate cell growth
Cause cancer if mutated resulting in overexpression - they are then called oncogenes
Mutation in how many alleles (one or two) of a proto-oncogene are required to cause disease?

One
Gain of function in a single mutant allele increases malignant potential
How does gain of function in a proto-oncogene (which then becomes an oncogene) result in increased malignant potential?

Proto-oncogenes regulate cell growth
Overexpression can result in 
- DNA missense mutations
- Chromosomal translocation causing abberant protein or expression
Why are mutations in proto-oncogenes almost never seen in familial cancer sydromes?

Mutation causes overexpression
These constitutively active mutations are generally not tolerated during embryogenesis/do not survive to term
Name one proto-oncogene which, when mutated, causes a familial cancer syndrome

RET
Mutation causes multiple endocrine neoplasia type 2
Mutations in proto-oncogenes are usually germline or somatic?

Somatic
Usually not tolerated during embryogenesis so germline is rare
What is the Philadelphia chromosome?

Fusion of parts of chromosomes 9 and 22, causing BCR (from 22) and ABL (from 9) gene fusion
BCR promotor causes high expression of the aberrant ABL proto-oncogene, a tyrosine kinase
Results in leukaemia (usually CML)
Name 3 clinical features of multiple endocrine neoplasia type 1 (MEN 1)

Parathyroid adenomas (90%)
Pancreatic islet cell/GI adenomas (65%)
Pituitary adenomas (15%)
Name 3 clinical features of Multiple Endocrine Neoplasia type 2A

Medullary thyroid cancer (90%)
Pheochromocytoma (45%)
Parathyroid hyperplasia (15%)
Mutation in the RET proto-oncogene results in what clinical syndrome?
Multiple endocrine neoplasia type 2 (MEN 2)
What inheritance pattern does RET follow?

Autosomal dominant

RET is a proto-oncogene. Mutation results in MEN2.
Name 4 clinical features of multiple endocrine neoplasia type 2B

Medullary thyroid cancer
Pheochromocytoma
Mucosal neuromas
Marfinoid body habitus
Mutation in what gene results in multiple endocrine neoplasia type 2?
RET
Mutation in the MENIN tumour suppressor gene results in what clinical syndrome?
Multiple endocrine neopalsia type 1
What mutation results in multiple endocrine neoplasia type 1?
MENIN (tumour suppressor gene)
Mutation in the MENIN tumour suppressor gene results in multiple endocrine neoplasia type 1. What pattern of inheritance does it follow?
Autosomal dominant
What percentage of breast cancers are associated with germline high risk gene mutations?
What percentage of breast cancer patients will have a family history of breast or ovarian cancer?
Name 4 genes associated with familial breast/ovarian cancer, and their syndromes

Hereditary breast and ovarian cancer syndrome - BRCA 1 and 2
Li Fraumeni syndrome - TP53
Cowden syndrome - PTEN
Li Fraumeni Syndrome results from mutation in what gene?
TP53 (missense mutation)
Mutation in TP53 results in what syndrome?
Li Fraumeni syndrome
Mutation in PTEN results in what syndrome?
Cowden syndrome
Cowden syndrome arises due to mutation in what gene?
PTEN
Do all patients with a germline mutation associated with high breast and ovarian cancer risk have a family history of those diseases?
No
Why don't all patients with a germline mutation associated with high breast and ovarian cancer risk have a family history of those diseases?

This may be due to:

De novo mutation
Small, male-enriched paternal family history
Not 100% cancer penetrance
Adoption
Name 8 features that are seen in families with heriditary breast and ovarian cancer syndrome (HBOC)?

Young, premenopausal onset of breast cancer (age <35)
Breast and ovarian cancers within the family
Triple negative breast cancer
High grade serous ovarian cancer or primary peritoneal cancer
>1 generation affected
Male breast cancer at any age
Ashkenazi Jewish or Icelandic heritage
Breast cancer in a patient with a 1st or 2nd degree relative with ovarian cancer, or relative with breast cancer age <50
What is the incidence of BRCA1 and 2 in the population?
BRCA 1 and 2 are what type of genes?
Tumour suppressor genes
BRCA 1 and 2 mutations follow what pattern of inheritance?
Autosomal dominant
Do all BRCA1 and 2 families have the same mutations?

No
>1000 different BRCA mutations have been reported
Describe how mutations in BRCA 1 and 2 result in malignancy

BRCA are responsible for repair of breaks in double stranded DNA via the error-free homologous recombination pathway (BRCA 1 and 2 act at different points along the same pathway)
If unable to use this pathway due to BRCA nonfunctioning, cells switch to using non-homologous end joining, an error-prone method
This gives rise to mutations
Biallelic mutations in BRCA2 result in what disease?
Fanconi anaemia
What is a biallelic mutation?
Mutation on both copies of a particular allele - may be homozygous (the same mutation) or compound heterozygous (a different mutation on each allele)
What percentage of high risk familities will have a BRCA 1 or 2 mutation?
Mutations in BRCA 1 are found in what percentage of triple negative breast cancer?
What percentage of high grade serous ovarian cancer have BRCA 1 or 2 mutation?
Mutation in what genes account for the vast majority of famila breast cancer in Ashkenazi Jewish women?
BRCA 1 and 2 - 96%
When should genetic testing for BRCA 1 and 2 be considered? (6)

Diagnosis of breast cancer age < 35
Male breast cancer at any age
High grade serous ovarian cancer or primary peritoneal cancer
Ashkenazi Jewish background
Triple negative breast cancer
Very strong family history
Government funded testing for BRCA 1 and 2 is provided when...
Risk of BRCA mutatation >10%
Name 3 differences between BRCA1 and 2 clinical syndromes

BRCA 1: 
- higher risk of breast cancer (73 vs 69%)
- higher risk of ovarian or fallopian tube cancer (44 vs 17%)
BRCA 2:
- higher risk of male breast cancer (5-6% vs 2-3%)
What are the recommended risk reduction strategies in patiens with BRCA mutation? (3)

Prophylactic bilateral mastectomy OR annual mammography and breast MRI from age 25 until mastectomy
Salpingo-oophorectomy after completing family or at age 40
Tamoxifen (if premenopausal) or raloxifene (if postmenopausal) for 5 years (reduces risk by 40%)
Is screening for ovarian cancer recommended in patients with BRCA 1 and 2 mutation?

No - it does not work.
Salpingo-oophorectomy at age 40 is recommended
What is the other name for Li Fraumeni syndrome?
SBLA (sarcoma, breast, leukaemia, adrenal gland) cancer syndrome
Name 5 clinical features of Li Fraumeni syndrome

Breast cancer, often before age 30, 66% HER2 positive
Sarcoma - osteosarcoma, other soft tissue sarcoma
Childhood brain, leukaemia, adrenal cancers
What proportion of Li Fraumeni syndrome patients will have a tumour by ages 30 and 70?

50% by age 30
95% by age 70
In patients with Li Fraumeni syndrome who develop a malignancy, what percentage will develop a second malignancy?
When should testing for Li Fraumeni syndrome be considered?

HER2 positive cancer age <35
Family history of cancer aged less than 45 AND sarcoma at any age
Childhood adrenal adenocarcinoma
What proportion of Li Fraumeni patients will develop a HER2 positve breast cancer?
Two thirds

A patient presents with breast cancer aged 25. Her mother had breast cancer diagnosed at age 30, and her aunt had a sarcoma aged 10. Her brother, two uncles, grandmother and grandfather are healthy. What is the most likely familial cancer syndrome and mutation?
Li Fraumeni, TP53
What is the function of the TP53 gene?

Tumour suppressor gene, mutation causes Li Fraumeni syndrome
Produces Tumour Protein 53, which delays cell cycle progression, can allow cell to initiate DNA repair, can initiate apoptosis
TP53 follows what pattern of inheritance?
Autosomal dominant (Li Fraumeni syndrome)
Mutation in how many alleles of TP53 within a single cell is required for malignant transformation?

Both must be mutated - two hit hypothesis, as it is a tumour suppressor gene.
One inherited as mutant (germline mutation)
Second allele mutates during life (somatic mutation) resulting in no gene to produce functional TP53
Usually missense mutation
Do all Li Fraumeni patients have an identifiable mutation in TP53?
No, but the majority do.
What screening should be offered to patients with Li Fraumeni syndrome?

Annual breast MRI or prophylactic mastectomy
No other effective screening for the other cancers - whole body MRI is being trialled.
Name 6 clinical features of Cowden syndrome

Large head circumference
Tricholemminomas (tumour of outer root sheath of hair follicle, benign, usually head and neck, may be described as skin tags)
Lhermitte Duclos (dysplatic cerebellar gangliocytoma, benign, may have cerebellar signs)
Breast cancer and benign breast changes (fibrocystic disease) 
Endometrial cancer
Follicular thyroid cancer
What type of gene is PTEN?
Tumour suppressor gene, seen in Cowden syndrome
What pattern of inheritance is seen in Cowden syndrome?
Autosomal dominant (PTEN tumour suppressor gene)
What is Cowden syndrome?

An autosomal dominant condition characterised by multiple hamartomas, large head, trichilemmomas, white flat mucosal lesions (papillomatous papules), increase cancer risk (breast, follicular thyroid, endometrial)
What proportion of Cowden syndrome patients have an identifiable PTEN mutation?
Around 1/3

Pancreatic cancer

Villous adenoma (75100% villous tissue)

Autosomal dominant syndrome

Usually asymptomatic until cancer diagnosis - present with symptoms of colorectal cancer

Name 8 extracolonic manifestations of familial adenomatous polyposis

Fundic gland polyps 
Gastric adenomas 
Duodenal cancer 5% (2nd most common cause of death)

Desmoid tumours 10 -15%

Congenital hypertrophy of the retinal pigment epithelium (CHRPE)
Osteomas, cysts
What type of thyroid cancer is typically seen in FAP?

What is the 2nd most common cause of death in FAP?

Describe the features of fundic gland polyps seen in patients with FAP

Occur in most patients
<1cm size
In fundus or body of stomach
May have 100s
Rarely progress to cancer
Describe the features of gastric adenomas seen in FAP

Uncommon
Typically isolated and located in the antrum
May progress to cancer
Describe the presentation of desmoid tumours in patients with FAP

Occur in 10 - 15%
Arise from fibroblasts, usually in the abdomen 
Slow growing (rapid progression in 10%) 
Do not metastasise, can cause morbidity and mortality due to compression of surrounding structures
Recur after resection
What is the penetrance of FAP in patients with APC gene mutation?
What percentage of patients with FAP have de novo mutations in the APC gene?
How many different APC gene mutations associated with FAP have been described?
>1000 different mutations
When should total colectomy be considered in patients with FAP?

Eventually required in all patients
Typically performed between age 15 - 25, once adenomas have been observed

100%

When shuold APC testing be considered

Cumulative count of 10 colorectal adenomas before 30 years of age or 
20 colorectal adenomas at any age
Known APC mutation in a relative (children should be tested at age 10)

APC mutation is seen in familial adenomatous polyposis
With regards to FAP, which patients should have colonic surveillance?

Patients with a diagnosis of FAP
Individuals found on genetic testing to carry a pathogenic APC mutation
First-degree relatives of patients with FAP or AFAP in whom genetic testing has been declined or is not possible because the family mutation has not been identified.
In AFAP, should surveillance be by colonoscopy or flexible sigmoidoscopy?

Colonoscopy - first adenomas may only be present in the proximal colon

This is unlike FAP, where flexisig is sufficient as adenomas appear simultanously throughout the colorectum.
Give a definition for MutYH associated polyposis

MUTYH-associated polyposis is an autosomal recessive polyposis syndrome. 
Patients typically have 100 - 1000 polyps (less than FAP)
Onset at age 45 (later than FAP)
Can get FAP-like extracolonic manifestations but no desmoid disease
What percentage of the population have a mutation in one MUTYH allele?
What percentage of colorectal cancer patients have biallelic MUTYH mutations?
What percentage of patients with multiple colorectal adenomas and no APC mutation have biallelic MUTYH mutations?
What is the function of the MUTYH gene?

MUTYH protein repairs oxidative damage to DNA

Mutation results in MUTYH associated polyposis
What pattern of inheritance does MUTYH associated polyposis follow?
Autosomal recessive
What is the recommended surveillance for patients with biallelic MUTYH mutations?

These patients have MUTYH associated polyposis
Colonoscopy every 2 years from age 18 - 20
Once polyps are detected, annual colonoscopy

Give a definition for Peutz-Jeghers syndrome

Autosomal dominant syndrome characterized by

- lip, buccal, and palm pigmentation
- increased risk of colorectal, breast, and other cancers (lifetime cancer risk 37 - 93%)
Mutation in what gene is responsible for Peutz-Jegher syndrome?

Mutation in STK11 results in what syndrome?

Name 6 non-colorectal cancers seen in patients with hereditary non-polyposis colorectal cancer (HNPCC)

Stomach cancer 5 - 15%

3-2-1 rule:

When should surveillance be commenced for patients with hereditary non polyposis colorectal cancer syndrome (HNPCC)?

Surveillance colonoscopy every 1 to 2 years

What is the frequency of germline mutations in a MMR-gene in unselected individuals with colorectal cancers?

2-4%

How is tumour testing in patients with suspected HNPCC conducted?

Immunohistochemistry staining for the 4 MMR proteins
PCR testing for microsatellite instability

95% concordance between the two, both are acceptable.
In which patients is tumour testing for HNPCC-like features conducted?
Colorectal cancer diagnosed prior to age 50

What is the lifetime risk of endometrial cancer in HNPCC?
What risk reduction strategies are recommended in HNPCC that are directed at non-colonic manifestations (3)?

When should HER2 directed therapy be withheld in patients with asymptomatic decreases in LVEF?
When should HER2 directed therapy be withheld in patients with asymptomatic decreases in LVEF?
When should HER2 directed therapy be withheld in patients with asymptomatic decreases in LVEF?
When should HER2 directed therapy be withheld in patients with asymptomatic decreases in LVEF?

Human epidermal growth factor receptor 2 (HER2) is an oncogene, part of the epidermal growth factor receptor (EGFR) family

Binds to extracellular portion HER2, resulting in

APC, or
MLH1

What is a 'founder mutation'?

A specific mutation that is observed with high frequency in a population
Arises due to
- genetic bottleneck (large number of population die)
- selective mating (due to geographical isolation, religious/cultural constraints)
e.g. BRCA mutations in Iceland and Ashkenazi Jews
What is a 'recurrent mutation'?

A specific mutation that is common in a population not due to the founder effect, but due to occuring in lots of different people as an independent event
Commonly in genes with repeditive sequences as this increases mutation rate
e.g. cystic fibrosis CFTR delta 508 mutation
What is a missense mutation?
A point mutation in which a single base change results in a codon that codes for a different amino acid compared to the original
What is a codon?
Sequence of three nucleotides (bases) that codes for a single protein
What are introns and exons?

Exons are coding areas of DNA - i.e. they code for a protein
Introns are the areas of DNA between the exons, they are removed by RNA splicing fore the mature RNA molecule is generated
How many pairs of chromosomes do we normally have?
How many chromosomes do we normally have?
What is a nonsense mutation?
A single point mutation that results in change of codon to a STOP codon (as opposed to a codon that codes for a protein)
What is a frameshift mutation?

An insertion or deletion of one or more nucleotides that shifts the 'reading frame' of a gene
Genes are read in sets of three - three bases make one codon
if a number that is not a multiple of three is added or subtracted, the subsequent bases will be read in different groups of three, altering which amino acid is produced for each
Can result in an early STOP codon and much shorter protein
Tend to produce singificantly abnormal protein (more so than non-frameshift mutations)

e.g.
What is signal to noise ratio, and how is it calculated?

Signal to noise ratio is used to determine the liklihood that detection of a given mutation is of significance
Noise is the frequency of the genetic mutation in the population
Signal is the mutation in cases
The signal-to-noise ratio is calculated by dividing the yield in cases by the background rate of variants of uncertain significance (VUS) in controls.

e.g. long QT signal to noise ratio is 19:1 (for 19 true cases there will be 1 false positive)
What signal to noise ratio is suggested as a cutoff for use of a genetic test?
What positive predictive value is suggested in the college lecture as a cutoff for use of a genetic test?
40% (can't find another reference!)

KVLQT1 on chromosome 11, codes for the slowly acting component of the outward-rectifying potassium current (IK), which prolongs ventricular action potentials

Which patients should be tested for long QT mutations? (3)

Patients with long QT phenotype
Family members of the above

Congenital deafness

What is Brugada syndrome?

Autosomal dominant disorder with variable expression
Characterised by abnormal ECG findings and increased risk of ventricular tachyarrythmias and sudden cardiac death

Brugada syndrome is presence of the pattern +  sudden cardiac death or a sustained ventricular tachyarrhythmia, or who have one or more of the other associated clinical criteria (long list of factors including family history, other arrythmias, other ECG findings)
What are Brugada type 1 and 2?

Two different ECG patterns seen in Brugada syndrome and Brugada patern

Type 1: elevated ST segment (2 mm) descends with an upward convexity to an inverted T wave ("coved type" Brugada pattern)

Type 2 Brugada: ST segment has a "saddle back" ST-T wave configuration, in which the elevated ST segment descends toward the baseline, then rises again to an upright or biphasic T wave

Increasing the ventricular end diastolic pressure (preload) increases the strength of the subsequent ventricular contraction

Describe how the Frank Starling curve shifts in heart failure

Despite increasing preload (end diastoic pressure), contractility does not increase by the usual amount

Aortic stenosis

We are looking at LV outflow tract so must relate to aortic valve.

Then there is flow back towards the probe in diastole - aortic regurgitation
Answer = C
Describe how aortic pseudostenosis may occur

Mild to moderate aortic stenosis present
Then situation causing poor flow arises (low cardiac output, low pressure gradient)
Unable to generate enough pressure to open the valve fully, so valve area appears severely reduced instead of mild/moderate

A patient has reduced ejection fraction, low flow, and a low pressure gradient across their aortic valve. The valve area indicates severe AS (<1.0cm2). How can it be determined if this is true severe AS?

Low flow states may cause aortic valve area to look smaller (not enough pressure to open it fully, making disease look more severe)
It may also mask severe AS by masking pressure gradient (not enough pressure to generate gradient)
Correct the ejection fraction via dobutamine stress echo and see if meet criteria for severe AS
- valve area improves with only tiny increase in gradient - not true severe AS
- valve area stays the same and gradient increases > 40mmHg - true severe AS

A patient has severe AS (valve area <1) with low flow, low gradient (<40mmHg), and reduced EF. It is not correctable with dobutamine stress test (no flow reserve). 
How may it be determined if this is true severe AS requiring valve replacement?

This is 'paradoxical' low flow state with normal EF
Calcium score - significant valve calcification favours true severe AS
A patient presents with apparent severe AS (valve area <1), low flow, low gradient (<40mmHg) and preserved EF. Do they have true severe AS? Why does this occur?

These patients have 'paradoxical' low flow low gradient
e.g. may have severe LV hypertrophy with restricted filling causes reduced flow but normal EF
Consider intervention if symptomatic and comprehensive evaluation suggests significant valve obstruction

Describe the workup of a patient with aortic stenosis with valve area <1 and mean gradient <40mmHg

Rule out measurement error
Rule out small body size
Assess ejection fraction and flow
- if low EF, perform dobutamine stress echo to correct low flow state. If gradient >40mmHg severe AS confirmed
- If low EF that is not correctable, perform calcium score
- If normal EF and low flow, consider replacement after 'careful confirmation of severe AS'
- if normal EF and normal flow, pseudosevere AS

Describe the mechanism of action of angiotensin receptor-neprilysin inhibitors (ARNI)

Naturetic peptides like BNP promote natriuresis and vasodilation
Neprilysin degrades natriuretic (and other vasoactive) peptides - neprilysin inhibitors block this
However neprilysin also breaks down angiotensin II, so inhibition leads to more angiotensin II and RAAS activation
Therefore ARB must be given concurrently - this combination is ARNI

Describe how cirrhosis leads to complications such as ascites, hyponatraemia, and hepatorenal syndrome. (6)

Cirrhosis ->
Intrahepatic resistance (due to fibrosis of the sinusoids) ->
Portal (sinusoidal) hypertension ->
Increased splanchnic/systemic vasodilation (which leads to high cardiac output and high output cardiac failure) ->
Greatly reduced effective arterial blood flow ->
RAAS activation (sodium/water retention, renal vasoconstriction)

Water retention causes hyponatraemia
Sodium retention causes refractory ascites
Renal vasocontriction causes reduced renal blood flow and hepatorenal syndrome (can also be due to high output cardiac failure)

Management of complications of liver cirrhosis
Management of complications of liver cirrhosis

Effective hypovolaemia due to splanchnic arterial vasodilation
RAAS activation with sodium retention leads to positive fluid balnce
Extracellular fluid volume expansion

What is hepatic venous pressure gradient?

Hepatic venous pressure gradient = wedged hepatic venous pressure - free hepatic venous pressure
Used to quantify degree of portal hypertension that is due to sinusoidal resistance to blood flow
(The wedged pressure approximates sinusoidal pressure)

Normal 1 - 5
Portal hypertension present if >6
Clinically significant portal hypertension >10
At risk of ascites and varices > 12

Reduce cardiac output and thereby reduce splachnic bloodflow
Allow unopposed alpha 1 adrenergic receptor activity which results in splanchnic vasoconstriction -> less blood flow into portal vein -> lower portal pressure

Nonaggressive resuscitation
Octreotide OR terlipressin for 5 days
Endoscopy with banding within 12 hours
- If fails or not possible, consider balloon tamponade
Consider emergency TIPS if ongoing bleeding
Ceftriaxone, then step down to norfloxacin (minimum 2 days, up to 7 days treatment)
PPI has minimal evidence but is usually given

Rifaximin 550mg BD

Terlipressin, and
Albumin

Describe the diagnostic criteria for hepatorenal syndrome acute kidney injury (HRS-AKI, formerly known as HRS type 1) (5)

More than 2 fold increase from baseline creatitine
Does not improve with diuretic withdrawal and volume expansion with albumin
No shock
No recent nephrotoxic drugs
No parenchymal renal disease
Describe the pathogenesis of hepatorenal syndrome (6)

Portal hypertension -->
Splanchic arterial vasodilatation (due to increased production of vasodilators, mainly nitric oxide) -->
Decreased effective circulatory volume, rise in cardiac output, fall in systemic vascular resistance -->
RAAS activation -->
Renal vasoconstriction -->
Renal hypoperfusion and hepatorenal syndrome
Describe the expected urinalysis findings in a patient with hepatorenal syndrome (4)

Benign urine sediment
No or minimal proteinuria
Very low sodium
Oliguria
Describe type 1 and type 2 hepatorenal syndrome

Type 1: The more serious type; at least a twofold increase in serum creatinine (reflecting a 50 percent reduction in creatinine clearance) to a level greater than 221 micromol/L in < 2 weeks
Type 2: more insidious onset than type 1. Characterised by treatment-resistant ascites.
Describe the presentation of hepatorenal syndrome (5)

Progressive rise in serum creatinine
Oliguria
Normal urine sediment
No or minimal proteinuria
Very low urinary sodium
Describe the typical patient who may develop hepatorenal syndrome (4)

Ascites
Low MAP

What is the mechanism of action of terlipressin in the treatment of hepatorenal syndrome? (4)

Terlipressin is a long acting vasopressin
Causes vasoconstriction by activation of vasopressin receptor (V1)
This is expressed on vascular smooth muscle cells in the splanchic bed
Thus reverses splanchnic vasodilation

Should be given as a continuous infusion. Can be continued indefinitely as a bridge to transplant.
What is the only definitive therapy for hepatorenal syndrome?

all three of:

three out of five of:

drug toxicity

Describe the mechanism of action of calcineurin inhibitors to bring about immunosuppression (2)

Without calcineurin, the nuclear factor of activated T cells (NFAT) does not translocate to the nucleus, and interleukin (IL)-2 production (along with a number of other genes) is shut down
Results in markedly diminished T-cell response to class I and class II antigens, and a significant reduction in the rejection cascade
What is the mechanism of action of tacrolimus?

A macrolide antibiotic with immunosuppresive action
Binds to FK-binding proteins, which then competitively binds to and inhibits calcineurin
This inhibits the translocation of a family of transcription factors (NF-AT), leading to reduced transcriptional activation of cytokine genes for
- interleukin (IL)-2
- (TNF)-alpha
- IL-3
- IL-4
- CD40L
- granulocyte-macrophage colony-stimulating factor
- interferon-gamma
Ultimately, proliferation of T lymphocytes is reduced.
Name 3 short term complications post liver transplant

Describe chronic rejection post liver transplant

blood Pressure
BMI

>3 is good sensitivity but poor specificity

What are the diagnostic criteria for OSA?

AHI >5 and one symptom, or
AHI > 15
Describe the management of OSA

Weight loss, lifestyle modification (very low energy diet) +/- bariatric intervention
Nasal treatments (nasal dilating strips or intranasal steroids)
Surgery
Position treatments (vibrate when lie supine)
Mandibular advancement splint
CPAP (Australian invention!)
Which patients should trial CPAP for sleep apnoea?

Epworth sleepiness core >10/24 with moderate to severe disease
Severe disease
What proportion of sleep apnoea patients fail to tolerate CPAP long term?
What are the benfits of CPAP in OSA?
Improve cognitive function, sytolic/diastolic blood pressure, quality of life, depression, sleepiness
What is the impact of CPAP use on cardiovascular outcomes?

Do not improve cardiovascular mortality in RCTs, some data in observational trials show does improve.
NO improvement in cardiovascular event rates in patients with cardiovascular disease (SAVE trial: NEJM 2016, Australian study)
How does CPAP work?

Pneumatically 'splints' the upper airway open
Provides constant pressure
Does not ventilate the patient; they need to breath
What are the two types of CPAP?

Fixed pressure - deliver one constant pressure
Automatic - detects reduction in flow and matches the delivered pressure to patient's need. Good to use for a trial to determine patient's 'ideal'pressure. 50% more expensive than fixed pressure.

Both equally good at fixing AHI
How does BiPAP work?

Gives background expiratory positive airway pressure (EPAP) (also called CPAP) to open up airway
Then on top of this gives inspiratory positive airway pressure (IPAP) which breathes for the patient
Then IPAP switches off and the natural chest recoil causes breath out, against the constant background pressure
Should vented or nonvented masks be used with CPAP and BiPAP?

BiPAP masks may be vented or nonvented
CPAP must ALWAYS have a vented mask or they will just rebreath their own CO2
Describe 3 modes a BiPAP can be set to

Spontaneous mode (S) - patient trying to breath, BiPAP detects and gives a breath to help
Timed mode (T) - breath given every certain (programmed) number of seconds (would use in patients making no respiratory effort at all)
ST mode - BiPAP will give a breath if patient tries to breath, and if no effort detected after a certain time period, will give a breath (most are set this way)
What are type 1 and type 2 respiratory failure?

Type 1: hypoxia with normal CO2
Type 2: hypoxia with elevated CO2
Name 2 broad causes of type 2 respiratory failure

Increased dead space
- anything in the alveoli e.g. infection, fluid
Reduced minute ventilation
- normal lungs but reduced respiratory effort e.g. sedation, respiratory muscle weakness
How is A-a gradient calculated?

PAO2 - PaO2

Where
PAO2 = amount of oxygen in the alveoli
PaO2 = arterial concentration of oxygen on arterial blood gas
How is PAO2 calculated?

PAO2 is the alveolar oxygen tension

where 
FiO2 is the fraction of inspired oxygen (0.21 at room air)
Patm is the atmospheric pressure (760 mmHg at sea level) 
PH2O is the partial pressure of water (47 mmHg at 37C)
PaCO2 is the arterial carbon dioxide tension
What is a normal A-a gradient?

For a young nonsmoker breathing room air, 5-10mmHg
Increases normally with age
Can use normal <  [age in years/4] + 4
What does a high A-a gradient indicate in a hypoxic patient?
Cause of hypoxia likely due to oxygen transfer/gas exchange problems (e.g. alveolar membrane diseases, interstitial diseases, or ventilation/perfusion (V/Q) mismatch.)
What does a normal A-a gradient indicate in a hypoxic patient?
Hypoxia likely due to hypoventilation e.g. respiratory muscle weakness, sedation
What O2 sats should clinicians aim for in type 2 respiratory failure?

88 - 92%
Higher can cause worsening respiratory failure
Name 5 contraindications to BiPAP

Severely impaired conscious state
Patient cannot protect upper airway
Upper airway burns/trauma/surgery
Haemodynamic instability
Unable to cope with BiPAP
Define chronic respiratory failure
Awake with PaCO2 > 45 with normal pH

CO210mmHg higher asleep than awake

Deficiency of dopamine transport are thought to be involved in pathogenesis

Total lung capacity

Low total lung capacity (TLC)
What lung volume abnormality is seen in hyperinflation?
High total lung capacity (TLC)

High residual volume/total lung capacity ratio (RV/TLC)

Reduced lung compliance (stiff lungs, e.g. ILD)
Stiff chest wall (e.g. kyphoscoliosis)

Increase in residual volume
Increase in functional residual capacity
How is gas transfer/diffusing capacity (TLCO) measured?

Breath in a known quanity of CO up to total lung capacity and hold for 10 seconds
When breath out, can measure the concentration that is left and use to calculate how much has been transferred
What is TLCO?

The amount of CO that can access available haemoglobin
Measurement of diffusing capacity, i.e. the ability to conduct gas exchange
What parameters are measured in gas exchange? (3)

TLCO - diffusing capacity (can be corrected for Hb if anaemia)
VA - alveolar volume
KCO (TLCO/VA): transfer coefficient, the gas exchange per unit of lung volume.
Name 3 factors that reduce TLCO

Problems with the blood-gas barrier (diffusion)
- thickening of the membrane (e.g. ILD, pulmonary oedema)
- reduction in surface area (emphysema)
Capillary blood problems (rate of combination)
- anaemia
- change in capillary blood colume
Reduced lung volume
Why might a patient with asthma have a reduced FVC that corrects with bronchodilator?

Gas trapping
Not true restriction.
What is the role of KCO in interpretation of lung volumes?

KCO - ratio of TLCO to alvolar volume (VA)
Increased in:
- pneumonectomy (discrete loss of alveolar volume and only small impairment in DLCO)
- incomplete lung expansion, e.g. kyphoscoliosis, neuromuscualar disorders (reduced VA more than reduced DLCO)
Low in
- emphysema
- interstitial lung disease (reduced DLCO, reduced VA)
- pulmonary vascular disease (reduced DLCO, normal VA)
What abnormality is shown?

Normal spirometry
No response to bronchodilator
Reduced TLCO with reduced KCO indicates diffusion defect - patient has scleroderma lung disease
What abnormality is shown?

Airflow obstruction with >20% reversibility
This is typical of asthma
Note reduced FVC prior to bronchodilator - due to gas trapping, not true restrictive lung disease

Flow volume shows fixed upper airway obstruction
Patient has tracheal stenosis

Variable extrathoracic obstruction (flattened insiratory curve)

Describe the defect below.

Restriction on spirometry (reduced FEV1 and FVC with normal ratio)
TLCO within normal limits despite reduced alveolar volume

Describe the defect below

Severe obstructive defect with decreased FVC
Reduced TLCO with reduced alveolar volume
Raised TLC and FRC indicate hyperinflation
RV/TLC raised confirms gas trapping as cause of reduced FVC

Patient has severe COPD.
In healthy controls, maximal cardiorespiratory function is limited by which - cardiac or respiratory function?

Cardiac function is the limitation.

Should have some ventilatory reserve at the end of exercise

Reduced workload achieved

Poor workload (41% predicted)
Desaturation with exercise

Limitation due to respiratory dysfunction

Tachycardia at start of study
Did not exceed VEmax (respiratory reserve is present)

Baseline tachycardia and exceed HRmax

Exercise limitation due to cardiac dysfunction
What is the second most common cancer in Australia
Colorectal

Right sided and transverse colorectal cancers arise from the midgut or the hindcut?
Midgut
Left sided colorectal cancers arise from the midgut or the hindcut?
Hindgut

Obesity

MSH6

Less severe variant of FAP with fewer adenomas (<100) with older age of cancer diagnosis (in 50s)

Age 10-12 with flexi-sig or colonoscopy
Continue until colectomy, usually in late teens or early twenties depending on number and size of adenomas

Age 25

1 in 32
Which patients should be considered for screening colonoscopies for colorectal cancer? (3)

Personal history of CRC
Hereditary CRC syndrome
Strong family history

How is aspirin thought to function in its role as primary prophylaxis against colorectal cancer? (3)

Inhibition of COX2 (70% of CRC express COX2)
Antiplatelet effect thought to decreases rate of metastasis
Direct modulation of ocogene induced expression of transcription factors

Reduced incidence (HR 0.76) and mortality (HR 0.65)
Benefit is delayed - onset of effect after around 5 years
Patients with colorectal cancer with a history of aspirin use have a better prognosis if PIK3CA mutant

Reduces risk of colorectal cancer (59% risk reduction)

What percentage of stage II CRC are cured with surgery alone?
Describe the management of stage II (T3 - T4, N0) colorectal cancer

Surgery (80% cure)
adjuvant chemo with single agent 5FU or capecitabine has limited benefit (up to +4%), only recommended if high risk:
- T4 tumour
- Perforation/obstruction
- LVI/PNI
- Poorly differentiated
- Inadequate node sampling (<12)

Do NOT use if MMR deficient - trend towards harm
Define stage II colorectal cancer
T3N0 or T4N0
Define stage I colorectal cancer

T1N0

Describe the management of stage I (T1-2, N0) colorectal cancer

Surgery alone
No role for chemotherapy

Single agent adjuvant capecitabine or 5FU
+4% cure rate in addition to surgery
Define stage III colorectal cancer

Any T
N1 or N2
M0
What is the standard management of stage III colorectal cancer?

Surgery
Adjuvant FOLFOX for 6 months
- there is an argument for 3 months of therapy if low risk (e.g. only 1 positive lymph node) to avoid toxicity
HR 0.8 of disease free survival with addition of chemo
Which patients with rectal cancer who are considered fit for surgery appropriate for neoadjuvant chemotherapy?

T3 or T4 tumour
Low rectal cancer not amenable to local excusion
Tumour invades or in close proximity to mesorectum
Which patients with rectal cancer who received neoadjuvant chemo will also receive adjuvant chemo?
Adjuvant chemo considered if patients are found on histopath to have responded to neoadjuvant chemo
Describe the surveillnace post curative-intent treatment for early stage colon cancer

Frist 2 years: 3 monthly clinical review, plus CEA and CT every 6 months
Yaer 3 - 5: 6 monthly clinical review and CEA, plus annual CT
Colonoscopy 1 year post, then every 2nd year
Which patients with metastatic colorecal cancer should receive intensive therapy?

Potentially resectable mets (to achieve cure)
Nonresectable with high tumour burden and tumour-related symptoms (to improve QoL)

Patients with low volume or indolent disease can be managed more conservatively
Does RAS or RAF status influence the appropriateness of bevacizumab for metastatic colorectal cancer?
No
Does primary tumour location (right or left) influence the appropriateness of bevacizumab for metastatic colorectal cancer?
No
Name 2 EGFR inhibitors

Cetuximab
Panitumumab
Why can EGFR inhibitors not be used in RAS mutant tumours?

the EGFR pathway leads to cell proliferation, survival, invasion and metastasis
Blocking the EGFR receptor switches off this pathway
However if RAS mutant, there are mutations further down the pathway in KRAS or NRAS which result in the pathway being permanently activated, regardless of EGFR signalling
Hence blocking EGFR signas in these patients is ineffective
Name 4 toxicities of cetuximab

Rash (most common)

GI (nausea, vomiting, diarrhoea)
Fever

Sunscreen

In right sided lesions, bevacizumab may be superior (though either can be used)

Anti-PDL1 (pemprolizumab)

These are thin lines 1-2 cm in length in the periphery of the lung(s). They are perpendicular to the pleural surface and extend out to it. They represent thickened subpleural interlobular septa and are usually seen at the lung bases.

Describe the management of idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis (7)

Treat GORD
Oxygen if hypoxic
Pulmonary rehab
Manage comorbidities
Conser list for lung transplantation
Consider refer to clinical trials

Rash
Diarrhoea

HRCT consistent with IPF in last 12 months
FEV1/FVC > 0.7 (not obstructed)
FVC > 50% (not too severe)
DLCO > 30%
Multidisciplinatry diagnosis (MDT)
Not due to other known causes (e.g. connective tissue, environmental exposure)
Treated by a respiratory physician

No, strong recommendation to NOT use

HRCT - check pattern of involvement
Screen for autoimmune disease
Screen for co-existant emphysema and pulmonary hypertension
Serial lung function, check FVC and DLCO trends
+/- Bronchioalveolar lavage
+/- Biopsy

- ground glass

endobronchial ultrasound-guided transbronchial needle aspiration (EBUS TNBA)
How is a population of naive B cells with different surface receptors (to match to different antigens) generated from common lymphoid progenitor cells (CLP)?

Antigen receptor (VDJ) rearrangement: randomly generated receptor through random gene segment recombination 
This results in a unique immunoglobulin displayed on its surface
It can then wait for a matching antigen, and undergo clonal expansion if it does

Note it can randomly generate an immunoglobulin against self (occurs in 60 - 80% prior to selection)
Negative selection reduces this population
Maturing T cells undergo what process as they mature in the thymus?

Positive selection on bases of strength of binding to self HLA
- removal of strongly binding (anti-self)
- removal of no-binding useless T cells
- keep the weakly binding T cells
How does the thymus avoid producing anti-self T cells?

AIRE
Expression molecule in the thymus that regulates self-expression
Allows the thymus to present a variety of 'self' molecules (e.g. a bit of thyroglobulin, a bit of insulin, etc) to insure anti-self T cells against these are deleted
How is it determined what kind of T helper cell population will be created during a given immune response?

The predominant cytokine present at the time
e.g. if IL-4 is around, they become Th2
Immune responses against blood borne pathogens mostly occurs in which organ
the spleen
Different immunoglobulins (IgG, A, M, etc) have what differences?
A different heavy chain (e.g. IgG all have the same heavy chain)

Heavy chain (constant)
Hinge region
Light chain (end of the light chain is variable antigen binding site)
On an immunoglobulin IgG, how many hypervariable regions are there?
What is the role of the hypervariable region of immunoglobulin?
antigen binding
What are the roles of the Fc and Fab regions of an immunoglobulin?

Fc = effector region (heavy chain)
Fab = antigen binding (light chain)
Describe the difference between avidity and affinity in immunoglobulins

Avidity = overall interaction between antibody and target
Affinity = interaction between one antibody binding site and its target

E.g. IgM has lots of binding sites that are weak. It has high avidity but low affinity.
What is the role of IgG?

Predominates in serum
Main antibody of specific immune response
- slower but more durable response to infection
- important defence against bacteria, viruses
- opsonising 
- activates complement
Crosses placenta and protects neonate
Describe the function of IgM

Exists in serum and on B cell surface
Exists as a pentamer in serum - multivalency (which increases its affinity despite low avidity)
Extra constant domain in place of hinge of IgG
Rapid response to infection but short lived
Good at activating complement and agglutinating bacteria
Important defence against bacteria, viruses
What produces IgG in the secondary immune response?
Memory B cells
What is the role of IgA?

Mucosal surface protection.
Predominates in secretions (saliva, breast milk, tracheobronchial and genitourinary secretions)
Inhibits pathogenic colonoisation of mucosal surfaces/tissues
Binds to mucsu and traps pathogens
Inhibits penetration of bacterial toxins
How is IgA transport mediated?

Polymeric Ig receptor (pIgR)
Synthesised by epithelial cells. Sits on luminal surface, binds IgA and transports across epithelium
What is the role of IgD?

Co-expressed on surface of naive B cells with IgM

Describe the role of IgE

Exists on surface of mast cels and basophils
Trace amounts in serum

Pathogenic role in allergic disease (allergen cross-linking and degranulation)
Describe how antibody activation of B cells works

Immunoglobulins on B cell surface activate B cells when they (surface Ig (smIg)) are cross linked by antigen
B cells then go on (with T cell help) to produce the identicl Ab present on their cell surface
Name 6 functions of immunoglobulins

Activate B cells
Neutralisation of toxins, viruses, bacteria
Activate complement
Opsonisation
Ab-depndent cell mediated cytotoxicity
Activate innate cells (neutrophils, macrophages)
How long does maternal IgG last in a newborn after birth, conferring protection?
6 months
Define isotype
Variations in Igs which are present in all members of the species
Define idiotype in relation to immunoglobulin
Structural variation in the antigen binding region of an immunoglobulin
What is a hapten? Given an example

A small molecule that alone will not elicit an immune response, but will do so when linked to a larger one (called a carrier)
e.g. penicillin is a tiny molecule, too small to elicit an immune response on its own, but can do so when bound to albumin
What is an adjuvant with regards to immune response?
Substance that enhances the immune reponse, which can turn a toleragen into an immunogen
What is an epitope (determinant)
A portion of a macromolecule to which an antibody binds
Describe the process of B cell antibody production (4)

Recognise antigen via immunoglobulin IgM on its surface (SmIg, 'b cell receptor')
Break down Ag and re-present to T cells as peptides on surface MHC class II
T cells provide activation signal ('help')
B cells differentate to antibody secreting cells
What are KRECS and TRECs?

Circular DNA segments that are markers of new B cell output (KRECS) and T cell output (TRECs)
Absence can be used to screen newborns for severe combined immunodeficiency, agammaglobulinaemia prior to clinical manifestations
What screening do B cells undergo just prior to exiting the bone marrow as naive B cells?

Tolerance
- highly cross linking self Ag -> apoptosed
- minimally cross linking self-Ag -> angergy (inactivation)
- receptor editing rearranges other light chain to escape autoreactivity (40 - 50% of developing B cells)
What is the role of B cell activating factor (BAFF)?

Promotes survival of naive B cells at late transitional stage
- upregulates TLR expression
- promotes Ig class switching
Mutations block development -> no B cells
BAFF levels are increased in autoimmune disease (belimumab for SLE is anti-BAFF,)
What happens to B cells after they exit the bone marrow?
Naive B cells migrate to spleen, LN, MALT, GALT and await a specific antigen (and T cell help) before differentiating further
Describe the process of somatic hypermutation of B cells, and how it brings about affinity maturation

Occurs in germinal centres, after a naive B cell has encountered a matching antigen
B cell moves to the germinal centre and multiplies rapidly
Very high mutation rate, random point mutations introduced by AID into the V regions (hypervariable CDR 'hotspots')
Done to try to improve affinity (affinity maturation)
Cells are then tested (at the T cell/B cell border) for increased affinity to the antigen; if higher, they survive, if not, die by apoptosis
What is isotype switching?

Activated B cells, which are proliferating in a germinal centre after being activated by encountering an antigen, switch isotypes (e.g. from IgM/IgD to IgG, IgA, IgE)
They change the constant region of the antibody heavy chain without changing the V regions and thus the specificity to a particular antigen
Changes the effector function of the antibody produced
What two types of cells are generated following B cell maturation and clonal proliferation in a germinal centre?

Plasma cells (antibody-producing)
Memory B cells
What is the mechanism of action of Rituximab?

Anti-CD20 monoclonal antibody
Destroys mature B cells
Does not target plasma cells or pre-cell precursors
What do T cells do?

Recognise antigen as degraded peptide gragments present on the MHC
- by T cell receptor (TCR)

Two major subsets, CD4 and CD8

Major roles
- cytotoxic (CD8, CTL)
- helper (CD4)
What is the structure of T cell receptor?

Two chains, alpha and beta
Always membrane bound, never secreted
V and C regions
Bind antigens in their variable region
Associated with signalling chains of CD3 complex
Role is to recognise peptide presented on MHC
What are the two major classes of T cells?

CD4 (helper)
CD8 (cytotoxic)
Which MCH do CD4 and CD8 bind to?

CD4 binds to MHC class II and strengthens that interaction
CD8 binds to MHC class I and strengthens that interaction
Describe T cell development

T cell progenitors migrate from marrow to thymus
Undergo T cell receptor gene rearrangement (to make a wide variety of variable regions to recognise different antigens)
- Express functional TCR complex and expression of accessory molecules (CD4 or CD8)
Selection (learning to respond to MHC)
- 95% fail
- need to interact with self MHC but not too strongly (anti-self) or too weakly (useless)
- self reactive T cells may become T regulator cells

As they mature move from the cortex of the thymus, to the medulla, then exit to the periphery
Do T cells undergo somatic hypermutation, as B cells do?
No
How do T cells become either CD4 or CD8 positive?

When maturing they are positive for both, as it is not known if their will react better with MHC class I or II
If their T cell receptor ends up with an interaction with MHC class I -> keep their CD8, get rid of the other
If interacts with MHC class II -> keep their CD4, get rid of the other
What is the role of IL2 in T cell maturation?

Required ot generate T regulatory cells
- Acts via CD25 (IL-2R alpha)
- Induces Foxp3
Loss leads to out of control action of CD4 and CD8 T cells
What are the role of AIRE and FEZF2 in T cell maturation?

AIRE = autoimmune regulator
Exists in the cortical epithelial cells of the thymys
Turns on expresiosn of tissue specific Ags at low levels in the thymus
This allows developing T cells to see 'self' from various parts of the body, and be deleted if they react too strongly (deletion of high affinty T cells)
Describe autoimmune polyendocrine syndrome type 1

Autosomal recessive disorder due to mutated AIRE
- failure to express tissue-specific antigens in the thymus (for training T cells)
- therefore failyre to delete T cells specific for multiple tissue antigens
autoimmune T cells released into the periphery, causing autoimmunity
lymphocytic infiltration of multiple tissues and multiple autoantibodies

Cardinal manifestations:
- chronic mucocutanous candidiasis (antibody to cytokines that protect against candida, IL17 and IL22)
- autoimmune hypoparathyroidism
- autoimmune addison's disease
What occurs when T cells leave the thymus?

Mature T cells (naive and memory) leave and circulate through lymphoid tissue
Look for MHC+foreign peptide on APCs
Name 3 types of memory T cell

Central memory: circulate in lymphoid tissue
Effector memory: circulate through other tissue
Tissue resident memory: do not circulate, reside in tissue
Describe T cell activation and co-stimulation

Requires two signals to activate:
- signal 1: MCH+peptide
- signal 2: co-stimulation

Absence of co-stimulation results in tolerance (no activation)
Costimulation mediated by CD80 and CD86 on the APC
These interact with CD28 (activation) and CTLA4 (delayed deactivation, eventual cause of switch off of response) on the T cell
Describe the role of IL2 with regards to T cell function

IL2 is released from T cells
Drives resting T cell division (acts on IL2R)
Induces regulatory T cells (critical for induction and maintenance of Treg cells)

Target in renal cell cancer immunotherapy
Calcineurin inhibitors inhibit IL2 induction
Describe peripheral T cell tolerance (3)

A lot of tolerance occurs in the thymus (central tolerance via AIRE)

Peripheral tolerance mediated by
- Inhibitory molecule engagement (CTLA4, PD-1): inhibitory molecules expressed on T cell surface
(this is why checkpoint inhibitors like anti-PD1 results in autoimmunity; lifts the lid on the usual suppressive action of these molecules)
- Angery (MCH and TCR bind but no co-stimulation -> switch off of response or morph to Treg)
- Clonal ignorance: T cells do not 'see' antigen in priviledged sites (brain, eye, testes) as the T cells don't go there, or if they do are killed
Describe how sympathetic opthalmia works

T cells usually do not 'see' self antigens in the eye (T cells are ignorant of eye antigens)
Penetrating eye injury causes circulation of 'eye' antigens into the lymphatics
T cells react to eye antigens as non-self
T cell attack on both eyes
Name 3 markers of Treg cells

CD4+
Often CD25 pos
Express foxp3
What is IPEX (immune dysfunction, polyendocrinopathy, enterpathy, X-linked)

Lack of foxP3 means no Treg cells

Induced (in vitro - therapeutic use)

Kill other cells

Th2

- Candida
- Staphylococcus

What is the role of CD8 T cells?

Perforin-granzyme

Fas pathway

- apoptosis and cleavage of viral genes
TNF pathway

Complement

- strep pyogenes

- stpah aureus

- CMV, VZV, HSV, protozoa,

Structural (e.g bronchial obstruction, CF)
Burns
Skin desquamation

- +/- neutrophil oxidative metabolism test (screen for chronic granulomatous disease)
Biochem and LFT

HIV studies
Immunoglobulin levels (+/- IgG subclasses)
EPG (exclude paraproteinaemia)

- if previous vaccination, check antibodies to tetanus, diptheria
- give a vaccine e.g. pneumovax and check post-vaccination antibody levels
T cell subsets (% and count)
Completment (screen with CH50)
All T cells express what marker?

CD3
(check this)
What percentage of T cells express CD4

Common variable immunodeficiency
Bruton's agammaglobulinaemia
- X linked
- autosomal recessive
- other
IgA deficiency
IgG subclass deficiency
Specific Antibody syndrome
Hyper IgM syndrome
What percentage of CVID is familial?
What is the most common immunodeficiency requiring treatment in adults?
CVID

Chronic or recurrent diarrhoea
Malabsoprtion
- diarrhoea, LOW
- Sprue-like syndrome with nodular lymphoid hyperplasia of the SI

EGP: hypogammaglobulinaemia
Impaired vaccine response

Immunoglobulin
Antiboitics for infection - start early, treat for longer, identify the organism
HRCT and lung function every year (looking for bronchiectasis)

PIK3CD (27% of genetic CVID)

Around 30%
What is X linked agammaglobulinaemia (Bruton's agammaglobulinaemia)?

No B cells
Mutation in Bruton's TYR kinase causes block of B cell development at pre-B-I stage

Name 5 clinical manifestations of X linked agammaglobulinaemia

Onset at 6 months of age
B cell type infections of resp and gastro tract
Malabsorption
Polyarthropathy (RA)
Cjrpmoc echovirus meningoencephalitis (may be fatal)

Undetectable IgG
B cell count = 0
No plasma cells or germinal centres on tissue biopsy
B cell precursors present in marrow
Btk expression by flow cytometry
Genetic analysis of Btk gene
