Most do not present, found incidentally
- recruitment of oligometrig IgM into secretions to cover for IgA lack
Mucosal infections (sinopulmonary, giardia)
Associated with 
- atopy
- cow's milk allergy
- autoimmune
- Coeliac and other GIT disease (nodular lymphoid hyperplasia, inflammatory bowel)
(can have false negative coeliac disease testing due to IgA deficiency, can't make the antibody)
- Anaphylaxis if transfuse IgA containing blood products
Occurs at any age
Describe IgG subclass deficiency

Any single or combination of low IgG subclasses (1 - 4)
- IgG1 is most prevalent in serum; if this is low, tend to have frank hypogammaglobulinaemia
May have no manifestations
May have recurrent sinopulmonary infection
Normal B cell count
Can't get IVIG replacement on PBS
Describe specific antibody deficiency (SAD)

All Ig levels normal and B cells present
Specific antibody to vaccination is impaired
- pneumova, prevenar, HIB
Present with recurrent URTI
Can manage with trial of IVIG or vaccination
Describe hyper IgM syndrome

Absent CD40-CD40L signal
- failure of B cell isotype switching and memory B cell generation
- impairment of APC:T cell interaction
Type I is X linked (other types rare)
Can only make plasmoblasts and make IgM, cannot make anything except IgM
Recurrent severe bacterial infections (respiratory++, especially PCP)
Normal circulating B cells
Impaired antibody repsonses ot T cell dependent antigens
Neutropenia
Describe the investigation findings in hyper IgM sydrome (5)

Very low IgA, IgG, IgE; normal or raised IgM
Normal circulating B cells
Impaired antibody response to T cell dependent antigens
Flow cytometry for surface CD40L - absent
Molecular studies
Name 2 adult T cell deficiencies

Idiopathic CD4 lymphopenia (ICP)
Chronic mucocutaneous candidiasis / APECED
Describe idiopathic CD4 T cell lymphopenia

Low CD4 count, HIV negative
T cell type infections
- oesohpageal candida, MAC infection, disseminated VZV, cryptococcal pneumonia/meningitis
CD4 count < 300 or 20% of lymphocytes
Managed with prophylaxis for opportunistic infections
Describe chronic mucocutaneous candidiasis

Chronic/recurrent candida
Onset in childhood, affects skin, nails, mucosa, oesophagus, pulmonary
Often lack Th17 cells
Genetic (e.g. STAT1 gain of function mutation) or thymoma associated
What is the pathogenesis of SCID

Lack of a component essential for T cell function
- most common failure of gamma-common chain (cannot develop mature T cells)
Describe chronic granulomatous disease

Deficiency of 1 or 4 subunits of DADPH oxidase, which is responsible for respiratory burst of neutrophils necessary for killing organisms
Usually pediatric onset
Describe the infections seen in chronic granulomatous disease

Recurrent infection of skin, lungs, other tissues with coag negative bacteria and fungi
staph infections of skin (especially ears, nose)

Purulent dermatitis
Lymphadenitis, often granulomatosis
Recurrent bronchopneumonia
intestinal obstruction
Chron's like syndrome
Osteomyelitis
Aspergillus pneumonia
Describe the investigations for chronic granulomatous disease (3)

Tests of activated granulocyte ability to gnerate reactive oxygen species for microbicidal action:
NBT
Chemoluminescence
Flow cytometry for dihydrorhodamine reduction
Describe the treatment of chronic granulomatous disease

Chronic antibiotics
Immunisation
Interferon gamma
What activates the complement alternate pathway? (3)

surfaces of bacteria, viruses, other microbes
IgA immune complexes
C3 nephritic factor (autoantibody against C3bBb)
Name 4 principle funtions of complement

Opsonisation
Cytolysis
Activation of inflammatory response (anaphylactoxins C3a, C4a, C5a)
Immune complex clearing
Name the classical pathway components
C1q, C1r, C1s, C2, C4, C3
Name the alternate pathway components of the complement cascade
C3, B, D, Properdin
Name the membrane attack complex components
Describe the alternate pathway in the complement cascade

C3 spontaneously activated to C3b (constant 'tickover')
C3b can bind onto a foreign surface if present (if not, it is degraded)
Bound C3b activates distal components (factor B), which is then cleaved by factor D to make C3bBb, which binds to PRoperdin, which then makes lots of C3 convert to C3b and coat more of the target
C3bBb also binds to more C3b -> forms C5 convertase
Describe the classical pathway

Antibody binds to bacteria
This activates C1
This causes C2 and C4 to convert to C2a and C4a
C2aC2b forms, which is a C3 convertase - C3 is converted to C3b and coats the bacteria
What are anaphylatoxins

Act locally and facilitate acute inflammation
Can cause anaphylactic shock when in excess
cause
- smooth muscle contraction
- increased vasc permeability
- expression of adhesion molecules
- activate mas cells
What stops complement being activated by 'self'?

Complement control proteins
Multiple proteins acting at many levels to stop complement being deposited on 'self'
e.g. C1inh supresses the classical and lectin pathway
Describe the role of C1 esterase inhibitor

Serine protease inhibitor
Acts to suppress the classical and lectin complement pathways
Binds to C1r:C1s, causes them to dissociate from C1q, limits time available to activate C4 and C2
7 fold more C1inh than C1 in serum - hence deficiency means C1 cannot be controlled
Deficiency results in hereditary angioedema
How does the compleemnt system distinguish self from non-self?
Self expresses complement control proteins (DAF, CR1, MCP, etc)
Describe hereditary angioedema

Hemizyous deficiency of C1 esterase inhibitor (defect in 1 gene is enough deficiency to cause problem)
Increased classical C' activation
Activation of contact pathway of coagulation
Increased bradykinin release is the main driver of the swelling, rather than a complement problem (increased HMW kininogen to bradykinin)
Binds bradykinin B2 receptor -> oedema
Autosomal dominant, SERPING1 gene
- type I and type II

Uncontrolled activaiton of C1 results in:
- Activation and consumption of C4, C2 (not C3) - continuous, not just during attacks
- Excessive formation of FXIIa and kallikrein: bound (with HMW kininogen) to endothelium -> increases bradykinin -> oedema
Describe type 1 hereditary angioedema

marked reduction in c1-inh level
80 - 85% cases
describe type 2 hereditary angioedema

dysfunctional C1inh protein
c1inh levels normal or increased
15 - 20% cases
describe acquired c1inh deficiency

type1: b cell lymphoproliferative disorders; consumption of c1inh
type 2: associated with autoimmune disease or idiopathic; autoantibody to c1inh

C1q levels reduced (normal in hereditary)
describe the diagnosis of hereditary angioedema and acquired angioedema

C4 reduced, C3 normal
C1-INH: reduced in type 1, normal in HAE type II, and acquired type II
functional C1-inh assay is abnormal in all
C1q: decreased in acquired forms (consumption)
Describe the acute treatment of hereditary angioedema episodes

Replacement of purified C1-INH protein if life-threatening
Bradykinin-2 receptor antagonist (icatibant) - patients can self administer without ED presentation
Describe the prevention of hereditary angioedema episodes (5)

Regular C1-inh infusions if very severe
Anabolic steroids e.g. danazol
Tranexamic acid
Anti-kallikrein mAb (lanadelumab)
If acquired, also treat underlying disease
What is the most common complement deficiency syndrome
C2 deficiency
All hereditary complement deficiency syndromes follow what pattern of inheritance
Autosomal recessive (except properdin - x linked)
Hereditary complement deficiencies early in the cascade cause what type of problem?
Early complement component deficiencies cause immunocomplex disease: SLE, glomerulonephritis, vasculitis
Describe the pathogenesis paroxysmal nocturnal haemoglobinuria

Somatic mutation in PIG-A on X chromsome - > clonal expansion of haematopoietic stem cell
Results in deficiency of membrane-bound complement regulatory proteins CD59 and CD55 on red cell surface
Results in a clone of red cells without complement control protein which become targets for complement - > recurrent episodes of intravascular haemolysis
What is eculizumab

Monoclonal antibody against C5a
Used in paroxysmal nocturnal haemoglobinuria, atypical HUS
Where are HLA proteins coded for?
Chromosome 6 short arm
What is the role of class I HLA proteins
Bind peptides derived from degrated intracellular proteins and present them on the cell surface to interact with CD8 T cells' T cell receptor
What is the role of class II HLA proteins?

Present on antigen presenting cells
Bind peptides derived from degraded extracellular proteins (all types of forein pathogens) and express them on cell surface, to interact with CD4 T cells' T cell receptor
Describe the structure of HLA class I molecules

2 components:
Heavy chain with three domains: alpha 1, 2, and 3
- Alpha 3 can bind to CD8
- Peptide binding groove between alpha 1 and 2 (very polymorphic, which determines what peptide can be bound)
Beta 2 microclobulin
- coded for on chromosome 15
- levels reflect cell turnover
Where are HLA class I molecules expressed?

Most cells
Not on red blood cells, some neuronal cells
Where are HLA class II molecules expressed?
Antigen presenting cells (B cells, dendritic cells, macrophages, vascular endothelial cells)
How does HLA class I help CD8 cells determine healthy and unhealthy cells?

Healthy cells present self antigens via HLA I, are ignored
Unhealthy/nfected cells present foreign antigens, are targeted
Most variation between HLA molecules occurs where?
Peptide binding groove
Name 4 antigen presenting cells

B cells
Macrophages
Dendritic cells
Vascular endothelial cells
How does variation in HLA alleles protect the population from widespread disease?

Some variations in HLA will be good at binding a particular pathogen - it will be readily recognised and prompt an immune response
Other variations in HLA may not bind so well, so the pathogen prompts less response, and the individual is more severely affected
This variation means the population is affected differently by the same pathogen, and we are unlikely to be all wiped out by the same pathogen
How is HLA typing performed?

Molecular genetics
Gold standard is sequencing based typing (e.g. Sanger sequencing or next generation sequencing)
How does HLA nomenclature work?

HLA-[gene name]*[allele number]
e.g. HLA-DRB1*04:01
What is linkage disequilibrium?

When genes or alleles are non-randomly associated
i.e. the frequency of association between different genes is higher or lower than would be expected if they were independent and associated randomly

e.g. two genes located next to each other on the same chromosome are likely to be inherited together; there is linkage disequilibrium
How are HLA genes inherited?

Tend to be inherited together in a block (a haplotype)
One haplotype from each parent
e.g. each parent has two haploptypes (parent 1: A and B, parent 2: C and D)
Each child will randomly inherit a haplotype from each parent - e. A and C, A and D, B and C, or B and D
Describe how a patient may become refractory to platelet transfusion

Platelets express HLA class I
Patients may development anti-HLA antibodies - in this case need HLA matched transfusions
How do HLA DQ2 and DQ8 contribute to the pathogenesis of coeliac disease?
They can present gluten peptides, activating CD4 T cells
Name 2 HLA alleles associated with coeliac disease

HLA DQ2 
HLA DQ8
What HLA type should not be given abacavir?

HLA B*:57:01
This HLA binds a derivative of abacavir and presents it to T cells
What HLA type should not be given carbemazepine?

HLAB*15:02
HLA A *31:01
How to T and B cells recognise antigen?

B cells recognise intact antigen
T cells require it to be processed and expressed with MHC (class II for CD4, class I for CD8)
What is the role of antigen presenting cells?

Process an external antigen then present it via MHC II to CD4 T cells
- antigen broken into peptide fractments
- transported into endoplasmic reticulum
- MHC II molecules synthesied in ER and bind peptides in groove
- present on cell surface to CD4 cells
What is the role of MHC class I?

Sample cytoplasmic peptides and present on the cell surface
Allows continuous monitoring of the intracellular environment
- if cell is healthy, these will be 'self' peptides
- if foreign proteins present, this will be recognised by CD8 and cell targeted for killing
Describe how intracellular proteins are expressed on the cell surface via MHC class I

Cytoplasmic peptides degraded by proteosome
Free cytoplasmic peptides transported into endoplasmic reticulum by TAP-1 and TAP-2
Transported peptides associate with and stabilise MHC class I molecules and beta 2 microglobulin
Complex transported to the cell surface via Golgi apparatus
If foreign, will be recognised by CD8 and targeted for killing
How does HSV subvert the MHC class I antigen presenting process?

TAP inhibitor protein
Results in downregulation of MHC class I molecules (the virus avoids being expressed on cell surface to hide from CD8)
However NK cells recognise the lack of MHC class I anyway and kill it
How does adenovirus try to avoid intracellular detection by CD8?

Prevents surface expression of MHC class I
However NK cells recognise the lack of MHC class I anyway and kill it
How does CMV try to avoid intracellular detection by CD8 cells via MHC class I?
Accelerates transport of peptides out of the endoplasmic reticulum, reduces their chances of being bound to MHC class I and expressed on the cell surface
Describe how MHC class II pathway works

Antigen is taken up from the extracellular space into the intracellular space (into an endosome)
Protease activated in the endosome degrates the antigen peptide into fragments
Vesicles containing MHC II molecules fuse
- MHC class II groove is occupied by CLIP protein, which was keeping it from binding to things in the meantime
- CLIP is removed by HLADM
Antigen is loaded into MHC II groove and presented on the surface to be recognised by CD4 (signal 1)
Describe the function of classic dendritic cells (CDC)

Antigen presenting cell
Process the antigen (break it into peptides)
Present in surface via MHC class II
Express costimulator molecules
Migrate to meet immune reactive cells in the lymph nodes, spleen, or MALT
Describe the plasmacytoid dendritic cell

Respond to viral infection
- Role is to recognise virus and release a lot of type 1 interferon: induce rapid antiviral state
Not antigen presenting ells
Name 5 absolute contraindications to skin prick testing

Topical steroids (<72hrs)

Dermatography

Antihistamines (oral or intranasal)
Desensitisation (immunotherapy)
Name 6 contraindications to immunotherapy for atopy

Malignancy
Autoimmune
Beta blockers
Asthma with FEV1<70% or poor control
Pregnancy at the start of immunotherapy
Acute infection

Subcutaneous

Comparable efficacy
Sublingual can be used at home (more convenient) but more expensive

Downregulation of inflammation via induction of T regulator cells
Describe omalizumab

Anti-IgE monoclonal antibody
Binds free IgE and downregulates high affinty IgE expresiosn on mast cells

Describe the management of food allergy

Avoidance
Action plan +/- epipen
Treat comorbidities (asthma, cardiovascular)

Immunotherapy under trial, not used yet
Are egg, milk, and nut allergies in childhood likley to resolve?

80% egg and milk resolve by age 5

Is egg allergy/anaphylaxis a contraindication to influenza vaccine?
No

Peaks at 60 - 90min, persists up to 5 hours after anaphylaxis

Can be done for venom and drug allergy testing

At least 3 years

Type 2: antibody mediated
Type 3: immunocomplex mediated
Type 4 (delayed): T cell mediated
Describe the investigation of suspected drug allergy (5)

IgE mediated:
- Skin prick testing 
- intradernal skin testing (ONLY ever do this for venom or drugs)
Non IgE mediated
- Patch testing
- Delayed reading of intradermal testing

Can do drug provocation test in either (gold standard)

Generally do skin prick testing then provocation test in patients where you are trying to exclude allergy

Specific IgE (less useful)
Tryptase if suspect anaphylaxis (within 5 hours of episode)
Describe the management of drug allergy

Stop drug, seek alternative
Beware cross-reactivity
Consider desensitisation
- lifelong therapy, or
- recurrent desensitisation
(because tolerance is lost)
Name 6 contraindications to desensitisation for drug allergy

SJS
TEN
Haemolytic anaemia
Type II - IV reactions
Hepatitis
Interstitla nephritis
What is the cross reactivity rate of penicillin allergy with imipenen/meropenem?
What is the cross reactivity of cephalosporins with penicillin in patients with allergy?

1st gen: 5 - 16%
2nd: 4%
3rd: 1-2%

Particularly high crossreactivity between amoxicillin and cephalexin/cefaclor
Describe the diagnosis of radiocontrast medial allergy

Skin prick testing (high specificity but horrible sensitivity)

Describe the management of allergy to contrast media

Use low losmolar contrast or gadolinium

A patient is commenced on an ACE inhibitor and presents with tongue swelling. What is going on?

1-2% cross-reactivity with ARB

Name 2 non-IgE mediated drug reactions to aspirin/NSAIDs

Describe the investigation of suspected NSAID/aspirin angioedema or urticaria

Provocation challenge

Itchy hives for >6 weeks, recurrent, last <24hrs

Other investigations normal

Short course oral steroids for acute flares
Define Stevens Johnson syndrome and toxic epideermal necrolysis (TEN

SJS: <10% body surface
TEN: >30%

Severe delayed type hypertensitivity (type IV, T cell mediated)
Mortality 5 - 15%
Associations with HLA phenotypes in some drugs
Do not do skin prick testing or intradermal testing. Can test HLA.
Describe the management of SJS/TENS

Treatment
- supportive care
- Consider steroids + IVIG, cycA, TNF inhibitor
Can SJS/TENS occur weeks after starting a drug?
Yes, is a delayed type reaction, can occur 4 - 8 weeks after starting
Name 7 drugs associated with SJS/TENs

Antiinfective sulphonamides
Carbamazepine and phenytoin (aromatic antiepileptics)

Checkpoint inhibitors
Name 5 risk factors for SJS/TENS

Age >70
Active malignancy
Autoimmune disease
AKI
HIV
Describe Takayasu arteritis

Steroids
Methotrexate as steroid-sparing agent
Toxilizumab if refractory
Low dose aspirin if high cardiovascular risk

Immediately to preserve vision
Biopsy changes persist for several weeks (at least 2?)
Describe polyarteritis nodosa

ANCA negative

manage with pred + cyclophosphamide, then maintenance pred + aza
Antivirals if hep B positive
80% 5 year survival
Granulomatosis with polyangiits with associated with what renal manifestaiton?

Granulomatosis with polyangiits is typically positive for which antibody?
ANCA PR3 (80 - 90%)
What is the other name for Churg-strauss vasculitis?

Define eosinophilic granulomatosis with polyangiits

Eosinophil rich necrotising granulomatous inflammation of small vessels

- asthma (adult onset and severe)
- eosinophilia > 1.5
- mononeuropathy
- polyneuropathy
- pulmonary infiltrates
- paranasal sinus abn
- eosinophilic granulomas
ANCA pos in 30-40%

Name 2 causes of rapidly progressive GN

GBM disease
What is anti-GBM disease?

Pathogenic autoantibody against NC alpha 3 chain of type IV collagen

1/3 ANCA positive

Patients with henoch-scholein purpura may have what prodrome?

What is a good marker of prognosis in HSP?

Describe the management of Kawasaki disease

Aspirin
IVIG (reduces coronary aneurysms)
What are the criteria for Kawasaki disease

Bilateral conjunctival injection (80 - 90%)
Oropharyngeal mucosal changes (e.g. strawberry tongue, injeted pharynx, fissured lips) 80 - 90%
Peripheral extemity changes (erythema/oedema or hands or feet, or periungal desquamation) 80%
Polymorphous rash - primarily truncal, no vesicles >90%
Cervical lymphadenopathy 50%
NAme 3 major toxicities of methotrexate

Hepatotoxicity
Myelosuppression
Pulmonary fibrosis
Name 3 major toxicities of azathioprine

Hepatoxicity
Myelosuppression (check TPMT)
Skin cancer
Name 2 major toxicities of MMF

GIT
Hepatotoxicity
Name 7 major toxicities of cyclophosphamide

Amenorrhoea
Infertility (cumulative dose and age)
Teratogenicity
Bladder toxicity
Infection
Myelosuppression
Malignancy
How is hyperacute transplant rejection mediated?

Antibody mediated
Pre-existing anti-ABO or anti-HLA antibodies
- natural IgM ant-ABO antibodies may exist
- may form anti-HLA due to pregnancy (paternal HLA), transfusion, previous transplant
Occurs within minutes of perfusion of transplanted organ

Patients are screened for anti-HLA prior to transplant, and are given ABO matched transplant to avoid.
Describe how direct pathway leads to acute organ rejection

Occurs within days

Recipient T cells (CD8) are activated by HLA class I on donor tissue cells, which present donor peptide, which appear foreign to the native T cell
Aggressive and rapid reaction - graft cells killed by cytotoxic T cells

Also:
HLA class II on donor dendritic cells carried with the graft
- foreign HLA II molecule looks like self HLA + foreign peptide, activates D4
Describe the indirect pathway leading to chronic organ rejection

Dendritic cells infiltrate the graft, replace any donor antigen presenting cells
They process and present graft antigens in HLA II to CD4
Results in chronic rejction, both T cell and antibody mediated
Most renal transplant loss due to rejction occurs due to hyperacute, acute, or chronic rejection?
Chronic rejection
Name 3 steps taken when a donor and recipient are being evalualted for renal transplant

HLA typing of donor and recipient
No donor-specific anti-HLA antibodies in the recipient (regular screening while on waitlist)
Negative HLA serological crossmatch (mix donor lymphocytes and recipient serum - positive indicates recipient antibodies to donor HLA, would cause hyperacute rejection)
Is HLA typing done prior to all solid organ transplants?

Tends to be done for renal transplant, tends not to be done for others
This is due to small organ pool, urgeny, limited cold ischaemia time (organ needs to be transplanted urgently)
Just do HLA crossmatch instead
Can an ABO-incompatible kidney be transplanted? How?

Pre-conditioning with rituximab, plasma exchange, and immunosuppressives to remove recipient anti-ABO antibodies
Must be living donor
In the first year following solid organ transplant, what is the most common cause of death in patients with a functioning graft?
Cardiovascular
After the first year following solid organ transplant, what is the most common cause of death in patients with a functioning graft?
Cancer
What testing is done prior to haematopoietic stem cell transplant?

HLA typing
- closer match = improved graft survival, reduced graft vs host disease. Best to use complete match (all 6 types that are tested)
Test for absence of donor specific HLA antibodies
Which HLA types are routinely tested prior to transplants where HLA testing is required? (6)
HLA-A, -B, -C, -DRB1, -DQB1, -DPB1
T cell depletion to try to reduce graft vs host disease prior to haematopoietic cell transplant in leukaemia patients carries what major risk?
Risk of leukaemic recurrence
Describe the grades of graft vs host disease

Grade A: rash <25%, no liver or GIT

Describe vitamin D metabolism

Cholecalciferol is synthesised in the skin from 7-dehydrocholesterol in the presence of ultraviolet light
Hydrocylated to form 25-hydroxyvitamin D (aka calcidiol) by the hepatic enzyme 25-hydroxylase
Enters circulation bound by vitamin-D binding protein
Filtered by the glomerulus and reabsorbed by the tubule
Then either enters the 1-alpha-hydroxylase pathyway to become calcitriol (the active metabolite), or the 24-alpha-hydroxylase pathyway to become 24,25dihydroxyvitamin D (the inactive metabolite)
How does calcitriol act to increase plasma calcium? (3)

Increased intestinal absorption
- Enhanced apical intestinal calcium absorption by increased expression of transient receptor potential vanilloid 6 (TRPV6) and basolateral efflux via increased expression of PMCA1b
Bone resorption
Renal resorption
- Increased expression of TRPV5 and calbindin-D28k
Describe the regulation of calcitriol (3)

Regulated by PTH, serum calcium and phosphate, and FGF-23

In response to low calcium, PTH increases activity of 1-alpha-hydroxylase, thereby increasing production of calcitriol

Excessive rise in calcium is prevented by rise in calcitriol, as calcitriol has a negative feedback effect on the parathyroid, and directly inhibits 1-alpha-hydroxylase in the kidney
When is PTH secreted?

PTH is secreted in response to low serum calcium.
Change detected by calcium-sensing receptor (CaSR) on parathyroid cells
How does PTH act to increase calcium? (3)

Increased intestinal absorption
Bone resorption
Renal reabsorption
Describe how PTH promotes serum calcium increase through increased intestinal absorption
Promotes renal formation of calcitriol (1,25dihydroxylvitamin D), aka active vitamin D, which enhances intestinal calcium and phosphate absorption
Describe how PTH promotes calcium increase through bone resorption

Mobilises calcium stores readily available in extracellular fluid
Activates bone resorption by binding to PTH receptors on osteoblasts, which increase osteoclast activity and number and result in bone resorption.
Describe how PTH results in increased serum calcium through renal reabsorption

Increases active calcium reabsorption in the distal nephron. 
Activates adenylyl cylclase --> inceases cyclic adenosine monophosphate (AMP) levels --> stimulates protein kinase A --> protein kinase A phosphotylates and activates TRPV5 --> results in increased transceullular calcium transport. Also increases expression of calcium transport proteins TRPV5, calbindin D28k, NCX1, and PMCA1b.
Describe how PTH is regulated by negative feedback

Elevations in plasma calcium bind to CaSR on parathyroid glands - > lower PTH via negative feedback
Increase in calcitriol inhibits production and secretion of PTH.
Describe renal handlihng of calcium

99% of renally excreted calcium is reabsorbed
- 70% passively in conjunction with sodium in proximal tubule
- 20% passively in thick ascending loop of Henle via paracellular mechanism mediated by the tight junction protein claudin-16
- 10-15% actively in distal nephron via transcellular mechanism. Calcium enters tubular cells via transient reeptor protential vanilloid 5 (TRPV5) channel, expressed on the apical membrane of both distal convoluted tubule and connecting tubule cells. Inside the cell the calcium binds to calbindin-D28k protein, which takes it to the basolateral surface. It is then extruted into the circulation via two channels, NCX1 and PMCA1b.
What compound is required for intestinal calcium absorption?
Activated vitamin D (calcitriol)
Describe how calcium is absorbed in the GI tract (3)

Active transcellular pathway via transient receptor potential vanilloid 6  (TRPV6) channel on the apical membrane of the duodenum and the proximal jejunum
Paracellular calcium transport that occurs throughout the length of the intestine

Calcium combines with anions in the intestinal lumen to form insoluble salts (calcium phosphate, calcium oxalate) that are not absorbed. Thus not all dietary calcium is absorbed.

Vitamin D resistant rickets type 3 - CYP3A4 gain of function mutation, accelerated inactivation of vitamin D

Oral glucose tolerance test (gold standard)
- use only if fasting glucose 5.5 - 6.9, or random glucose 5.5 - 11, or pregnancy GDM screen
HbA1c > 6.5
Name 5 factors that may make HbA1c unreliable

Altered erythropoiesis (increased erythropoeisis will decrease HbA1c, reverse also true)
Altered haemoglobin
Glycation
Erythrocyte desctruction (increased lifespan = increase HbA1c, reverse also true)
Assays
When may HbA1c not be used to diagnose diabetes? (8)

Children and young people
Suspected type 1
Symptoms less than 2 months
Patients at high risk who are acutely ill
Patients on medications that cause rapid glucose rise (steroids, antipsychotics)
Acute pancreatic damage
Pregnancy
Presence of factors that make HbA1c unreliable (see other card)
Should pancreatic autoantibodies be routinely tested in new diagnoses of diabetes?

Yes, including older patients with presumed type 2
May have LADA
When is c peptide used for patients with new diabetes?

When there is uncertainty about type 1 vs type 2 (i.e. LADA is suspected)
Usually ordered together with pancreatic autoantibodies

C peptide will be lower in LADA, inducating less endogenous insulin production
What is Whipple's triad?

Hypoglycaemic symptoms
Documented low BSL at time of symptoms
Resolution of symptoms with restoration of normal glucose
What is this sign?

Pemberton's sign
This patient has a large retrosternal goitre
Name 5 investigations in a patient with a goitre

TFT
Thyroid antibodies
Thyroid ultrasound
+/- CT (do not give contrast if TSH is low - iodine load!)
+/- nuclear scan (if hyperthyroid)
What percentage of older patients will have a thyroid nodule on ultrasound?
Describe the approach to a thyroid nodule
Describe the investigations for hypothyroidism

TSH, T3, T4
Anti-TPO
Anti-thyroglobulin

Ultrasound or nuc med scan usually not required
Describe the investigations for hyperthyroidism (4)

TSH, T3, T4
TSH receptor antibodies
Anti TPO and anti-thyroglobulin antibodies
Thyroid nuclear scan (not needed if clinical features of Graves)
Biotin (vitamin B7) has what effect on thyroid function?

None, but it interfers with assays
May make the patient appear to have Grave's disease (but they don't)
Can affect TSH, T4, T3, TSH receptor antibodies
Effect goes away after 3 days
Describe the investigations required after finding an incidental adrenal mass

Aldosterone-renin ratio (Conn syndrome)
24hr urine catecholamines +/- plasma metanephrins (Pheochromocytoma)
1mg dexamethasone suppression test (Cushing's)
If all normal, repeat adrenal CT in 6 months and 12 months
Describe Conn's syndrome

Primary (nonsuppressible) hypersecretion of aldosterone
Presents with hypertension and hypokalaemia (salt retaining, potassium wasting)
May be due to aldosterone producing adenoma, bilateral adrenal hyperplasia, or rarely familial hyperaldosteronism
What investigations should be ordered in suspected Conn's syndrome? (6)

Serum K (low)
Aldosterone (normal or high)
Renin (low)
Aldosterone:renin ratio (high)
Aldosterone suppression test (oral sodium load, measure urine aldosterone) - does not suppress
CT adrenals
When should adrenal vein sampling be considered in a patient with Conn's syndrome (primary hyperaldosteronism)?

CT adrenals is normal
Bilateral CT abnormalities
Unliateral abnormality but age > 35

AVS done to confirm unilateral disease, so can pursue surgical management
Name 4 drugs that interfere with testing for primary hyperaldosteronism (Conn syndrome)?

Minteralocorticoid receptor antagonists (spironolactone)
ACE inhibitors
ARBs
Direct renin inhibitors
Describe Addison's disease

Primary adrenal insufficiency - failure of adrenals to produce cortisol
High ACTH, low cortisol
Describe 2 investigations used in suspected Addison's disease

ACTH stimulation test: cortisol will not rise with ACTH being given (note secondary and tertiary adrenal insufficency also tend not to respond due to atrophy of adrenals)
Insulin induced hypoglycaemia test - contraindicated if seizures or cardiovascular disease. Hypoglycaemia is induced and cortisol stress response is recorded.
Describe the causes of Addison's disease

70-90% autoimmune
Remainder due to infection, malignancy, adrenal haemorrhage/infarction, or drugs
What is the next test that should be ordered in a patient with low testosterone?
FSH, LH (to distinguish primary vs secondary hypogonadism)
What is the effect of the oral contraceptive pill on LH and FSH
They will be low
What are the 2 best screening tests for Cushing's?

24hr urinary free cortisol
Overnight 1mg dexamethasone suppression test
A patient presents with high cortisol which does not suppress with low dose dexamethasone. Describe the investigations that should be done next (3)

Patient may have Cushing's

ACTH
- if <1, ACTH independent (adrenal source)
- if >65, ACTH dependent (pituitary (most common) or ectopic ACTH cause)
- if 1 - 65, usually ACTH dependent
Consider high dose dexamethasone suppression test
Consider pituitary MRI
How can crush fractures confound DEXA scans?

BMD may be falsely elevated due to crush fractures making the bone look denser
Do plain XR to check for this if discordant spine/hip results
What would be the expected effect on bone turnover markers (P1NP, CTx) in patients on antiresorptive therapy for osteoporosis?
Supressed
Which is the 'active' thyroid hormone, T3 or T4?
T3
What is the effect of acute illness on thyroid function?

Non-thyroidal illness syndrome
Result sin low T3
More severe illness results in low T4 and TSH
Treatment is not required
Should exclude pituitary disease if TSH, T3, and T4 all low
Name 3 T cell mediated autoimmune thyroid diseases

Hashimoto's
Idiopathic hypothyroidism
Lymphocytic and postpartum thyroiditis
Name 3 features of Grave's disease that are relatively specific to the disease (as opposed to the usual signs and symptoms of hyperthyroidism)

Graves ophthalmopathy
Pretibial myxoedema
Thyroid acropachy (clubbing)
Describe the disease course of Graves disease (5)

Relapsing remitting
25% will spontaneously remit
50% will remit with conservative treatment
Once in remission, 25% will recur, 25% will become hypothyroid
Untreated mortality 11 - 50%
What antibody is seen in Graves' disease, and how does it cause disease?

Thyroid-stimulating hormone (TSH, thyrotropin)-receptor antibodies (TRAb) 
These activate the receptor, thereby stimulating thyroid hormone synthesis and secretion as well as thyroid growth
What is chemosis?
Oedema of the conjunctiva
Name 3 possible treatments for graves disease

Antithyroid drugs
Radioiodine ablation
Surgery
Describe the initial management of Graves' disease in younger patients with small goitres

Antithyroid drugs are first line for first time presentations
- Particularly in young patients with small goitre
After 12-18 months and stable on treatment, wean and cease to see if remission has occured
Describe the initial management of Graves' disease in patients with large goitres with obstructive symptoms

Commence antithryoid drugs to achieve euthyroidism
Then surgery
If not fit for surgery, radioactive iodine may be used instead
Describe the management of recurrent or severe Graves' disease

Antithyroid treatment until euthyroid
Then either radioactive iodine or surgery
Describe the management of Graves' disease in older patients

Initial antithryoid therapy
Followed by radioiodine
What is the antithyroid drug of choice in Graves' disease?
Carbimazole
Describe the management of Graves' disease in pregnancy (5)

Propylthiouracil before conception and in first trimester
Then switch to carbimazole
If hyperthyroidism is difficult to control after the first trimester, requiring high carbimazole dose, consider surgery
Be aware high risk of postpartum recurrence
Block-replace therapy is contraindicated in pregnancy
Describe the relationship between Graves' eye disease and the use of radioactive iodine

Radioactive iodine should NOT be used in moderate or severe orbitopathy
Can exacerbate eye disease
Describe the symptomatic management of Graves' disease

Propranolol
If beta blockers contraindicated:
Diltiazem
Describe the toxicities of carbimazole (4)

Rash (10%)
Foetal abnormalities in 1st trimester
Agranulocytosis (0.4%) - sudden, acute, and idiosyncratic (no monitoring)
- Patients should stop drug if coryza or unexplained fever
Mild neutropenia
Describe gestational hyperthyroidism (3)

bHCG is similar to TSH, has TSH activity
Causes a mild hyperthyroidism that self-resolves as bHCG drops after the 1st trimester
Usually no teatment required
Describe the investigation findings in Graves' disease (2)

Low TSH, high T3, normal T4
Radioiodine scan: diffuse increased uptake
Describe toxic multinodular goitre (5)

Result of focal and/or diffuse hyperplasia of thyroid follicular cells whose functional capacity is independent of regulation by TSH
Women > men
Onset age > 50
Nodular goitre often present for years
Hyperthyroidism may be after iodine load e.g. contrast
Describe the investigation results in toxic multinodular goitre

T3 > T4
Thyroid uptake scan: normal or multifocal uptake
Describe the management of toxic multinodular goitre

Radioactive iodine is first line
Surgery for compressive symptoms, large goitre, or coexisting other indication (e.g. cancer)
Occasionally long term low dose carbimazole is needed
Describe hyperthyroidism due to toxic adnoma (4)

Somatic activating mutation of TSH receptor gene or of signal transduction gene (G protein gene)
Female > male
Onset age 30 - 50
Slow growing solitary nodule, usually >3cm
Describe the management of toxic thyroid adenoma

Radioactive iodine is first line
Remission is rare without definitive treatment.
Describe the investigation results in toxic thyroid adenoma (2)

T3 > T4
Radionuclide scan: focal uptake with suppression of surrounding thyroid uptake
Describe the difference between T3 and T4 hyperthyroidism

T3 toxicosis: high T3, normal T4. Seen in Graves' and toxic multinodular goitre.
T4 toxicosis: high T4, normal T3. Seen in nonthyroidal illnesss that decreases extrathyroidal conversion of T4 to T3, and in amiodarone-induced hyperthyroidism
Name 3 risk factors for gestational thyrotoxicosis

Anything that is associated with higher bHCG, such as
- twin pregnancy
- molar pregnancy
- hyperemesis gravidarum
Describe TSH dependent hyperthyroidism

High TSH, high T3 and T4
Very rare
Due to TSH secreting pituitary adenoma or partial resistance to feedback from T3/T4
Describe the expected findings in factitious hyperthyroidism (3)

Low TSH, normal or high T4 and/or T3 (levothyroxine is T4)
Low serum thyroglobulin
24hr radioiodine uptake scan: nearly absent uptake
Describe struma ovarii

A teratoma of thyroid tissue
5% of ovarian teratomas
A rare differential for women with hyperthyroidism without goitre who have minimal/absent uptake on radioiodine scan (this is usually due to exogenous thyroxine intake or thyroiditis)
Can be benign or malignant
Describe how one may differentiate between exogenous thyroid hormone use and struma ovarii

Both will have low TSH, high T3 and/or T4, no goitre, and low/absent neck radioiodine uptake
- exogenous use will have low thyroglobulin
- struma ovarii will have normal thyroglobulin
Describe the investigation findings in amiodarone-induced thyrotoxicosis (4)

Low TSH, disproportionately high T4 compared to T3
Thyroglobulin and IL-6 may be elevated in type 2 (but overlap)
Radioiodine scan: low uptake
Ultrasound: normal or increased vascularity in type 1, diminished or absent in type 2
Describe type 1 and 2 amiodarone-induced thyrotoxicosis

Type 1: increased thyroid hormone synthesis due to iodine load
Type 2: destructive thyroiditis
Describe the management of amiodarone induced thyrotoxicosis type 1

Antithyroid drugs (carbimazole)
Stop amiodarone unless life-threatening indication

If normal TSH with high T4, no treatment
Describe the management of amiodarone induced thyrotoxicosis type 2

Prednisolone 40 - 50mg daily
Stop amiodarone unless life-threatening indication

If high T4 but normal TSH, no treatment required
In many patients with amiodarone induced hyperthyroidism, differentiating between type 1 and 2 can be difficult. Describe the management approach in this group.

Carbimazole and prednisolone
If rapid response (50% T4 fall in 2 weeks), is type 2 - stop carbimazole, continue prednisolone. Otherwise, do the reverse.
Stop amiodarone unless life-threatening indication
Surgery if deteriorates despite therapy
Describe the management of subclinical hyperthyroidism

If TSH < 0.1 and persists, treat.
- antithyroids if subclinical Graves' and young
- radioiodine for older patient with multinodular goitre
Does subclinical hyperthyroidism have risk of long-term adverse effects?
Yes - progression to overt disease, osteoporosis, atrial fibrillation, heart failure.
Describe 6 clinical features of thyroid storm

Fever
Tachycardia/arrythmia (e.g. rapid AF)
Proximal myopathy and tremor
Nausea, abdo pain, jaundice
Dehydration, shock
Coma/seizure/delirium
End organ dysfunction - often hepatic
Name 5 factors which may precipitate thyroid storm

Infection
Trauma
Surgery (especially thyroid)
Radioiodine (rare)
Poor compliance with antithyroid drugs

May or may not have a history of thyrotoxicosis
Describe the management of thyroid storm (7)

HDU or ICU

Propylthiouracil (PO or rectal) to block synthesis, AND
Lugol solution to block hormone release
Consider adding dexamethasone
Consider adding cholestyramine (to increase T4 clearance)

Control tachycardia with:
propranolol or esmolol

Plasmapheresis if desparate
Plan for thyroidectomy when stable
Describe subclinical hypothyroidism (4)

Raised TSH (<10) and normal T3/T4
2.6% progress to hypothyroidism per year
Do not treat if TSH < 10, unless pregnant or planning pregnancy (in which case treat TSH > 4)
Check antibodies to predict progression
Describe myxoedema coma (4)

Severe hypothyroidism leading to slowing of function in multiple organs
It is a medical emergency with a high mortality rate (40%)
Hallmarks: decreased mental status, hypothermia. 
Often with hypotension, bradycardia, hyponatraemia, hypoglycaemia, hypoventilation
Describe the treatment of myxedema coma (3)

Thyroid hormone (T4/levothyroxine and T3/liothyronine) IV
High dose glucocorticoids
ICU and supportive measures
Describe subacute thyroiditis (5)

Probably a post-viral syndrome, often follows URTI
Destruction of thyroid follicles and release of stored thyroid hormone
HLAB35 positive in 75%
Female: male 5:1
Onset 20 - 60
Describe the clinical presentation of subacute thyroiditis

Neck pain, radiating up to the jaw
Tender diffuse goitre
Hyperthyroidism for 1-2 months, then hypothyroidism for 4 - 6 months (permanent hypothryoid in 10%)
Describe the investigation findings in subacute thyroiditis (3)

Low TSH < 0.1, raised T3/T4
Low uptake on radiodine uptake scan
High ESR, CRP
Describe the management of subacute thyroiditis (4)

NSAID or aspirin for pain relief
Prednisolone 40mg/day if no relief with above, or if severe pain
Beta blockers if troublesome hyperthyroid symptoms
Thyroxine replacement in hypothyroid phase if symptomatic

No role for antithyroid drugs or radioactive iodine (thyroiditis results in release of preformed hormone)
Describe postpartum thyroiditis (3)

Autoimmune process, destruction of thyroid follicles with release of preformed hormone
1 - 6 months after delivery
More common in type 1 diabetics, patients with positive antithyroid peroxxidase antibodies, and who have had it before
Describe the clinical findings in postpartum thyroiditis (3)

Diffuse, small goitre
Painless
Classic pattern: hyperthyroid for 1-2 months, followed by hypothyroid for 4 - 6 months; hypothyroid permanent in 20%
- may have only hyperthyroid or only hypothyroid phase
Describe the investigation results in postpartum thyroiditis (4)

Hyperthyroid pattern if hyperthyroid phase, hypothyroid pattern in hypothyroid phase
Radionuclide thyroid scan: near absent uptake
TPO antibody high tire positive, anti-Tg positive
Normal ESR
If biopsy: lymphocytic infiltrate
Describe the management of postpartum thyroiditis (2)

Betablocker if symptomatic of hyperthyroidism (propranolol preferred)
Thyroxine in hypothyroid phase if symptomatic, breastfeeding, or trying to conceive
Define Hashimoto's thyroiditis
Gradual thyroid failure, with or without goitre, due to autoimmune-mediated destruction of the thyroid gland and apoptosis of thyroid epithelial cells
Describe the biopsy findings in Hashimoto's thyroiditis
Lymphocytic infiltration and follicular destruction
Name 2 autoantibodies one would expect to be positive in Hashimoto's thyroiditis
High tire anti-thyroid peroxidase (anti-TPO) and anti-thyroglobulin (anti-Tg)
Describe the usual clinical course in Hashimoto's thyroiditis
Gradual loss of thyroid function
In patients with Hashimoto's thyroiditis, is hypothyroidism typically permanent or transient?
Permanent
Describe the pathogenesis of Hashimoto's thyroiditis (6)

Starting point is not known - may be molecular mimicry or bystander activation

Once started:
B cells secrete anti-thyroid antibodies
T cells react with processed thyroid antigens, then secrete cytokines to activate other immune cells
- Th2 get involved with antibody production
- Th1 cytotoxic T cells cause apoptotic destruction of thyroid cells
- T cells regulate the local immune response
Describe the concept of molecular mimicry

Foreign antigen shares similar structure to 'self' substance
Anti-foreign response cross-reacts with self
e.g. rheumatic fever and streptococcal infection, reactive arthritis, narcolepsy after H1N1 fluvax
Describe the concept of bystander activation with regards to immunology

Anti-self T cells usually tolerised by presentation of self-antigen by immature tolerogenic dendritic cells (that do not express B7 so cannot co-stimulate and produce a response)
Infection engages innate immunoreceptors and stimulates B7 expression
--> activation of self-reactive T cells
What is the most common cause of hypothyroidism in iodine-sufficient areas?
Hashimoto's thyroiditis
Name the 2 forms of Hashimoto's thyroiditis, and how they differ

Goitrous
Atrophic

Different degree of lymphocytic infiltration, fibrosis, and thyroid follicuylar cell hyperplasia
Same pathophysiology
At what rate do patients with subclinical hypothyroidism and thyroid antibodies progress to overt hypothyroidism?
5% per year
Name 4 risk factors for Hashimoto's thyroiditis

Female
Age
Personal or family history of autoimmune phenomena (e.g. type 1 diabetes)
High iodine intake
Describe Hashimoto encephalopathy (5)

Thought to be due to autoimmune vasculitis, not due to thyroid disease
Heterogenous presentation - fulminant, subacute, or chronic course of declining mental status, with seizures and myoclonus
Positive anti-TPO, other findings nonspecific
Manage with trial of corticosteroid
Majority have good outcome
Describe painless thyroiditis (6)

A varient of Hashimoto's thyroiditis
Autoimmune destructoin of thyroid follicles, release of preformed thyroid hormone
Female > male
Age 20 - 50
Nonpainful, diffuse small goiter
Hyperthyroidism 1-2 months, followed by hypothyroid 4- 6 months, then recovery (permanent hypothyroid 20%)
Describe the investigation findings in painless thyroiditis (5)

Hyperthyroid phase, then hypothyroid phase
Anti-TPO positive high titre
Normal ESR
Very low uptake on radioiodine uptake scan
Reduced flow on doppler ultrasound
Describe the management of painless thyroiditis (2)

Betablocker if hyperthryoid symptoms
Thyroxine if prolonged or symptomatic hypothyroid phase
What percentage of clinically apparent thyroid nodules are malignant?
What percentage of 'hot' thyroid nodules are malignant?
Name 4 types of thyroid cancer

Papillary (80%)
Follicular
- includes Hurthle cell
Medullary
Anaplastic
Name the 3 types of thyroid follicular epithelial-derived cancers

Papillary
Follicular
Anaplastic
Name 7 features suggestive of malignancy on thyroid nodule ultrasoudn

TI-RADS score

Three points:
Very hypoechoic
Taller-than-wide
Extrathyroid extension
Punctate echogenic foci

Two points:
Solid (rather than cystic or mixed)
Lobulated or irregular margins
Peripheral calcifications

>4 points = biopsy
Describe how size impacts on the management of thyroid nodule (4)

<1cm: repeat evaluation in 6 - 12 months
- if increase by 30% volume or 10% diameter, biopsy
>2cm: FNA (if not cyst or spongioform)
In between: assess characteristics on ultrasound (TI-RADS score)

Do not biopsy a hot nodule, regardless of the above.
Differentiated thyroid cancer (papillary and follicular) are associated with what mutations? (4)

Mutations in the mitogen-activated protein kinase (MAPK) pathway
- RET/PTC
- NTRK1
- RAS
- BRAF

Present in up to 70% of patients
Describe the management of thyroid cancer (5)

Total thyroidectomy
Remnant ablation with radioiodine (I131) 
+/- adjuvant radiotherapy if high risk
Levothyroxine to replace thyroid hormone and to suppress TSH
Surveillance with thyroglobulin measurement
Retreat with radioactive iodine if recurrence
TKI therapy (serafenib, vandetinib, lenvatinib) or BRAF inhibitors (venurafenib, dabrafenib) are showing promise when radioactive iodine resistant

If young and tumour < 4cm and no nodal mets, can consider partial thyroidectomy
Name 3 poor prognostic factors in papillary thyroid cancer

Age
Larger tumour
Soft tissue invasion
What 2nd agent should be chosen for blood pressure control in patients with diabetes?

Calcium channel blocker (e.g. amlodipine)
Superior to hydrochlorothiazide

(the 1st agent will be ACE or ARB)
When should patients with diabetes take their antihypertensive(s)?
At least one of them should be taken in the evening - reduces cardiovascular event rate
Name 4 lifestyle measures to reduce lipids in patients with diabetes

Reduce saturated fat, trans fat, cholesterol intake
Increase omega 3, viscous fiber, plant sterols
Weight loss
Exercise, break up sedentary time
Does fenofibrate decrease cardiovascular events in diabetes (in addition to a statin)?

Not in all patients
Does if high triglycerides and low HDL
Which diabetic patients should be on a statin for primary prevention of cardiovascular disease?

All of them, regardless of lipid profile

Except age <40 and no risk factors
In patients with diabetes who have inadequate lipid control on a statin, what agent can be added to improve outcomes?

Ezetimibe
Reduces risk of cardiovascular events, in addition to statin (primary prevention)
What is an appropriate blood pressure target in patients with diabetes?

At least < 130
Differing evidence on if < 120 improves outcomes (SPRINT trial in nondiabetes showed improvements, but trial in diabetics did not)
Does aspirin have a role in primary prevention of cardiovascular disease in diabetes?

No, not routinely

Can be considered in patients that are high risk (e.g. smoker, microalbuminuria, family history)
In diabetic patients with known cardiovascular disease, what medications should be used to prevent events? (4)

ACE inhibitor
Statin
Aspirin
If prior myocardial infarction: beta blocker for at least 2 years
Give 2 examples of GLP1 agonists

Exenatide
Liraglutide
Describe the actions of glucacon-like peptide 1 (GLP1) (5)

GLP1 is an incretin
Produced from the proglucagon gene in L-cells of the small intestine and is secreted in response to nutrients
Binds to GLP-1 receptor in various tissues, including pancreatic beta cells, stimulating glucose-dependent insulin release
Also slows gastric emptying, inhibits glucacon, reduces food intake
Degraded by dipeptidyl peptidase-4 (DPP-4)
Describe the action of dipeptidyl peptidase-4 (DPP-4)
Enzyme that degrades glucagon-like peptide (GLP1)
Name 3 DPP4 inhibitors

Linagliptin
Saxagliptin
Sitagliptin
Describe the mechanism of action of DPP4 inhibitors (4)

Inhibit DPP4, which breaks down glucagon like peptide 1 (GLP1) and gastric inhibitory polypeptide (GIP)
Results increased concentration of these incretins, therefore more insulin release and less glucagon secretion
Do DPP4 inhibitors (gliptins) improve cardiovascular outcomes in type 2 diabetes, in addition to conventional glucose-lowering therapy?
No
Do SGLT2 inhibitors improve cardiovascular outcomes in type 2 diabetes, in addition to conventional blood glucose control?

Yes - EMPA-REG study
14% lower CV death, nonfatal MI, or nonfatal stroke
32% lower mortality
35% less hospitalisaion for heart failure

40% reduction in renal complications as well in a similar trial
Do GLP1 agonists improve cardiovascular outcomes in type 2 diabetes, in addition to conventional blood glucose control?
Yes - LEADER study, SUSTAIN study
Name 2 glucose-lowering medications that, in addition to standard blood sugar control, improve cardiovascular outcomes in type 2 diabetes

SGLT2 inhibitors (e.g. empagliflozin) (also improve renal outcomes)
GLP1 agonists (e.g. exenatide)
What is the best indicator of chronic kidney disease in diabetes?

eGFR

Microalbuminuria is highly variable - can have albuminuria without CKD, can have CKD without albuminuria
Does tight glycaemic control in type 2 diabetes improve renal outcomes?

Yes, HR 0.54
ADVANCE-ON trial
Which patients with type 1 or 2 diabetes should be on ACE or ARB to prevent renal disease/prevent progression of renal disease?

Patients with hypertension and any degree of albuminuria (including macroalbuminuria)
Slows progression of nephropathy
What monitoring for chronic kidney disease is recommended in all diabetics?
Yearly eGFR/creatinine, urinary albumin excretion, potassium
Name 9 interventions in diabetes that improve outcomes in terms of primary prevention of complications

Lifestyle modifications, smoking cessation
Intensive BSL control
ACE if hypertensive (to prevent CVS disease)
ACE if hypertension and any degree of albuminuria (to prevent renal disease)
Statin for all patients (unless age < 40 and no risk factors)
- Add ezetimibe if inadequate control on statin
- Add fenofibrate if high triglycerides and low HDL
SGLT2 inhibitor
GLP1 agonist
Does intensive multifactorial intervention in diabetes (ACE, statin, intensive BSL control, lifestyle, etc) improve outcomes in diabetes?
Yes, improvement in complications and mortality
What is the effect of ACE inhibitors on the afferent and efferent arterioles of the glomerulus?
Decrease efferent arteriolar tone (it dilates)
What medication is derived from this guy?

This is a Gila monster!
Exenatide (GLP1 agonist) is derived from its saliva
Name 2 sulfonylureas

Gliclazide
Glimepiride
What is the mechanism of action of sulfonylureas?
Increase insulin secretion via the pancreatic sulfonylurea receptor
0ff0fef4c1c44b109e8fbd79b7dc13bd-ao-1
0ff0fef4c1c44b109e8fbd79b7dc13bd-ao-2
0ff0fef4c1c44b109e8fbd79b7dc13bd-ao-3
0ff0fef4c1c44b109e8fbd79b7dc13bd-ao-4
0ff0fef4c1c44b109e8fbd79b7dc13bd-ao-5
0ff0fef4c1c44b109e8fbd79b7dc13bd-ao-6
0ff0fef4c1c44b109e8fbd79b7dc13bd-ao-7
Give the equation for calculating incidence from carrier frequency for autosomal recessive disorders

Incidence = 4 x (carrier frequency)2

Example:
Friedreich ataxia has carrier frequency of 1/100
100 squared = 10,000
10,000 x4 = 40,000
Incidence is 1 in 40,000
Give the equation for calculating carrier frequency from incidence for autosomal recessive disorders

Carrier frequency = square root of (Incidence/4)

Example
The incidence of cystic fibrosis = 1 in 2,500 Caucasians
2500/4 = 625
Square root of 625 = 25
Carrier frequency = 1 in 25
What is the Hardy-Weinberg equation? Give an example on how to use it for cystic fibrosis.

p+ 2pq+ q = 1
Where:
p is the indicence of allele 1
q is the incidence of allele 2
2pq is the frequency of the carrier state

Example:
Let q be the gene for cystic fibrosis, and p be the normal gene

For CF the frequency of qq in northern Europeans = 1 in 2500

     q2=1/2500

     q = 1/50
     
     Since the sum of the alleles   q + p = 1 , p = 1 - q

     p= 49/50

     Carrier frequency = 2pq= 2*(49/50)(1/50) = 98/2500 =.04
Describe the action of ADH (4)

Secreted by the posterior pituitary
Results in V2 receptor mediated aquaporin insertion 
Aquaporin in distal convoluted tubule
Increased free water reabsorption, concentrated urine, lower serum sodium (due to water reabsoprtion)
How is serum osmolality calculated
(2 x serum Na) + glucose + urea
What is the osmolar gap

osmolar gap = osmolality (measured) - osmolality (calculated)

>10 is abnormal and indicates presence of extra osmotically active particles (i.e. other than sodium, glucose, and urea)
e.g. glycine post TURP, mannitol post IVIG
What are the 4 most common causes of severe hyponatraemia (<120)?

Thiazide/indapamide (41%)
SIADH (38%)
- 70% medication related, 40% psychotropics
Hypovolaemia (24%)
Alcohol (11%)
Patients with hyponatraemia should not be rapidly corrected to avoid what complication?

Osmotic demyelination syndrome
- occurs if there is rapid correction and the hyponatraemia had been present >2 days, as the brain has adapted to the hypotonicity
- higher risk at lower Na levels
How quickly can hyponatraemia be corrected, keeping in mind risk of osmotic demyelination syndrome?

Aim to correct by 4-6mmol/L per 24hrs
Maximum is 10mmol per 24hrs
Only correct more rapidly if definitely known to be <48hrs since onset
Name 15 drugs that can cause hyponatraemia

Thiazides
Indapamide
Loop diuretics

Omeprazole

ACEi, ARB
Amlodipine

Carbamazepine

SSRI
TCA
MAOI

Opiates
NSAID

Cyclophosphamide
Haloperidol
Amitriptyline
How do thiazides result in hyponatraemia? (3)

Sodium and potassium loss
Stimulation of thirst
Impaired urinary dilution
Name 5 drugs or drug classes that cause hyponatraemia by stimulated ADH release

Carbemazepine
SSRIs
TCAs
MAOIs
Opiates
Name 2 drugs or drug classes that cause hyponatreaemia by potentiating the action of ADH in the kidneys

NSAIDs
Cyclophosphamide
Name 7 investigations that may be ordered for a patient with hyponatraemia

Glucose
Lipids
Cortisol
Thyroid function
LFT
Paired urine and sodium osmolality
Urine Na and K
Name 3 causes of hypertonic or isotonic hyponatreaemia (osmolality > 275)

Hyperglycaemia
Hyperproteinaemia (pseudohyponatraemia)
Hyperlipidaemia (pseudohyponatraemia)
Describe hyperglycaemia induced dilutional hyponatraemia

A type of hypertonic hyponatraemia
Omolality typically > 290
High blood sugar causes water to move out of cells via osmosis, expanding extracellular fluid volume -> dilutional hyponatraemia
Describe how sodium level can be corrected for hyperglycaemia

Decrease sodium by 2mmol/L for every 5.5mmol/L increase in BSL

Simple version: divide BSL by 3 and add to sodium

e.g. Na = 120, BSL = 60
120 + 20 
true sodium = 140 (normal!)
How can hyperlipidaemia and hyperproteinaemia result in pseudohyponatraemia?

Lab error - different proportion to usual for lipids and protein stuffs up the lab equation
Can circumvent by doing VBG which does not use this formula
Most causes of hyponatraemia are hypotonic, isotonic, or hypertonic?
Hypotonic (90%)
What does a low urinary sodium usually mean about the patient's circulating volume, in patients with hypotonic hyponatraemia?

Low circulating volume
Body is conserving sodium to increase intravascular volume

Can occur if diarrhoea, sweating, vomiting, other losses
Can occur if deficiency in intravascular volume/high extravascular fluid in CCF, cirrhosis, nephrotic syndrome
What does a high urinary sodium (>20) usually indicate in patients with hypotonic hyponatraemia?

Implies presence of ADH causing water reabsorption

e.g.
SIADH
Diuretics, renal failure, cerebral salt wasting, hypocortisolaemia (Addisonian crisis)
Name 3 causes of hypovolaemic hyponatraemia with low urinary sodium

These patients have low sodium due to low fluid state/low circulating volume, and they are appropriately retaining sodium (low urine sodium) to try to retain fluid and increase intravascular volume

e.g.
GI losses
Excessive sweating
Third spacing (burns, bowel obstruction, pancreatitis, trauma)
Name 4 causes of hypovolaemic hyponatraemia with high urinary sodium (>20)

These patients have low sodium due to low volume with inappropriate ADH mediated water reabsorption

e.g.
Diuretics (thiazides)
Salt-losing nephropathy
Cerebral salt wasting syndrome
Hypocortisolaemia (Addison's crisis)
In patients with hypotonic hypovolaemic hyponatraemia, by how much should 1 litre of normal saline increase the sodium?
1L = 1mmol/L increase in sodium
Name 3 causes of hypotonic hypervolaemic hyponatraemia with low urinary sodium (<20)

These patients have intravscular volume depletion despite overall too much water, resulting in dilutional hyponatraemia and low tonicity
Low urine sodium as they try to retain it to increase circulating volume

e.g.
Heart failure
Cirrhosis
Nephrotic syndrome

Management is treatment of underlying cause
Name 2 causes of hypotonic hypervolaemic hyponatraemia with high urinary sodium (>20)

Diuretics (early)
Renal failure - nephrogenic SIADH
Describe the management of hypotonic hypervolaemic hyponatraemia

Treat underlying cause (e.g. heart failure, cirrhosis)
Fluid restrict
+/- diuresis
+/- conc albumin (if cirrhosis)
Describe the renin-angiotensin system (7)

Renin is synthesised in juxtaglomerular cells
Secreted in response to renal hypoperfusion
Renin cleaves angiotensin I from angiotensinogen
ACE catalyses conversion of angiotensin I to angiotensin II (mostly in the lung)
Angiotensin II causes arteriolar vasoconstriction and sodium reabsorption by the kidney
Aldosterone is secreted from the adrenal cortex in response to angiotensin II
Aldosterone binds to mineralocorticoid receptors, causing salt and water retention and potassium secretion

Describe the actions of aldosterone

Secreted by the adrenal cortex in response to angiotensin II
Binds to minteralocorticoid receptors
--> increases the expression of epithelial sodium channels in the distal tubule, causing salt and water retention, potassium wasting
Describe secondary hyperaldosteronism

Occurs in chronic low effective arterial blood volume states, e.g. CCF, cirrhosis, CKD
Instead of normal attenuation of effect of aldosterone (salt/water retaning, potassium wasting), the effect continues
Name 4 causes of hypotonic euvolaemic hyponatraemia with low urinary sodium

Water intoxication (psychogenic, NMDA use, marathons)
Poor solute intake (malnutrition - ETOH dependance, elderly on tea and toast diet)
Hypothyroid (very rare)
Hypotonic fluid infusion
Name 2 causes of hypotonic euvolaemic hyponatraemia with high urinary sodium

SIADH
Nonosmotic physiological ADH release (stress, pain, nausea)
Name 5 criteria for SIADH

SIADH is a diagnosis of exclusion where:

Euvolaemic
Low serum osmolality < 275
High urine osmolality > 100
High urine sodium >20
Inappropriately concentrated urine for serum osmolality
Name 10 causes of SIADH

CNS disturbance (any; e.g. stroke, haemorrhage, infection, trauma, psychosis)
Malignancy with ectopic ADH production (e.g. SCLC)
Drugs (e.g. carbamazepine, cyclophosphamide)
Surgery
Pulmonary disease (e.g. pneumonia, asthma, atelectasis, acute respiratory failure, pneumothorax)
Hypopituitarism and hypothyroidism
Hormone administration (oxytocin, vasopressin)
HIV
Hereditary
Idiopathic
Name 5 symptoms of slow onset (chronic) hyponatraemia
Fatigue, nausea, dizziness, gait disturbance, confusion
Name 4 symptoms or signs of sudden onset hyponatraemia (acute)

Obtundation
Seizure
Coma
Respiratory arrest
Describe the management of hyponatraemia where duration is unknown, not severe or symptomatic (4)

Aim to raise sodium by 4-6mmol per 24hrs
Treat underlying cause
Give normal saline if hypovolaemic
Fluid restrict if SIADH or hypervolaemia
Describe the management of symptomatic or severe hyponatraemia (5)

Move to HDU
Consider hypertonic saline
- 2ml/kg 3% saline IV over 15min (raises sodium by 2-3mmol/L)
- assess response and repeat at 20min
- aim to increase by 4-6mmol over 2-3hrs (avoids cerebral oedema; still need to correct less than 10mmol per 24hrs)
- recheck every 2-4hrs
Name 3 risk factors for osmotic demyelination syndrome

Lower serum sodium < 115
Rapid correction >12mmol/24hrs
ETOH use
What is the test of choice for osmotic demyelination syndrome (central pontine demyelination)

MRI brain

May not be present on initial scans
Describe the presentation of osmotic demyelination syndrome (5)

Confusion
Seizure
Drowsiness
Pseudobulbar palsy
Tetraparesis
When is onset of symptoms of osmotic demyelination syndrome typically seen?
Delayed onset; 2 - 6 days after presentation
A patient with hyponatraemia has overrapid correction of their sodium by 14mmol/L in 24hrs. What can be done to reduce risk of osmotic demyelination syndrome?

Relower the sodium 
- give dextrose infusion (based on case reports only) ,or
- desmopression
Describe the use of vasopression receptor antagonists

Selective V2 receptor antagonists (tolvaptan, conivaptan)
Can be used in treatment of hypervolaemic or euvolaemic hyponatraemia
Very expensive, poor side effect profile, can cause overrapid correction
What percentage of HIV patients are diagnosed late (CD4 count <350)?
What percentage of HIV patients have advanced disease at diagnosis (CD4 < 200)
What percentage of patients with HIV in Australia have undetectable viral load?
Describe the differences between HIV 1 and HIV 2

Different area affected: HIV 1 worldwide, HIV 2 in West Africa and Europe
HIV1: higher viral load, faster disease progression, lower CD4 counts, faster replication rate
HIV2: resistant to all NNRTIs, many PIs, and T-20
Describe the life cycle of HIV (7)

Binding: binds to CD4 and one of to co-receptors, CXCR4 or CCR5
Fusion: fuses with the host cell and release RNA into it
Reverse transcription: single stranded RNA is converted to HIV DNA by reverse transcriptase
Integration: HIV DNA enters the nucleus, integrase (an enzyme) cuts the cell's DNA and inserts HIV DNA
Transcription and translation: RNA polymerase makes RNA copies of DNA. HIV RNA is inserted into new virus particles or processed and translated into HIV proteins.
Assembly: gag molecules, viral RNA, and envelope proteins are packaged into the growing virus that buds off from the host cell
Release and maturation: viral protease cleaves the gag molecules into individual functional proteins. Mature virus can now infect other cells.

Which cells are the primary reservoir of HIV?
Memory cells
What is the effect of HIV infection on lymphoid tissue?

Leads to progressive fibrosis and marked CD4 depletion
Persists despite ART
What is the significance of delta32 mutation in CCR5 in HIV patients?

32 base pair deletion within the coding region results in frameshift, generates a nonfunctioning receptor
This receptor is required for HIV to bind to CD4 cells (is a co-binding site)
Present in 10% of europeans, absent in blacks and Japanese
Confers resistance to HIV1 if homozygous (1% of Europeans)
Describe 3 mutations/HLA types that confer resistance to HIV

delta32 mutation in CCR5
HLA B57 (protective early)
HLAB27 (protective late)
Name 1 HLA subtype that confers susceptibility to HIV
HLAB3503
When should antiretrovirals be commenced for patients in HIV?
At diagnosis
Describe immune activation in HIV (3)

Immune activation is associated with increased morbidity and mortality, poor CD4 recovery
Associated with atherosclerosis
Immune activation is also seen in HIV controllers and elite controllers
Can be reduced with ART
What are the benefits of early ART in HIV patients? (3)

Reduce AIDS diagnosis/disease progression/opportunistic infections/death
Reduced immune activation
Reduce HIV reservoir
When is the reservoir established in HIV?
During initial acute infection (first 30 days)
Describe the story of the Berlin Patient, Timothy Brown (5)

Diagnosed with HIV in 1995
4 years of ART
AML diagnosed in 2006 - chemotherapy
HLA identical donor by delta 32 homozygous donor, x2, then total body irradiation
Aviremic since then despite off ART since 2007
What is a HIV 'elite controller'?

Patient able to maintain HIV viral load <50copies spontaneously (without any therapy)
Tend to be HLAB27 or B57
What is a long term nonprogressor in HIV?
Long-standing HIV infection who are not on ART do not develop clinical progression and have stable CD4 cell counts and low levels of detectable viremia
What is the expected outcome if a HIV patient ceases ART?
Rapid viral rebound with rise in viral load, drop in CD4
Describe immune reconstitution inflammatory syndrome (IRIS)

Inflammatory reaction to latent or subclinical infection
- 'paradoxical' subtype: worsening of a recognised pre-existing infection
- 'unmasking' subctype: worsening/appearance of an unrecognised pre-existing infection
May occur 1 week to 1 month after starting any ART
Clincial features relate to the type and location of the pre-existing infection
Higher risk with low CD4 count (<100 cells mircoL)
Describe the non-infective immune reconstitution inflammatory syndrome (IRIS) in HIV patients

Rarely, instead of worsening of a pre-existing infection, ART can be associated with dramatic onset or worsening of an autoimmune condition
e.g. sarcoidosis, autoimmune thyroiditis, graves' disease
Describe the management of TB and HIV co-infection (which should be treated first)

Start TB treatment first.
- If CD4 count <50, start ART < 2 weeks (to minimise AIDS progression and death)
- If CD4 >50, start ART between 2 - 8 weeks (to minimise IRIS risk)

In TB meningitis, wait at least 8 weeks regardless of CD4, as severe IRIS can be fatal
How can IRIS be differentiated from worsening immunodeficiency-related infection?

In IRIS: 
- HIV RNA low, inflammation high, evidence of immune response on histopathology, may resolve without treatment
in immunodeficiency: 
- HIV RNA high, inflammation low, impaired immune response on histopathology, requires antimicrobials
Name 3 aromatase inhibitors

Anastrozole
Letrozole
Exemestane
