A patient with HIV is started on prophylaxis against opportunistic infection due to a CD4 count below the required theshold. With ART, it rises above the threshold again. Should the prophylaxis be ceased or continued?
Can be ceased once CD4 count above the cutoff, provided viral load is well ocntrolled so there is no indication CD4 count will drop again
When should antiretroviral therapy be started?

At diagnosis in all patients, regardless of CD4 count
(some delay may be required if current opportunistic infection - see other cards)

From the START study: 57% reduce risk of AIDS illness, serious non-AIDS illness or all cause mortality with immediate (vs delayed) ART
When should ART be started in HIV patients with an opportunistic infection?
Once stable on treatment for the infection - generally within 2-4 weeks (to avoid overlap of toxicity)
When is it safe to stop ART for HIV patients?

Never. Do not stop, no breaks or holidays (unless very significant toxicity)
Results in higher mortality/AIDS events
Which opportunistic infection carries the highest risk of IRIS in HIV patients?
Cryptococcal meningitis
Name the 5 classes of antiretroviral drugs

Reverse transcriptase inhibitors - nucleoside/nucleotide analogues
Reverse transcriptase inhibitors - non-nucleoside reverse transcriptase inhibitors
Protease inhibitors
Entry inhibitors (fusion inhibitor/chemokine receptor blocker)
Integrase Strand Transfer inhbitors (most potent)
Describe the initial antriretroviral therapy for HIV infection
At least three drugs are used, typically two NRTIs + a third agent
Name 3 nucleoside analogue reverse transcriptase inhibitors (NRTIs)

Lamivudine
Emtricitabine
Abacavir
Name 1 nucleotide analogue reverse transcriptase inhibitor (NRTI)
Tenofovir
Name 2 toxicities of tenofovir

Renal impairment
Osteopenia
Name the medication associated with hypersensitivity in HLAB*5701 positive patients
Abacavir
What test must be performed prior to starting abacavir?

HLAB*5701
If positive, cannot use abacavir
Name 3 toxicities of tenofovir

renal tubular toxicity/renal impairment 
reduced bone mineral density
acute exacerbation of hepatitis B on discontinuation in hepatitis B / HIV co-infected patients
Name 2 toxicities of emtricitabine

hyperpigmentation of palms and soles
acute exacerbation of hepatitis B on discontinuation in hepatitis B / HIV co-infected patients
Name 2 toxicities of efavirenz

neuropsychological reactions (insomnia, altered dreams, impaired concentration, abnormal thinking, dizziness [on starting, usually resolves after days to weeks])
hyperlipidaemia
Name 4 toxicities of atazanavir

unconjugated hyperbilirubinaemia and jaundice (not dangerous, cosmetic problem)
rash 
prolongation of PR interval
nephrolithiasis
Name 4 toxicities of dolutegravir

headache
diarrhoea
increased creatine kinase
increased serum creatinine due to inhibition of renal tubular creatinine secretion
Name 4 toxicities of elvitegravir

diarrhoea
nausea
headache
increased creatine kinase
Name 6 toxicities of raltegravir

nausea
headache 
increased creatine kinase
rash
abnormal liver function
rhabdomyolysis (rare)
Name 3 class toxicities of non-nucleoside reverse transcriptase inhibitors (NNRTIs)

nausea
rash (including StevensJohnson syndromemore frequent with nevirapine)
abnormal liver function (more frequent with nevirapine)
Name 6 class toxicities of protease inhibitors for HIV

hyperlipidaemia (all more common when ritonavir combined with lopinavir than with atazanavir and darunavir)
nausea
diarrhoea
lipodystrophy
hyperglycaemia 
abnormal liver function
Name 4 non-nucleoside reverse transcriptase inhibitors (NNRTIs)

1st gen:
Nevirapine
Efavirenz

2nd gen:
Etravirine
Rilpivirine (cannot take with PPI)
Name 2 toxicities of nevirapine

Severe hepatotoxicity (especially in women with CD4 count greater than 250 cells/microlitre or men with CD4 count greater than 400 cells/microlitre)
Fever
Name 3 protease inhibitors used in HIV

Atazanavir
Darunavir
Lopinavir+ritonavir
What drug must be given together with protease inhibitors (for HIV) to increase their effect?

Ritonavir, low dose
Is also a protease inhibitor, reduces the metabolism of the other PI to increase its effect
Name 1 fusion inhibitor used in HIV
Enfuvirtide
Name 1 HIV entry inhibitor (CCR5 inhibitor)

Maraviroc 
- only used in CCR5 HIV strain
Name 3 integrase strand transfer inhibitors

Dolutegravir
Elvitegravir
Raltegravir
Name 6 preferred features of antiretroviral therapy

Once daily dose
Fixed drug combination
Low toxicity and long time side effects
Minimal drug drug interactions
Low selection for resistance
CNS penetration
Describe genotype testing in HIV (5)

Should be done at baseline
15 - 20% have resistance to at least 1 drug
Strongly influenced by antiretroviral drug use patterns in source patient
Early detection important as some mutations become undetectable over time (virus is away from selection pressure of antiretrovirals in previous host) 
Most common is NNRTI resistance
Name 2 single pill combination that can be used as initial therapy for HIV

Dolutegravir + abacavir + lemivudine
(integrase inhibitor + NRTI + NRTI)

Elvitegravir + Cobicistat + Emtricitabine + Tenofovir ('Genvoya')
(integrase + cyp450 inhibitor + NRTI + NRTI)
Name 1 drug that interacts with integrase inhibitors
Metformin
Describe investigations that should ideally be done prior to starting antiretroviral therapy in HIV (7)

CD4 count
HIV viral load
Hepatitis B and C
HIV genotype
LFT, fasting lipids
HLAB5701
Drug review - any potential interactions
What is the ideal NRTI of choice in HIV and hep B co-infection?
Tenofovir - has anti hep B action
What is the aim for HIV viral load with antiretroviral treatment?
<20 copies/mL (undetectable)
Define virologic suppression in HIV
HIV RNA level below limit of assay detection (<20copies/mL
Define incomplete virological response in HIV
Inability to achieve virologic suppression after 24 weeks of therapy (viral load >200 on 2 consecutive samples)
Define virologic failure in HIV
The inability to maintain suppression of viral replication to a HIV RNA level <200copies/mL
Define virologic rebound in HIV
HIV RNA > 200copies/mL after virologic suppression
Should a single increased viral load result prompt a change in ART in patients with HIV?

No
Need two consecutive measurements 1 month apart of >200 to be termed virologic failure
A single measurement of viraemia 20 - 200copies/mL is a 'blip' and is not significant
Name 4 causes of virologic failure in HIV on ART

Noncompliance (most common)
Drug-drug or drug-food interactions
- e.g. Atazanavir or rilpivirine taken with a PPI, rilpivirine taken without a meal
Underlying malabsorptive condition
Drug resistance
You suspect a patient with HIV who has virologic failure has developed drug resistance. When should genotype testing for resistance be performed?

While on ART, or within 4 weeks of discontinuing
- virus tends to revert to 'wild type' in absence of ART selection pressure
Name 2 indications for switching ART therapy in HIV

Virologic failure
Toxicity

Do NOT switch in immunologic failure (persistent low CD4 despite therapy) - does not work
A patient with HIV has persistently low CD4 despite ART. Is there evidence for switching to different therapy?

No
Does not improve outcomes
What is 'archived resistance' in HIV?

Resistance to a previous ART treatment the patient has been on and developed resistance to, often long ago
Does not appear on genotype testing, however resistance appears if that drug is restarted

Need to take thorough treatment history to avoid.
When is it considered safe to switch one agent of an ART regimen in HIV patients who are having drug toxicity?
When viral load is suppressed <50copies/mL
When switching therapy in ART, should you switch within the drug class or to a new drug class?
Try to use a new class
Name 10 non-infectious complications of HIV

T2DM
Dyslipidaemia
HAND
Cardiovascular disease
Hepatic steatosis
Bone and kidney disease
Depression
Hypertension
Cancer
Sexual dysfunction
What is the risk reduction with PrEP with perfect adherence?
100% reduction (no documented cases of transmission)
What is contained in pre-exposure prophylaxis for HIV (PrEP)?
Tenofovir + emtricitabine
Which patients are eligible for PrEP?

Medium to high risk of HIV infection
Negative HIV test
eGFR >60
Not on nephrotoxic medication
Describe postexposure prophylaxis (PEP)

Start within 72hrs of exposure
Two NRTIs if low risk: 
- emtricitabine + tenofovir, or 
- lamivudine + zidovudine)
If high risk, add to the above
- lopinavir + ritonavir (protease inhibitor), or
- raltegravir (integrase inhibitor)

Continue for 4 weeks.

HIV test at baseline, 4-6 weeks, and 3 months after exposure.
Describe early HIV infection (first 6 months) (6)

May have acute HIV infection (refers to symptomatic patients/acute retroviral syndrome)
Viral load very high, >100,000 copies/mL (may be >1 million copies)
CD4 count drops transiently
Seroconversion occurs
Virus 'set point' reached - steady state of plasma viraemia, stable CD4 count
- higher virus set point = poorer prognosis, faster progression
Describe chronic HIV infection (without ART) (4)

Stable viral load with slow progressive CD4 decline
Average viral load 30,000 - 50,000 copies/mL
Average 109 CD4 cells destroyed daily without treatment, which are mostly replaced leading to slow decline
Average 50cells/microL decline per year; faster/slower decline with higher/lower viral load
Without treatment, what is the average time between HIV infection and CD4 <200?
8 - 10 years
What signs or symptoms may be seen in a patient with chronic untreated HIV infection without AIDS?

Majority asymptomatic
May have nonspecific constitutional symptoms
Majority have generalised lymphadenopathy - symmetrical, modest enlargement, painless
What HIV-associated complications begin to appear at CD4 count 200 - 499? (5)

Skin and mucosal: thrush, oral hairy leukoplakia, seborrheic dermatitis, bacterial folliculitis (particularly due to staph aureus)
Viral reactivation: HSV, VZV, HPV (may have rapid progression)
Strep pneumoniae
Hep B and C
Syphilis
Define AIDS
HIV infection with CD4 count < 200, or presence of an AIDS defining illness
What is the mean CD4 count at AIDS-definining illness diagnosis?
What percentage of patients develop AIDS with a CD4 count > 200?
What is the average time from CD4 < 200 to diagnosis of an AIDS defining illness?
12 - 18 months
Where is the viral reservoir for HSV and VZV?
Episomal DNA ganglia
Do antivirus drugs virucidal or virustatic?

All are virustatic
Hence no action against nonreplicating or latent virus
How do nucleoside and nucleotide analogue antivirals work?
False analogues of the building blocks the virus need to make new RNA or DNA, causing chain termination of the new strand
How do protease inhibitor antivirals work?
Interfere with enzymes essential for cleavage of proteins required to form a new viral particle
Describe the action of neuraminidase inhibitor antivirals

Bind the neuraminidase spike to prevent the passage of the virus through the cell membrane, thus preventing formation of the new viral particle
e.g. oseltamivir
How does HIV develop drug resistance?
When reverse transcriptase synthesises DNA from HIV viral RNA, this is an error-prone process and mutation can give rise to resistance
How does acyclovir work?

It is an analogue of deoxyguanosine (a nucleoside analogue) (i.e. the 'G' base in DNA)
Missing 3' hydroxyl sugar, which means no further bases can be added, thereby disrupting synethesis of new virus DNA
What is ID50?
Infectious doe required to produce infection in 50% of subjects
What is IC50?
Concentration of drug (e.g. gentamicin) required ot inhibit the growth of half of an inoculum of a bug (e.g. pseudomonas)
What is the relationship between acyclovir and valacyclovir

Acyclovir has poor bioavailability (20%)
Valacyclovir is a prodrug of acyclovir, better bioavailabilty (55%)
Can achieve much higher AUC and therefore treat infections that require higher drug concentrations (e.g. CMV)
What is the mechanism or action of penciclovir?

A nucleoside analogue of the deoxyguanosine base (same as acyclovir)
Crucial difference from deoxygyanosine at the end of the molecule no further bases can be added, thereby disrupting synethesis of new virus DNA
A first episode of genital herpes is usually caused by HSV 1 or 2?
HSV 1
Recurrent genital herpes is usually due to HSV 1 or 2?
HSV 2
Describe the management of a first episode of genital herpes (herpes simplex virus)
Start within 72hrs of symptoms for best results.
Describe the management of recurrent/episode genital herpes (herpes simplex virus)
Describe the suppressive treatment of genital herpes (herpes simplex virus) for patients with frequent severe recurrences

Treatment may be ongoing, or it may be interrupted every 6 months to determine the natural history of the disease and restarted in the event of recurrence. 
Long-term suppressive antiviral therapy is considered safe.
Describe the management of a minor primary episode of oral mucovutaneous herpes simplex virus (2)

Supportive management (ie oral fluids, antipyretic drugs and analgesia)
Topical lignocaine 2%
Describe the management of severe primary skin or oral mucocutaneous herpes simplex virus infection
Describe the management of minor recurrence of oral mucocutaneous herpes simplex virus (cold sore)
Topical aciclovir 5%, 5 times a day for 5 days at first sign of recurrence
Describe the management of herpes zoster (reactivated varicella zoster virus/shingles)
If presents within 72hrs of onset, or if immunocompromised regardless of duration, use:
What are the benefits of antiviral ltherapy in shingles (reactivated varicella zoster virus)?

If commenced within 72hrs, reduces acute pain, duration of the rash, viral shedding and ophthalmic complications. 
Whether antiviral therapy reduces the incidence of postherpetic neuralgia is contentious.
Describe the classic appearance the retina in CMV retinitis

Haemorrhage and exudates tracking along blood vessels
'tomato sauce on cottage cheese'
What is the diagnosis?

CMV retinitis
Classic haemorrhage and exudate tracking along blood vessels ('tomato sauce on cottage cheese') appearance
Describe the mechanism of action of ganciclovir

Analogue of nucleoside guanosine
Particularly potent against CMV (preferentially phosphorylated by CMV viral kinase UL97, leading to chain termination)
Terrible oral bioavailability, need to be used IV
Describe the mechanism of action of valganciclovir

A prodrug of ganciclovir with improved bioavailability (60% vs 6-10%)
Ganciclovir is an analogue of nucleoside guanosine with particularly potent action against CMV
What is the mechanism of action of zanamivir and oseltamivir?

Neuraminidase inhibitors, used for influenza
Bind the neuraminidase spike to prevent the passage of the virus through the cell membrane, thus preventing formation of the new viral particle
Describe the management of acute influenza infection

If established complications, or if requiring hospitalisation, or if at high risk for poor outcomes (e.g pregnant, elderly, co-morbidities), use:
- oseltamivir 75mg BD for 5 days, or
- zanamivir 10mg inhaled BD for 5 days

Can also consider within 48hrs of infection in otherwise well individuals, but only shortens disease duration by 1 day
What is the effect of neuraminidase inhibitors (zanamivir, oseltamivir) in patients admitted with influenza?
Reduced mortality, best if within 48hrs but still benefit after this too
Describe the mechanism of action of foscarnet (5)

Pyrophosphate analogue
Directly inhibits pyrophosphate binding site of DNA polymerase (no need for phosphorylation like the nucleoside analogues), preventing viral DNA replication
Therefore active against resistant viruses that have stopped phosphorylating and uptaking the nucleoside analogue drugs like acyclovir
Broad action against many different viruses
Less virus-specific than nucleoside analogues, so more toxic (renal dysfynction, metabolic disturbance)
Describe the mechanism of action of cidofovir

Nucleotide analogue of deoxycytidine monophosphate (dCMP)
Does not need viral enzymes to become activated (independent of TK/UL97 phosphorylation), therefore active against resistant virus
Active against adenovirus, HSV, EBV, HBV, HHV6, HHV8, HPV
Less viral-specific so more toxic
Describe the yellow fever vaccine

Live attenuated vaccine 
Contraindicated in immunocompromised (they can get yellow fever and die)
Lifelong protection
Indicated in travellers to endemic areas, and those who live there (parts of South America and sub-Saharan Africa)
Do not give over age 60
What is yellow fever
Mosquito borne viral haemorrhagic fever, caused by a flavivirus
Where is yellow fever found?
Found in tropical regions of South America, and sub-Saharan Africa (ongoing outbreak in Brazil)
Describe the three stages of yellow fever infection

Infection: nonspecific findings like fever, malaise, headache, joint pain, nausea, vomiting
Remission: abatement of symptoms for up to 48hrs
Intoxication: hepatic dysfunction, renal failure, coagulopathy, shock
How is a diagnosis of yellow fever made? (3)

Serology (ELISA for IgM)
- IgM provides presumptive diagnosis, confirmed by a rise in titre between paired acute and convalescent samples
PCR
- rapid diagnostic PCR tests
Virus isolation
Describe the management of yellow fever
Supportive care (no specific antivirals available)
For how long after travel to a Zika-endemic area should a male refrain from attempting to conceive a child?
6 months
For how long after travel to a Zika-endemic area should a female refrain from attempting to conceive a child?
8 weeks
How can Zika be transmitted? (4)

Mosquitoes
Blood
Sexual
Organ transplant
Lab exposure
Describe the manifestations of Zika virus infection (6)

Fever
Rash
Small joint arthritis
Conjunctivitis
Guillain-Barre
Foetal microcephaly if pregnant

Typically resolives in 1 week
Is it safe to travel to a Zika area while pregnant, in any trimester?
No
What percentage of patients will be asymptomatic with Zika infection?
Can a negative Zika test exclude infection?
No
Describe the Zika virus (2)

Flavivirus, mosquito-borne
Ongoing outbreak in the Americas, also found in Africa, Southeast Asia, Pacific Islands
Describe carbapenem resistance (2)

Frequently due to carbapenemase
Hydrolyse all beta lactams, including carbapenems
Define malaria

Infection with parasite from the Plasmodium family
Transmitted to humans through the bites of infected mosquitoes
Name the 5 species of plasmodium parasite that cause malaria, and their features

P. falciparum 
- almost all deaths/severe disease
- no dormant liver stage, no late relapses
- almost always chloroquinolone resistant
- need to exclude rapidly when malaria is suspected
P. knowlesi
- Can be severe, but looks like malariae on testing
P. vivax and P. ovale
- Can lie dormant and have late relapses
P. malariae
- Usually benign
Describe diagnostic testing for malaria

FBE
- haemolytic anaemia
- WCC low or normal
- thrombocytopenia (95%)
Microscopy (thick and thin film) 
Rapid diagnostic testing/antigen capture tests, e.g. immunochromatographic assay (ICT) 

Thick and thin films are much more sensitive for falciparum than for vivax and ovale
Describe the management of uncomplicated malaria

Artemether + lumefantrine (1st line)
or
Atovaquone + proguanil
or
Quinine sulfate + doxycycline or clindamycin

Do not use the same thing they had for prophylaxis
Describe severe malaria

Altered consciousness, jaundice, oliguria, respiratory distress, severe anaemia or hypoglycaemia
Parasite count > 100 000/mm3 (more than 2% of red blood cells parasitised)
Vomiting
Clinical acidosis or metabolic acidosis on blood biochemistry
Acute kidney injury
Severe malaria is usually due to which species?
Plasmodium falciparum
Describe the management of severe malaria (3)

Artesunate IV
Switch to oral artemether-lumefantrine when well/able to take oral therapy
Likely to need ICU

Can use IV quinine if artesunate not available (not as good)
What is the mortality in severe malaria?
15 - 20% with treatment
Describe 1 delayed toxicity of artesunate therapy for severe malaria
Delayed haemolysis (weeks after therapy)
Describe anti-relapse therapy in malaria with vivax and ovale

P. vivax and ovale can exist as dormant parasites(hypnozites) in the liver, which do not show up on testing
Require therapy to eliminate

Use the below concurrently with usual uncomplicated malaria treatment:
- primaquine

Need to exclude G6PD deficiency prior to use of primaquine (haemolysis)
What condition needs to be excluded prior to use of primaquine?

G6PD
Use can cause severe haemolysis

Primaquine is used to eradicate dormant parasites in plasmodium vivax and ovale (malaria) infection
Describe malaria prophylaxis (3)

Atovaquone + proguanil (start 1 day prior, continue 1 week after leaving)
or
Doxycycline (start 1-2 days prior, continue 4 weeks after leaving
or
Mefloquine (start 2 weeks prior, continue 4 weeks after leaving)
What is the malaria prophylaxis of choice in pregnancy

Mefloquine (safe in 2nd and 3rd trimesters)

In general malaria-endemic areas should be avoided in pregnancy
Describe the side effects of doxycycline (4)

Photosensitivity (10%)
GI upset
Vaginal thrush
OCP becomes ineffective
Describe dengue fever (2)

Flavivirus, mosquito-borne
Incubation 3 - 10 days
Describe the 4 classic dengue fever syndromes

Undifferentiated fever
Classic dengue fever
Dengue haemorrhagic fever
Dengue shock syndrome
Describe the general biochemical findings in dengue fever (3)

FBE
- neutropenia, later lymphocytosis
- thrombocytopenia (<100 = severe disease)
- haematocrit: rising haematocrit indicates fluid leakage, warning sign for shock
LFT
- mildly raised ALT, AST (3-5x ULN = severe)
Describe the diagnostic testing for dengue fever

Serology (1st test)
NS1 antigen 
Flavivirus PCR
Describe traveller's diarrhoea

A syndrome, causes largely by bacteria
Commonest travel related symptom (20 - 50% in developing countries)
Usually abrupt onset and self-limiting without treatment
Describe the treatment of traveller's diarrhoea
Azithromycin 1g as a single dose or 500mg daily for 3 days
What is the formula for positive liklihood ratio
sensitivity/1 - specificity
What is the negative likelihood ratio equation?
1 - sensitivity/specificity
What is the formula for sensitivity?
Sens = true pos/(true pos + false neg)
What is the formula for specificity?
Spec = true neg/(true neg + false pos)

Nocardia
Legionella

Aspergillus
Cryptococcus
Mucormycosis
Pneumocystis

Encapsulated organisms (inability to opsonise)

Hyposplenism/asplenism
Hypogammaglobulinaemia

Invasive fungal infections
Which has higher mortality, gram postive or gram negative bacteraemia in patients with febrile neutropenia?

Gram negative (18%) is higher.
Gram positive (5%)

Mild or no symptoms: 5 points
Moderate symptoms: 3 points
No COPD: 4 points
Solid tumour OR haem with no prior invasive fungal infection: 4 points

Outpatient: 3 points

Score >21 = can consider outpatient PO antibiotics

anti-CTL4
What is the mechanism of action of pembrolizumab
PD-1 inhibitor
What are ESBLs?

Extended spectrum beta-lactamases
Enzymes that inactivate and confer resistance to most beta-lactam antibiotics, including penicillins and cephalosporins
Coded for on plasmids, which can be transmitted between bacteria
Found exclusively in gram-negative organisms, primarily Klebsiella pneumoniae, Klebsiella oxytoca, and Escherichia coli.

Treat with meropenem or trimethoprim/sulfamethoxazole
How does the quantiferon gold assay work (4)

Measures host lymphocyte gamma-interferon response to specific antigens for MTB complex
Tests reactivity to TB antigens (ESAT6 and CFP10), which are potent antigens that cause T cells to produce interferon gamma
Control test of reaction mitogen - the mitogen is the 'control' to test if the patient is able to mount a sufficient immune response, and should be positive.
- an indeterminate result can occur in in immunosuppressed patients who fail to test positive in the mitogen control

Specificity 98 - 100%, sensitvity 80 - 85%
Name 5 risk factors for pneumocystis pneumonia

HIV
Glucocorticoidss, particularly if + another immunosuppressive therapy
Defect in cell-mediated immunity
Cancer (haematologic > solid)
Transplant
Describe the presentation of pneumocystis pneumonia in patients without HIV

Fulminant respiratory failure
Fever
Dry cough

Typically in an immunosuppressed patient
Describe the typical radiographic features of pneumocystis pneumonia in patients without HIV

Diffuse, bilateral, interstital infiltrates
Ground glass pattern on CT
Describe investigations for suspected PJP infection (5)

CD4 count (if HIV)
1-3-beta-d-glucan level (elevated in infection)
CXR and/or CT chest

Diagnostic tests:
Induced sputum
if negative, bronchoscopy with bronchoalveolar lavage
What type of organism is pneumocystis jirovecii?
An atypical yeast-like fungus
Name 8 risk factors for PJP in HIV patients

Not receiving ART
CD4 < 200
CD4 < 14%
Previous PJP
Oral thrush
Recurrent bacterial pneumonia
Unintentional LOW
HIgh viral load
Describe the presentation of PJP in HIV patients
Indolent onset of fever, cough, dyspnoea over days to weeks
Describe the treatment for mild to moderate pneumocystis jiroveci pneumonia (4)

Trimethoprim/sulfamethoxazole 5/25 mg/kg TDS for 21 days (preferred), or
Clindamycin, or
Dapsone, or
Atovaquone
Describe the treatment of severe pneumocystis jiroveci pneumonia (4)

Trimethoprim/sulfamethoxazole 5/25mg/kg IV, 6-8hrly until improved, then switch to orals (preferred)
or, if hypersensitive to the above,
Clindamycin IV
or
Pentamidine IV

Also, if HIV positve, ADD:
Prednisolone 40mg BD
Name 2 diagnostic tests for herpes virus infection

Herpes multiplex PCR
Histology showing tissue inclusions (gold standard)
What is the diagnostic test of choice in suspected CMV infection?
CMV viral load

Which patients undergoing immunosuppressive patients should be screened for hepatitis B? What should be tested?

All patients

Hep B surface antigen
Anti-hep B core

If the above are positive, complete the remaining serology for hep B
Describe the management of hep B surface antigen positve patients who are about to start immunosuppression

Antiviral prophylaxis, ideally 1 week before starting therapy
Continue for 6-12 months after stopping therapy (if rituximab, at least 12 months)

Tenofovir, or
Entecavir
Describe the management of hep B surface antigen negative, hep B core antibody positive patients who are about to start immunosuppression

Low risk of reactivation, unless rituximab

Either:
Use prophylxis (tenofovir or entecavir), or 
Monitor closely and start if anti-HBs level decreases, or hep B surface antigen or HBV DNA become positive
What is the preferred hep B treatment in pregnancy?

Tenofovir

Decision of whether to continue or not is expect advice (continue if advanced liver disease)
Describe strategies to reduce risk of mother-baby transmission of hepatitis B (2)

Tenofovir commenced at 30-32 weeks to reduce viral load (if high load)
Hep B vaccination and hep B immunoglobulin to the infant within 12 hours of birth
Describe progressive multifocal leukoencephalopathy

Caused by reactivation of JC virus (John Cunningham virus)
Deadly demyelinating disease of the CNS
Occurs only in immunosuppression
Associated with HIV and AIDS, also rarely in lymphoproliferative and myeloproliferative dieases, solid organ malignancy, organ transplant
Describe the presentation of progressive multifocal leukoencephalopathy (5)

subacute neurologic deficits including 
- altered mental status
- visual symptoms such as hemianopia and diplopia
- hemiparesis or monoparesis
- appendicular or gait ataxia
-  Seizures (18%)

Can be a manifestation of IRIS (i.e. after starting ART for HIV)
Describe the imaging findings in progressive multifocal leukoencephalopathy

Multifocal process limited to the white matter 
Does not conform to vascular territories 
Exhibits neither mass effect nor contrast enhancement.
Reactivation of the JC virus results in what disease?
Progressive multifocal leukoencephalopathy
How is progressive multifocal leukoencephalopathy diagnosed?

Brain biopsy (gold standard) (not always necessary)
PCR for JC virus DNA in the CSF
Describe the BK virus and its effects (4)

A polyomavirus, only causes disease in immunosuppression

Reactivation causes
- tubulointersitial nephritis (in renal transplant, rarely in other transplants)
- ureteral stenosis (in renal transplant, rarely in other transplants)
- haemorrhagic cystitis (in allogeneic stem cell transplant)
Describe the management of strongyloides hyperinfection syndrome (2)

Ivermectin +/- albendazole
Reduce immunosuppression if possible
Describe the presentation of strongyloides hyperinfection syndrome (5)

Fever
Nausea/vomiting, anorexia, diarrhoea, abdo pain 
Dyspnoea, wheeze, haemoptysis, cough
CXR showing pulmonary infiltrates with foci of haemorrhage, pneumonitis, and oedema
Bacteraemia (typically gram negative) due to bloodstream seeding from the GI tract or lungs
What is this?
Sputum sample shows stronyloides larvae being attacked by eosinophils
Toxoplasmosis is typically seen in which patint group? (4)

Condiutions with T cell deficits:

HIV infection (most common CNS infection in AIDS not on appropriate prophylaxis)
Allogeneic haematopoetic cell transplant
Heart transplant
Haematological malignancy with profound T cell deficit
What is toxoplasma gondii? (2)

Causative pathogen in toxoplasmosis
Intracellular protozoan parasite
Does toxoplasma gondii cause disease in immunocompetent patients?

No, typically only immunocompromised get toxoplasmosis
If infected, are asymptomatic
Latent infection can persist for life
At what CD4 count is toxoplasmosis typically seen in HIV patients?
CD4 < 100
Describe the clinical features of cerebral toxoplasmosis

Toxoplasmic encephalitis.
- headache
- fever
- neurologic symptoms, confusion - may have focal deficits or seizure
Name 3 clinical syndromes of extracerebral toxoplasmosis

Pneumonitis
Chorioretinitis
Disseminated disease with septic shock
Describe pneumonitis seen in toxoplasmosis (4)

Fever
SOB
Nonproductive cough 
Reticulonodular infiltrates on CXR

Can be indistinguishable from PJP
Describe toxoplasmosis chorioretinitis (3)

Eye pain
Decreased visual acuity
Raised yellow-white cottony lesions in nonvascular distribution (as opposed to CMV which is vascular distribution)
When may a presumptive diagnosis of toxoplasmosis be made? (3)

Compatible clinical syndrome (e.g. toxoplasmic encephalitis)
Positive T gondii IgG antibody
Brain imaging shows typical appearance
Describe the typical appearance on MRI in toxoplasmosis

Multiple ring-enhancing lesions
Associated oedema
Describe investigations for suspected toxoplasmosis (5)

Serology for T gondii IgG (IgM usually absent)
MRI brain

Occasionally:
Lumbar puncture - PCR for T gondii (highly specific, variable sensitivity 50 - 98%)
Brain biopsy + visualisation of organism
SPECT (good for lymphoma vs toxo, e.g. single lesion and poor candidate for biopsy)
Do cervical nerve roots emerge above or below the corresponding vertebra (e.g. does C6 nerve root emerge at C5/6 or C6/7)?

Emerge above
e.g. C6 emerges at C5/6
Do thoracic and lumbar nerve roots emerge above or below the corresponding vertebra (e.g. does T6 nerve root emerge at T5/6 or T6/7)?

Emerge below
e.g. T6 emerges at T6/7
Where does the spinal cord end?
Can lumbar level pathology give upper motor neuron signs?

No
Cord ends at L1-2
Describe the path of the corticospinal tract

Contain upper motor neurones that original at M1 of the primary motor cortex in the posterior frontal lobe
Fibres run to the internal capsule, become more closely packed
Go down through the brainstem
Decussate at the lower medulla (80 - 85% of fibres decussate and become the lateral corticospinal tract; the remainder do not and are the anterior corticospinal tract)
Synapse on the anterior horn cells

Lateral corticospinal tract contains majority of fibres (80 - 85%)
The dorsal columns control what sensory modalities (2)

Joint position
Vibration
Describe the path of the dorsal columns

Input from large sensory fibres in peripheral nerve
Enter through the dorsal horn, into the dorsal column ipsilaterally
Decussate at the cervicomedullary junction
Up to the thalamus and into the sensory cortex
The anterior and lateral spinothalamic tracts carry what three sensory modalities?

Pain
Temperature
Touch
Describe the path of the spinothalamic tract

Input from small sensory fibres in peripheral nerves
Enter through the dorsal root ganglion
Decussate almost immediately (within 1-2 segments)
Terminate in the thalamus (and a little to the cortex)

Name the 3 major white matter tracts of clinical importance

Corticospinal tract
Dorsal colum
Anterior and lateral spinothalamic tracts
This is an example of an intramedullary, intradural, or extradural mass of the spinal cord?
Intramedullary (i.e. mass is whithin the spinal cord itself)
This is an example of an intramedullary, intradural, or extradural mass of the spinal cord?

Extradural mass
This is a mass from outside the spinal cord that is pushing on it
This is an example of an intramedullary, intradural, or extradural mass of the spinal cord?
Intradural mass, e.g. fibroma or meningioma
What is 'lamination' of the spinal cord and how is it clincally relevent?

The lateral tracts (lateral corticospinal tract, lateral spinothalamic tract) have their fibres ordered laterally to medially from lowest (sacral) to highest (cervical)
This means extrinsic compression will affect the lower levels more, have a vague upper limit of the sensory level
Intrinsic compression will affect the upper levels more, have a crisp upper limit of involvement and attenuated lower level involvement with sacral sparing
What is the classic cause of a 'central cord pattern' of involvement?
Syringomyelia - fluid-filled, gliosis-lined cavity within the spinal cord
Describe the pattern of involvement in syringomyelia

Central spinal cord lesion
Involves decussating fibres of the spinothalamic tract (so they lesion will cause sensory loss at and above the level of the lesion)
- sensory loss of only pain and temperature
- sparing of dorsal column (joint position, vibration)
May have direct involvement of the anterior horn cells causing lower motor involvement
Finger jerk reflex corresponds to what level?
C8
Triceps jerk reflex corresponds to what level?
C7
What is brown-seqard syndrome?

Also called hemi-cord syndrome
Unilateral involvement of the dorsal column, corticospinal tract, and spinothalamic tract
Weakness, loss of vibration, and loss of proprioception on ipsilateral side below the level of the lesion
Loss of pain and temperature on the opposite side below the level of the lesion (the spinothalamic tract, because it decussates almost immediately)

Causes include knife/bullet wounds, demyelination.
Most spinal cord blood supply within the cord is provided by?

Anterior spinal artery
However the posterior columns (including the dorsal column) are supplied by the posterior spinal arteries)
What clincal picture would you expect with occlusion of the anterior spinal artery?

Dense paraplegia involving motor (corticospinal) and spinothalamic tracts, as these are supplied by the anterior spinal artery
May spare the posterior columns (including the dorsal column), as supply is by the posterior spinal arteries
Describe subactue combined degeneration of the cord

Caused by pernicious anaemia with B12 deficiency
 - Similar picture rarely caused by copper deficiency, viamint E deficiency, nitrous oxide intoxication
Degeneration of dorsal and lateral white matter (dorsal column, corticospinal tract)
Results in slowly progressive weakness, sensory ataxia, and paraesthesia
Ultimately results in spasticity, paraplegia, incontinence
Not all patients have anaemia or macrocytosis
B12 supplementation halts or reverses progression
Name 3 causes of neoplasia in the intradural/extramedullary space of the spine

Meningeal metastases (e.g. leptomeningeal disease)
Neurofibroma
Meningioma
Name 2 clinical presentations of meningeal cancer

Encephalopathy
Multifocal lesions, randomly scattered, with focal neurological signs (nerve roots, cranial nerves, spinal cord)
e.g. right L5 nerve root syndrome, left C7 nerve root syndrome, a numb chin on the left and deafness on the right
What is the most common cause of acute myelopathy?
Demyelination
Name 6 causes of acute myelopathy

Demyelination (most common)
Infection
Inflammatory process
Vascular
Neoplastic/paraneoplastic
Compression/surgical
Describe the diagnostic criteria for idiopathic transverse myelitis (5)

Bilateral, not not necessarily symmetric, sensorimotor and autonomic spinal cord dysfunction
Clearly defined sensory level
Progression to nadir of deficits between 4hrs and 21 days from onset
Demonstraction of spinal cord inflammation (CSF pleocytosis or elevated IgG indec, or MRI shows gadolinium enhancing cord lesion)
Exclusion of compressive, post-RT, neoplastic, vascular causes
Describe transverse myelitis (6)

Segmental spinal cord injury caused by acute inflammation
Usually idiopathic, presumed autoimmune
50% have preceding infection
Can be presenting event in multiple sclerosis
Can be part of the presentatin of neuromyelitis optica
Associated with connective tissue disease
Describe the clinical features of transverse myelitis

Inflammation in 1-2 spinal cord segments, usually in the thoraic cord
Symptoms develop rapidly over hours (though can be slowly over weeks)
Bilateral weakness and multimodality sensory disturbance below level of the lesion
May have pain or tingling, also tight banding/girdle-like sensation around the trunk
May have autonomic dysfunction (bowel and bladder)
Describe the expected investigation results in transverse myelitis (2)

MRI: Gadolinium-enhancing signal abnormality, usually extending over one or more cord segments. The cord often appears swollen at these levels. 
CSF: abnormal in 50%; elevated protein (usually 100 to 120 mg/100 mL) and moderate lymphocytosis (usually <100/mm3). Glucose levels are normal. Oligoclonal bands are usually not present in isolated TM, and when present suggest a higher risk of subsequent MS
What is the expected prognosis in transverse myelitis?

Recovery begins after 1 - 3 months
40% have persistent deficit
Recurrence is rare
Describe the management of transverse myelitis
Corticosteroids or other immunosuppression, though minimal evidence that it works
Describe the presentation of dural arteriovenous fistula (4)

Typically presents with gradual progressive myelopathy, sometimes stepwise
Symptoms may fluctuate but eventually permanent and progressive paraparesis and sensory disturbance with sphincter dysfunction occurs
Age >50-60
More common in men
Describe epidural abscess (6)

Infection via continutous spread from skin/soft tissue, post surgery, or via haematogenous spread
Risk factors: HIV, diabetes, IVDU, ETOH
Staph aureus most common pathogen (66%)
Classic triad of pain, fever, and neurological deficit, however neuro deficit is a very late sign
MRI is highly sensitive
Treatment is surgical drainage and IV antibiotics (genamicin and flucloxacillin)

Name 2 differential diagnoses for apparent C5 or C6 radiculopathy

Neuralgic amyotrophy
Suprascapular nerve palsy
Name 2 differential diagnoses for apparent C7 radiculopathy
Radial nerve palsy (Saturday night palsy)
Name 2 differential diagnoses for apparent C8 or T1 radiculopathy

Lower brachal plexus problem (radiation plexopathy, neoplastic infiltration)
Ulnar nerve palsy
Name 3 differential diagnoses for apparent L2, L3, or L4 radiculopathy

Femoral nerve palsy
Lumbar plexopathy
Psoas haematoma (cannot bear to straighten the leg due to pain)
Name 1 differential diagnoses for apparent L5 adiculopathy

Common peroneal nerve palsy 
- inversion of the foot may be supplied by L5 root but not the common peroneal nerve
- hip abduction is supplied by L5 but never by the common peroneal nerve (weak hip abduction will be L5 root)
Name 1 differential diagnoses for apparent S1 radiculopathy
Sciatic nerve palsy
What is the most common cause of foot drop after hip replacement under spinal anaesthetic?

Stretch or injury of sciatic nerve due to hip joint manipulation
- not due to anaesthetics messing up the L5 nerve root during the spinal anaesthetic
Describe motor neuron disease, and its 3 subtypes

Progressive degenerative condition involving both upper and lower motor neurons
Subtypes include
- amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (most common)
- primary lateral sclerosis (3 - 4%)
- progressive musclar atrophy
Describe amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (5)

The most common form of motor neuron disease
Clinical hallmark is combination of upper motor and lower motor neuron signs and symptoms
Presentations include asymmetric limb weakness (80%) or bulbar onset (20%)
- bulbar onset worse prognosis
Associated frontotemporal dementia in 10 - 15%
Autonomic symptoms, parkinsonism, supranuclear gaze paresis, and/or sensory loss can occur
Describe the natural history of amyotrophic lateral scerosis (subtype of motor neuron disease) (2)

Highly variable presentation and disease course between patients
Relentlessly progressive linear course, eventually resulting in neuromusclar respiratory failure and dysphagia which cause death
Describe primary lateral sclerosis (5)

A less common type of motor neuron disease (2 - 4% cases)
Progressive isolated upper motor neuron disorder
Slower progression than amyotrophic lateral sclerosis, with lack of weight loss, and absence of lower motor neuron findings in first 4 years
Most eventually develop lower motor signs, at which point it is called upper motor neuron onset ALS
Longer survival than ALS
Describe progressive muscular atrophy (3)

Type of motor neuron disease
Progressive lower motor neuron disorder
Many eventually develop upper motor neuron signs later in the disease course (at which point it is called lower motor neuron onset ALS)
Describe the diagnostic criteria for motor neuron disease (3)

Evidence of lower motor neuron degeneration on clinical, electrophysiological, or neuropathological examiantion
Evidence of upper motor neuron degeneration by clinical examination

The above in >4 regions.

And:
Progressive spread to symptoms or signs within a region or to other regions
Describe the investigations for suspected motor neuron disease (4)

History and examination
Electrodiagnostic studies (electromyography and nerve conduction)
MRI to exclude other causes (normal in ALS)
CSF if suspicion for chronic inflammatory demyelinating polyneuropathy, HIV, lymphoma
Describe the expected nerve conduction findings in motor neuron disease
Nerve conduction usually normal, may have reduced compound muscle action potential amplitudes if severe
Describe the expected electromyography findings in motor neuron disease (3)

Features of acute and chronic denervation and reinnervation:
- Acute denervation findings: fibrillations, positive sharp waves
- Chronic denervation and reinnervation findings: large-amplitude, long-duration, complex motor unit action potentials (MUAPs) with neurogenic recruitment and a reduced interference pattern.

Fasciculation potentials may also appear in denervated muscle and represent spontaneous firing of motor units that are not voluntarily recruited. Fasciculations may be visible to the naked eye when they occur on the surface of muscles
Describe the examination findings in motor neuron disease, including relevent negatives (7)

Multifocal distribution
Mixed upper and lower motor neuron signs in the same area
- e.g. a wasted arm with hyperreflexia
Wasting and fasciculation of the tongue (if bulbar)
Wasting of the side of the thumb and the index finger more than the little finger (split hand sign)
No sensory symptoms
No eye movement involvement
No bladder/bowel involvement
Describe the pathological findings in motor neuron disease with frontotemporal dementia (2)

Neuronal loss in brainstem nuclei and anterior horns of psinal cord
Ubiquitin-positive inclusions
What percentage of motor neuron disease patients have a familial syndrome? What is the most common mutation?

5%
C9orf72 (24% of mutations)
Describe the mechanism of action of polyenes

A type of antifungal
Create pores in the fungus cell membrane
e.g. amphotericin B, nystatin
Name 2 toxicities of amphotericin B

Nephrotoxicity
Infusion reaction (fevers, hypotension, bronchospasm, myalgia, nausea/vomiting, tachycardia)

These can be dose-limiting toxicities.
Name 3 uses of amphotericin B

Selected cases of invasive candidiasis
Cryptococcal meningitis in HIV
Empiric therapy, selected cases
Name 4 polyenes

A type of antifungal that targets the cell wall membrane
Amphotericin B, nystatin (older formations)
Liposomal amphotericin (ambisome), amphotericin B lipid complex (abelcet) (newer formations)

Amphotericin B is rarely used due to toxicity; the newer formulations are used instead.
Describe the management of mucormycosis

Urgent surgical debridement
Liposomal amphotericin B, IV
Name 2 agents that would be a good choice for presumed invasive fungal infection as empiric therapy

Liposomal amphotericin B - 1st line
Voriconazole - 2nd line
Describe the management of invasive pulmonary aspergillosis, in patients with no neutropenia and mild disease.

Voriconazole PO, or
Itraconazole PO
Describe the management of invasive pulmonary aspergillosis (2)

Voriconazole IV (preferred), or
Amphotericin B liposomal IV

Avoid using the same agent that was used for prophylaxis
Describe the management of mild to moderate cryptococcal pneumonia caused by C neoformans in immunocompetent patients, who do not have meningitis
Fluconazole IV or PO for first dose, then PO for 6 - 12 months
Describe the management of cryptococcal pneumonia caused by C neoformans in immunocompromised patients, or those with severe infection

Amphotericin B + flycytosine for 2 weeks
Then fluconazole maintenance
Describe the management of cryptococcal pneumonia caused by C Gatii

Amphotericin B (desoxycholate, liposomal, or lipid complex) IV
PLUS
Flucytosine IV

After 2 weeks, switch to PO fluconazole for 6  - 12 months
Describe fusariosis (8)

Infection with fusarium species
Most common invasive species is fusarium solani
Locally invasive or disseminated infection in immunocompromised 
Supsect when:
- persistent fever refractory to antibiotics and antifungals in setting of prolonged neutropenia
- positive fungal blood culture
- presence of skin involvement (cellulitis, interdigital intertrigo, onychomycosis, metastatic lesions)
Diagnose by isolating the fungus in secretions, blood, or skin scrapings
Treat with liposomal amphotericin B if invasive disease
Describe the presentation of cryptococcal meningitis

Subacute onset of headache, fever, altered mental state
May have cerebral mass lesions (cryptococcomas)
Name 2 species implicated in cryptococcal meningitis

Cryptococcus gatii (typically in immunocompetent)
cryptococcus neoformans (typically in immunocompromised)
Describe investigations for suspected cryptococcal meningitis (4)

CT or MRI to look for raised ICP or space-occupying lesion (cryptococcoma)
CSF: low WCC (<50cells/microL) with mononuclear predominance, slightly elevated protein, low glucose (may be completely normal, 25 - 30%)
CSF culture of organism (takes 3- 5 days)
Positive cryptococcal polysaccharide in serum or CSF (much faster than culture, strongly suggests the diagnosis)
Cryptococcal meningitis in non-HIV infected immunocompromised patients is usually caused by what organism?
C gattii
Cryptococcal meningitis in HIV infected immunocompromised patients is usually caused by what organism?

C. neoformans
Can also be C. Gattii
Describe the induction therapy management of cryptococcal meningitis in non-HIV infected immunocompromised patients, and immunocompetent patients

Amphotericin B (desoxycholate, liposomal, or lipid complex) IV
PLUS
Flucytosine IV

Continue for at least 2 weeks, then repeat lumbar puncture to check for viable cryptococci to assess for ongoing need for induction therapy
Need at least 2 weeks induction for C neoformans, 4 - 6 weeks for C gattii
Describe consolidation therapy management of cryptococcal meningitis in non-HIV infected immunocompromised patients, and immunocompetent patients
PO fluconazole for at least 8 weeks
Describe eradication therapy management of cryptococcal meningitis in non-HIV infected immunocompromised patients, and immunocompetent patients
Fluconazole PO daily for 6 - 12 months
Describe induction therapy management of cryptococcal meningitis in HIV infected immunocompromised patients

Amphotericin B (desoxycholate, liposomal, or lipid complex) IV
PLUS
Flucytosine IV

For at least 2 weeks
Describe consolidation therapy management of cryptococcal meningitis in HIV infected immunocompromised patients
Fluconazole 400mg PO daily for 8 weeks
Describe maintenance therapy management of cryptococcal meningitis in HIV infected immunocompromised patients
Fluconazole 200mg daily for at least 1 year, and until CD4 > 100 for 3 months or longer
Describe the mechanism of action of triazole antifungals (fluconazole, itraconazole, etc)

Impact on endoplasmic reticulum of the fungus - inhibit C12alpha demethylase
This is required for ergosterol synthesis to make the cell membrane
Describe the spectrum of activity of voriconazole (4)

Fluconazole resistant candida
Many moulds, including aspergillus, fusarium, scedosporium apiospermum
Voriconazole has what effect on CYP?
CYP inhibitor
Describe toxicities or voriconazole (5)

Elevated LFTs (30%)
Rash (19%)
Transient visual disturbance
Worsening of CKD (cannot use CrCl < 50)
Lung SCC in lung transplant patients
What is 1st line therapy for suspected or definite invasive aspergillosis?
Voriconazole IV
Describe the management of oesophageal candidiasis (2)

Asymptomatic and not immunocompromised: nystatin
All other patients: fluconazole
Name 5 indications for prophylaxis against mould infection (aspergillus, scedosporium)

higher-risk allogeneic HSCT
pre-engraftmentneutropenia expected to last for more than 14 days, or previous Aspergillus infection or colonisation
post-engraftmentsevere graft-versus-host disease (GVHD)
acute myeloid leukaemiahigh-intensity chemotherapy
acute lymphocytic leukaemiahigh-intensity chemotherapy
lung and heartlung transplantationpost-transplantation airway colonisation with Aspergillus
liver transplantationsome high-risk patients
Describe prophylaxis against mould infection (aspergillus, scedosporium)

posaconazole liquid 200 mg orally with fatty food or an acidic beverage, 8-hourly [Note 8] [Note 9]
OR
voriconazole 200 mg orally, 12-hourly
OR
itraconazole liquid 2.5 mg/kg orally, 12-hourly
Describe the indications for prophylaxis against yeast infection (candida) (5)

allogeneic HSCTneutropenia expected to last for less than 14 days
autologous HSCTchemotherapy associated with mucositis
acute myeloid leukaemialess intensive chemotherapy
lymphomahigh-intensity chemotherapy
liver transplantationsome high-risk patients (criteria vary between centres, and some centres use mould prophylaxis instead).

Patients who are already taking prophylaxis against mould infection do not need yeast prophylaxis
Describe prophylaxis against yeast infection (candida)
Fluconazole 400mg PO daily
Describe prophylaxis against herpes simplex virus

aciclovir 400 mg orally, 12-hourly
OR
valaciclovir 500 mg orally, daily (12-hourly in highly immunosuppressed patients)
OR (if unable to tolerate oral therapy)
aciclovir 5 mg/kg IV, 8-hourly.

Not required if already on prophylaxis for CMV
Describe prophylaxis for varicella zoster virus

aciclovir 800 mg orally, 12-hourly
OR
valaciclovir 500 mg orally, 12-hourly
OR (if unable to tolerate oral therapy)
aciclovir 5 mg/kg IV, 8-hourly.

Not required if already taking CMV prophylaxis
Describe universal prophylaxis, and pre-emptive treatment, for CMV

Valganciclovir 900mg PO daily

If active graft vs host disease of the gut, or severe diarrhoea, use
Ganciclovir IV
Describe the mechanism of action of echinocandins (caspofungin, micafungin)
inhibit beta 1,3-d-glucan synthesis inhibitors, thereby inhibiting fungal cell wall synthesis
Describe the spectrum of activity of echinocandins (caspofungin, micafungin)

Very narrow spectrum:
Fungostatic against aspergillus
Fungocidal against candida
Name 1 antifungal class that may be used for severe invasive candida infection or candidaemia
Echinocandins: anidulafungin, caspofungin and micafungin (because fungocidal)
Name 2 antifungals that require drug level monitoring

Voriconazole
Posaconazole

Improves response/treatment success, reduces toxicity
How is mycobacterium tubercolosis transmitted?

1-5 micrometer airborne particles
Low infectious dose (1-10 organisms)
Prolonged close contact in poorly ventilated surrounds results in transmission
Describe the natural history of mycobacterium TB infection

Exposure (20-30% of close contacts infected) -->
Latent TB infection -->
10% at some point reactivate, usually in setting of precipitating factors (HIV, immunosuppression, low body weight, diabetes, renal impairment, smoking, etc)
What is the impact of HIV infection of mycobacterium TB infection, in terms of risk of reactivation?

Drastically increased risk of reactivation
Instead of lifetime risk of 10%, becomes 10% per year
Control of replication and establishing latent infection in mycobacterium TB (as opposed to active infection) is mediated by what factors?

T cell immunity
Interferon gamma
TNF alpha

Hence anti-TNF, things that interfere with interferon gamma, greatly increase risk of reactivation
Describe the role of quantiferon gold in TB diagnosis and management

NOT recommended for diagnosing active TB
Can tell if exposed to TB or not; cannot differentiate between active and latent infection
Cannot be used to determine if successful treatment (remains positive for life)
Negative result does not rule out TB
Describe the classical presentation of TB

Subacute presentation (>3 weeks) of cough and sputum
Haemoptysis
Fever, night sweats, weight loss
Pleuritic pain
Upper lobe predominance, presence of cavitation or pleural effusion
Describe the non-pulmonary manifestations of TB (6)

Tuberculous lymphadenitis (30%), most commonly cervical - diagnosis with biopsy/aspirate
Bone/joint (particularly spinal) TB with chronic unrelenting back pain - need biopsy
Genitourinary TB -- sterile pyuria, need early morning urine mycobacterial culture
Chronic epididymo-orchitis
Pelvic TB in women with infertility and chronic pain
CNS TB with meningitis, tuberculoma
Describe tuberculosis meningitis

1% of TB
Peak incidence in children <4 and immunosuppressed adults
1 week to 1 month of symptoms - fever, meningism, culminating in focal neurology and seizures
May or may not have pulmonary involvement
Describe investigations for tuberculosis meningitis

CSF: lymphocytic pleocytosis, low glucose (ddx for this: cryptococcal meningitis)
MRI: basal meningitis
AFB and TB-PCR have poor sensitivity (20 - 50%), often treat as culture negative
Describe the treatment of tuberculosis meningitis

Isoniazid
Rifampicin
Moxifloxacin (rather than ethambutol - better CNS penetration)
Pyrazinamide
Dexamethasone for 6 - 8 weeks

9 - 12 months total treatment
Name 3 diagnostic tests for TB

PCR (rapid)
Acid fast bacilli
Culture (takes 2 - 6 weeks, antibiotic sensitivities take 8 weeks)
Describe the standard short course treatment of TB

Isoniazid
PLUS
rifampicin
PLUS
ethambutol 
PLUS
pyrazinamide

All four agents for 2 months (initial phase), then isoniazid and rifampicin for further 4 months (continuation phase) (total 6 months)

98% cure
Describe 3 toxicities of isoniazid

Hepatitis
Rash 
Neuropathy
Describe 2 toxicities of rifampicin

Drug interactions
Hepatitis
Describe 3 toxicities of pyrazinamide

Hepatitis
Rash
Gout, joint pain
Describe 1 toxicity of ethambutol
Optic neuropathy
What percentage of TB therapy patients will develop hepatitis as a drug toxicity, and which agents are to blame?

5%
Pyrazinamide > isoniazid > rifampicin
Describe the management of TB therapy induced hepatitis

If ALT 2 - 5x ULN and asymptomatic - monitor
If >5x ULN or symptoms, cease all therapy
- if can't interrupt, use ethambutol, moxiflocacin, amikacin
Restart once ALT < 2x ULT
- restart ethambutol + rifampicin, then isoniazid. If tolerated, it was probably the pyrazinamide; do not restart this, and extend therapy to 9 months instead.
What is primary drug resistance in TB?
Infection with a drug resistent strain of TB
What is secondary drug resistance in TB?
Development of resistance in an initially susceptible strain
What is the commonest mono-drug resistance in TB?
Isoniazid (4.6% in australia)
Why do we use combination therapy in TB?

Large number of TB bacteria (109 - 1010 bacteria), because of this at least a few will be resistant to any given drug due to spontaneous mutation
- isoniazid, 1 in 106
- rifampicin, 1 in 108
However chance of spontaneous mutation to more than one drug is highly unlikely
Use multiple drugs to kill off the resistant clones (may be resistant to one drug, but will not be to the other)
Describe the treatment of isoniazid-resistant TB
Rifampicin, pyrazinamide, ethambutol for 6 - 9 months
Describe the treatment of pyrazinamide resistant TB
Isoniazid + rifampicin for 9 months
Define multi-drug resistant TB

Resistance to isoniazid and rifampicin (+/- other resistance)
1.7% of Australian cases
Define extensively drug resistant TB

Resistance to rifapicin AND isoniazid AND quinolones AND at least one injectable (amikacin, kanamycin, or capreomycin)
Morality >20%
Name 2 risk factors for multi drug resistant TB

Previous TB treatment
- 60 - 70% have no history of prior treatment
Contact with multi drug resistant TB or residence in a 'hot zone'
Describe how testing for multi drug resistant TB is performed

Rapid drug resistance detection: genotypic detection of rifampicin by analysis of rifampicin resistance determining region, rpoB, via PCR (GeneXpert)
- Can detect TB, and also if resistant
- Sensitivity 98% if smear positive, 75% if smear negative (improve to 90% with 3 sputums)
Rifampicin resistance is highly predictive of multi-drug resistant TB
What is the test of choice for rapid diagnosis of TB in HIV positive patients?

GeneXpert (cartridge-based PCR for rpoB)
30% more sensitive than smear in HIV
Describe the Bangladeshi regimen management of multi drug resistant TB

4 months: Isoniazid (double dose) + moxifloxacin + pyrazinamide + ethambutol + amikacin + prothionamide + clofazimine
5 - 8 months: pyrazinamide, ethambutol, moxiflocaxin

Success 80 - 90%
Cannot use in pregnancy, extrapulmonary TB
Describe treatment of multi drug resistant TB

Aim for 5 drugs, at least 12 months treatment

An injectable (amikacin or capreomycin)
A fluoroquinolone (moxiflocacin)
Two drugs from group C (linezolid, clofazimine)
Then one from group D1, D2, or D3

Consider surgical resection in selected cases
Describe the presentation of TB in HIV patients with CD4 < 200

Cavitation rare
Atypical CXR
Smear negative more common
Extrapulmonary more common (40 - 80%)
- nodes
- miliary
- meningitis
- dissemination, bacteraemia
Describe the presentation of TB in HIV patients with CD4 count > 200
Same as non-HIV patients
Describe the drug interactions between rifampicin and HIV antiretrovirals (5)

Do not use
Tenofovir alafenamide + rifampicin (old tenofovir, tenofovir disoproxil is OK)
Protease inhibitors + rifampicin
Elvitegravir/corbicistat + rifampicin
Bictegraivir + rifampicin

Change dose
Double dose of raltegravir or dolutegravir if + rifampicin
Describe a regimen that can be used to treat HIV in the setting of TB co-infection on standard TB therapy

Truvada (emtricitabine + tenofovir disoproxil)
AND
Double dose raltegravir or dolutegravir

Once stopped TB therapy, wait 1 month then go back to normal therapy
What percentage of TB/HIV co-infected patients will get IRIS when they start antiretrovirals?

Name 4 mechanisms by which microbes can acquire antibiotic resistance

Chromosomal mutation
Plasmids
Transposons (free DNA)
Bacteriophage (virus)
Name 4 mechanisms of antibiotic resistance

Antibiotic inactivation, e.g. beta lactamases
Alterationo fo antibiotic target site
Decreased antibiotic permeability of the cell wall, preventing drug access to target
Active antibiotic efflux from the bacteria
Describe beta lactamases

Secreted by gram positive organisms, into the milieu surrounding the organism (they are exoenzymes)
Confer resistance to beta lactam antibiotics

Also found in the periplasmic space in gram negative pathogens
Describe the appearance of staph aureus
Gram positive cocci in grape-like bunches (not chains)
This is a CSF sample. What is the abnormality?

Large number of white blood cells
Inside the neutrophil in the centre are gram negative diplococci - neisseria meningitidis (meningococcal meningitis)
What does clavulanic acid do

It is a beta lactam
Acts as a 'suicide inhibitor' of beta lactamases - binds to beta lactamase and prevents it from inactivating the antibiotic it is co-administered with (typically amoxicillin), to overcome beta lactamase penicillin resistance
What are the ESCAPPM organisms?

Organisms with inducible chromosomally-mediated beta lactamase production
Will appear sensitive to beta lactams on initial testing, but quickly become resistant with therapy
Beta lactam antibiotics should never be used.

Enterobacter
Serratia
Citrobacter
ACinetobacter
Pseudomonas
Proteus vulgaris
Morganella morganii
Name 2 inactivating enzymes that may be produced by a bacteria to confer antibiotic resistance

Beta lactamases
Aminoglycoside modifying enzymes
What are penicillin binding proteins?

PBPs are associate with the bacterial cell membrane
Have functions essential for wall synethesis and remodelling
Beta lactam antibiotics bind to specific PBPs, causing cell death
Alteration in PBP target sites results in resistance to pencillin 
- e.g. penicillin resistant strep pneumoniae
- methicillin resistant staph aureus (MRSA) via mecA gene
Name 1 gene that is an absolute requirement for staph aureus to become methicillin resistant (MRSA)

mecA gene
Codes for penicillin binding protein 2a (PBP2a), which has a low affinity for beta lactam antibiotics, hence they cannot bind and destroy the cell wall
What is the mechanism of action of fluoroquinolones?

Direct inhibitors of bacterial DNA synthesis - target bacterial enzymes DNA gyrase and topoisomerase IV
Bactericidal
e.g. moxifloxacin, ciprofloxacin
Describe the mechanism of fluoroquinolone resistance

Alteration of the target, bacterial DNA gyrase
No longer blocked by the fluoroquinolones, so bacteria can multiply
Describe the mechanism of resistance to streptomycin
Alteration of the target, 30s ribosomal sub-unit
Describe the mechanism of resistance to erythromycin
Alteration of the target, 50s ribosomal subunit
What is the mechanism of action of rifamycins?

Inhibit bacterial DNA-dependent RNA polymerase, as a result of drug binding in the polymerase subunit deep within the DNA/RNA channel, facilitating direct blocking of the elongating RNA 
E.g. rifampicin
Describe how gram negative bacteria can decrease their cell wall permeability to antibiotics in order to become resistant

Gram negative bacteria have porins in their cell wall, through which antibiotics enter
Changes in the size and hydrophobicity of these can decrease penetration by antibiotics
e.g. resistance in enterobacteriaceae and pseudomonas to trimethoprim and fluoroquinolones
Name the 4 types of beta lactam antibiotic

Penicillins
Monobactams
Cephalosporins
Carbapenems
Describe the spectrum of activity of penicillins

Gram positives e.g. enterococcus faecalis, liseria, staphylococcus aueus, coagulase negative staph,  streptococci, strep viridans
Anaerobes e.g. clostridium perfringens, actinomyces, fusobacteria
